The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: THE Subject-matter of the≈øe en≈øuing sheets, concerning Chri≈øtian Re≈øolution, & Humble Submi≈øsion to the will of God, in times of di≈øtre≈øse, (according to the example of the holy Patriach Jacob) & Hearty ≈øubjection to the King, according to the Doctrine of the Church of England, & our many Indi≈øpen≈øable tyes of Con≈øcience, will, with all tho≈øe few who truly Feare God & Honour the King, ≈øufficiently a pologize, I hope, for the publication of them, in a Juncture, & an Age, advanced to the highe≈øt contempt & defiance both of Loyalty and Religion.

That Incen≈øed God, who hath for our manifold provocations, and more particularly (wee have rea≈øon to believe) for our Carnall Confidence in the Arme of Flesh, & Di≈øobedience to Gods Vice-Gerent, powred out the vialls of his wrath on three Kingdoms, is not like to be appea≈øed, without the ≈øerious practice of the contrary Graces, in a manner, as Univer≈øall, and generall, as hath been our late notorious Defection towards the King, by an abhorr'd & dete≈øtable Violation of the many ≈øacred, & often repeated Oaths, whereby all ≈øubjccts were obliged to ≈øupport his Crowne & Dignity.

Such is my ≈øen≈øe of what is pa≈øt, & Dread of Allmighty Gods future Indignation, when I con≈øider that I am (how weak and unworthy ≈øoever) advanced to a publick ≈øtation in the Church of England, that I cannot ≈øatisfy my ≈øelfe, with mourning in ≈øecret, but conceive it my indi≈øpen≈øable duty to proclame (after ≈øuch a Stupendious Revolution) as ≈øoon, & as well, as I am able, to all per≈øons in the Kingdom, my unfeigned Re≈øolution to adhere to my Soveraigne, in his di≈øtre≈øse; lea≈øt I may, by ≈øilence, contribute to the increa≈øe of that dangerous Lethargy, which hath ≈øeized on the People of England, who, by Re≈øi≈øting, & at length De≈øerting, their Prince, have Apo≈øtatized from their Religion.

I have helped, po≈øsibly‚ñ™ as litle as any one of my Brethren, or fellow-≈øubjects, in the Nation, to the fir≈øt growth of this di≈øea≈øe, having for ≈øix & tuentie years together openned my mouth widely‚ñ™ on Topicks, which would have prevented (had they met vvith due regard) our pre≈øent mi≈øery: & for the truth whereof, I appeale to the whole Juri≈ødiction whereto I have long related.

But however I cannot think my-≈øelfe perfectly di≈øengaged to ioyn in attempting the Cure, or, at lea≈øt, to help on vvhat is, God bee thanked, in ≈øome ≈øort begun, & vvhereto the contradictory, & prepo≈øterous, proceedings of the Kings enimies have a≈øsi≈øted; I mean to the oppenning the eyes of thou≈øands in England, to ≈øee already the madne≈øs of their Change, & the Errors of their late method to redre≈øse Grievances; by labouring to bring their Soveraigne to Termes (all that vvas aimed at, I do in Charity beleive, by the Church of Englands fallen ≈øons) and to deliver the Nation from Dome≈øtick Evills by calling for Forreigne A≈øsi≈øtance. ¬ß. The number of ≈øouls committed to my charge, in the Cathedrall, in my Archdeaconry, & in the Peculiar Juri≈ødiction depending on the Church of Durham, are too many, & too con≈øiderable, to be forgotten, or neglected by me, now, incapacitated othervvi≈øe to Preach to them.

Therefore in this low Ebb of Loyalty, vvhen In≈øtances of firme fidelity to ones Prince are ≈øo rare, the Dean of Durham, it is hoped, vvill be pardonned, if he ≈øets ≈øo much value on his ovvn Example, as to make u≈øe of it, as vvell as his vvords & vvritings, tovvards the Extricating the People, vvith vvho≈øe ≈øoules hee hath been Intru≈øted, out of the Labyrinth vvhereinto they are Run, by Non-Compliance vvith their Lavvfull & Gratious Soveraigne, & ready Concurrence vvith a Forreign U≈øurper, or, at lea≈øt, tovvards the Hindring them from Running farther yet into it, & remaining ≈øtupidly in ≈øo ≈øinfull and deplorable a ≈øtate & condition.

This induces me to vvish, that I could bring the la≈øt vvords, I ≈øpoke to the Clergy & Eccle≈øia≈øtick Officers of my Archdeaconry, & to the Members of the Cathedrall and Citty of Durham (contained in the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øes) to the vievv and con≈øideration of the vvhole County & Dioce≈øse‚ñ™ that tho≈øe, vvho vvere ab≈øent vvhen I utterd them, may, as vvell as tho≈øe pre≈øent, partake of my poor zeale and endeavours for their ≈øpirituall Advantage; vvhich is all the Returne, I can at pre≈øent make, for the temporall Benefits I have reaped in that country, during
my injoyment of ≈øundry con≈øiderable Preferments among them.

If ≈øuch Communication of my‚ñ™ Papers cannot be ≈øo ≈øoon, & ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øefully, effected, as I would, by rea≈øon all Intercour≈øe betwixt the Kingdom of England, & this wherein I re≈øide, is ≈øtop'd, I am willing, in the meane while, to let the world ≈øee, that I am not Idle, or Unconcerned, but do all that in me lyes, towards this hone≈øt End, whereby if no proffit accrews to them, or others, I shall ea≈øe my mind & deliver my ≈øoule.

If any are plea≈øed to cen≈øure, contemn, or reject my writings, becau≈øe they find nothing in them Learned, or Elaborate, ot (where of the Age is over-fond) Controver≈øial, I de≈øire them to con≈øider, that Polemik Learning & Divinity, are things I never did, nor shall pretend to. And that in the month of November 88. when I ≈øpake to the Clergy, & in the fir≈øt week of December following, when I preached in the Abby, at Durham (as ill as things did portend) I little dreamt, that my Soveraigne, or ≈øelfe, should be put under an unavoidable nece≈ø≈øity to fly in to an other Kingdome; or that I should be obliged to make u≈øe of ≈øuch meanes, & methods to Evidence my ≈øincerity in my Religion (the fir≈øt thing I should ≈øtrive to Evince to all tho≈øe to who≈øe ≈øpiritual A≈ø≈øi≈øtance I admini≈øter) otherwi≈øe more „Äà‚óä„Äâ Regard would had been had to the Penning & Compo≈øure.

But ≈øince I am reduced to ≈øuch hard circum≈øtances (whereto, in conformity to my own Doctrine I Heartily ≈øubmit) & that the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øes, how ≈øleight ≈øoever & little worth, in them≈øelves, are abundantly ≈øufficient to demon≈øtrate, that both my Religion & Loya ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y are not of the New Cutt, but of the old Royall ≈øtamp, & carry whith them, I tru≈øt, the true Touch of the Tower, Providence invites me to expo≈øes them to publick view, being ambitious of nothing in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e world more, than to approve my ≈øelfe (in this Day of Rebuke) to my Soveraigne, & his rigth Loyal ≈øubjects, for one who thinks that hee obliged to be as Faithfull to a Roman-Catholick, as a Prote≈øtant, Prince, & as true to him in Adver≈øity, as Pro≈øperity.

As far any Cen≈øures of vanity ari≈øing from my Title-Page, as if I did there ≈øet forth my ≈øelfe √† Patterne of humility & Loyalty, they ought not to ≈øway with me ≈øo farre, as to ≈øtop me, in my Endeavours to be ≈øo, or to per≈øwade others to become ≈øuch, ≈øince thereto
Heaven, at this tyme, loudly ≈øummons all the Nation.

This I can truly ≈øay, without Pride or Boa≈øting, that I have labour'd to practi≈øe, what I have preached to others, & that I was never more, than at this very in≈øtant, a≈øpiring towards tho≈øe Excellent (but rare) vertues mentionned in the following di≈øcour≈øes, which I commend to Gods Ble≈ø≈øing, & the Candid Readers Charity; de≈øiring all per≈øons in England, who have labour'd, either by Kind Invitations, or Threats of deprivation to prevaile with m ‚Ä¢ , to returne, & ≈øubmit to the new Government; to receive this as my finall An≈øver.

div.head: TO THE QUEEN OF ENGLAND.
div.p:
ALLMIGHTY GOD having enabled mee, by his grace, to re≈øist tho≈øe temptations which have overcome the greate≈øt number of the members of my own Church and Country, and being now incapacitated here a bread to render my Soveraigne, and your Maje≈øty, better ≈øervice than to owne your Righteous Cau≈øe, I think my ≈øelfe obliged to give the world a more than ordinary Te≈øtimony of my ≈øincere Loyalty and Re≈øolution, in all times and Changes, to adhere unalterably to the Crowne. Having therefore allready ≈øacrificed my Revenue by quitting the Nation rather than ≈øubmit to the V≈øurpation, and expo≈øed my ≈øelfe to Cen≈øure and Obloquy in that part of England wherein I have Lived, by Refu≈øing to Head, or Ioine with tho≈øe my dependants there, Eccle≈øia≈øticall and Secular, who have departed from their Allegiance, I know of no better and more Convincing In≈øtance yet remaining to bee given by mee of my ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈øs to stick to, and ≈øerve, the Royall familie, than to proclame that I dare ≈øpeake truth here a broad from the Pre≈øse as well as from the Pulpit at home, tho every one mu≈øt fore-know that ≈øuch an hone≈øt Boldne≈øs will unavoidably render mee uncapable of the favour and good opinion of all tho≈øe per≈øons, in the Nation (High and Low Spirituall and Temporal) who have Shipwrackt their Faith and Con≈øciences by cea≈øing to yeild (after often swearing) Allegiance and Fidelity to their Soveraigne. And it is ea≈øy to fore-≈øee, that the Printing the≈øe, and ≈øome other Papers, at this time, in mine ovvn name, will thus render mee obnoxious (as I am Contented to bee) to all tho≈øe Builders, who imploy them≈øelves in Erecting a New Monarchy and Church in England. But the A≈øper≈øions of them that for≈øake their Religion, as far as they de≈øert their Lavvfull Liege Lord, (as I hope the follovving sheets will evidence) vvill bee no intolerable Load to mee, who de≈øire no greater Honour and ≈øatisfaction,
than to share with my King, Queen, and hope-full young Prince, in their Misfortunes, and thereby to demon≈øtrate that my poor di≈øtre≈øsed Mother, in the greate≈øt and mo≈øt generall defection (as this ≈øeemes to be) that ever vvas among any King of Englands ≈øubjects, vvill never vvant ≈øome to bear te≈øtimony to the truth of her Doctrine; vvho, according to the Exemple of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, doth maintaine the practice of Allegiance, and intire ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and ≈øubjection to all Lavvfull ≈øupreme povvers, deputed by God as his Vice-Gerents to Governe the vvorld. Hovv great a contradiction hereof ≈øoever, the la≈øt years tran≈øactions in England have proved (vvhich hath given the greate≈øt vvound that vvas ever yet given to our Church) the Doctrine of Non-re≈øi≈øtance Remaines on ≈øuch authentick Record in the Church of Englands Printed Homilies again≈øt Rebellion (vvhich I have in ≈øome ≈øort Epitomi≈øed in the conclu≈øion of my di≈øcour≈øe) that your Maje≈øty, as vvell as the King, vvil, I hope, bee plea≈øed to continue your Charitie to our Eccle≈øia≈øtick Con≈øtitution, vvith liberty to its members to Exerci≈øe their Religion, and thinke no vvor≈øe of the Parent for the di≈øobedience of the Children, but render that Iu≈øtice to the Church of England, vvhich is due to all Churches, to vvit, to bee Iudged by her Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, and Order (vvhich I am ≈øure never did carry a long vvith them any Rebellion) and not by the practice or Conver≈øation of its Members. VVhereby if the vvhole Chri≈øtian Church vvas to bee Iudged it vvould, in many things, appeare more vile then ≈øome parts of the vvorld overrun vvith Turci≈øme and Pagani≈øme.

Offerring to God my mo≈øt fervent devotions for the pre≈øervation and Re≈øtoration of the King, the Life and Happine≈øse of the Prince, and (out of Gratitude to Heaven) in a mo≈øt particular manner for your Maje≈øty, vvho have been In≈øtrumentall to the Greate≈øt ble≈øsing vvhich hath been the≈øe many yeares conferred on the Kingdom, in bearing and bringing forth an Heir male for the ≈øupport of the Monarchy, I do, vvith all humility, implore yours, together vvith his Maje≈øties Patronage, as vvell as beg Pardon for this Pre≈øumption, and vvith the mo≈øt profound re≈øpect imaginable ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelfe

div.p:
FOR the better Under≈øtanding of the Story it Will be requi≈øire to reade the precedent Words from the 11. ver≈øe to the text. v. 11. As when wee ≈øay 4. is more than 2. the whole is greater than part; perfect knowledge of ≈øen≈øe & Experience ab≈øolutely conclude it mo≈øt certain.

The certainty of our Salvation is a faithfull cleaving to the ≈øure promi≈øes of CHRIST JESUS. Tho this in re≈øpect of it ≈øelfe be more ab≈øolute than that of ≈øen≈øe, as faith is more certain than any ≈øcience, yet mans mind not throughly purged, from the foggy Mi≈øts of Original pollution, cannot clearly determine.

CHRIST indeed hath broken downe the Partition VVall between God & his people, yet hath hee ≈øet the Regi≈øter of his Elect, beyond the ken of any mortall eye. Neither can wee a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelves any otherwi≈øe of our Salvation, than by trusting in him, by applying particularly what hee (that cannot lye) hath ≈øpoken in Generall. VVho≈øoever believeth in mee shall be ≈øaved. And this is in no man ≈øo perfect, but that the be≈øt may ≈øtill pray, adjuva me Domine, Lord helpe my unbeleife. Hee that doth not thus feare, hath no faith and then no certainty.

As the Spirit of God vvitne≈øseth vvee are the ≈øons of God, ≈øo Feare te≈øtifieth wee have the Spirit. No man more ≈øurely relyes on his Saviour, than hee that mo≈øt feares to Offend him; ≈øo is it no paradox at the ≈øame time to tremble and rejoyce in the Lord. The frailty of our nature & the ≈øubtilty of the Divell con≈øpire for our Ruine; here is good Cau≈øe to fear. But JESUS CHRIST is our Castle & Defence, here is greater Cau≈øe to rejoyce.

A man on the top of an high tower looking downe & con≈øidering the danger of a fall trembles to thinke thereon, but looking back on his feet & ≈øeeing him≈øelfe environned on every ≈øide with battlements rejoyceth that hee is ≈øo ≈øecure of the danger. So the mo≈øt ≈øteddy beleiver tho hee know that under the protection of the Allmighty hee cannot mi≈øcarry, yet hee (≈øometimes) trembles to reflect on the deplorable E≈øtate of Falling away. Allbeit his principle bee true, the Word of God cannot faile in any tittle, VVho≈øoever beleiveth shall bee ≈øaved, yet is hee Iealous of mi≈øapplying it to him≈øelfe. Tho hee thinketh hee ≈øtandeth, hee mu≈øt take heed lea≈øt hee fall. For it is the Condition of Grace & Faith as of Nature, ≈øtill to de≈øire encrea≈øe & perfection, which nece≈ø≈øatily requires earne≈øt prayer, and this implies a ≈øollicitous Feare.

So then wee may ≈øay of a Christian, as ≈øcipio ≈øometimes ≈øpake of Rome, it was more ≈øecure when it ≈øtood in awe of Cartbage. The Church was never freer from Heri≈øies than in the time of Per≈øecution, and the End of Per≈øecution was the beginning of Heri≈øy, Wee are mo≈øt certain, when wee are mo≈øt tempted. When Sathan de≈øires to vvinnovv S. Peter as vvheat, then Chri≈øts prayer a≈ø≈øures him of Salvation. Chri≈øts Interce≈ø≈øions are more prevalent than any temptation, and unle≈ø≈øe wee render them ineffectuall by impenitency, they are never in vain. Neverthele≈ø≈øe his Prayer may not hinder ours, nor his All≈øufficiency exclude our labours. Wee mu≈øt pray to him, & hee will pray for us. Let us fullfill
his Commandements, & hee will fullfill his Promi≈øes. If wee Love him, let us feare to offend him. If wee have Confidence of our Election in him, then let us u≈øe all diligence to make our Calling & this our Election ≈øure, by adding good vvorkes to our Faith, in doing where of wee shall never fall. It was an Heathen Cannon, that Fortune should not be prayed unto, but with hands in Motion; intimating that no Sacrifice could be accepted from a ≈øluggard. And it is the Apostles Rule, wee all know, to add Vertue to Faith, industry to Prayer. For to cry God helpe, & not to put to our helping hand, is as vaine as to labour without Gods Helpe. Not as if his Power were in≈øufficient, but becau≈øe our Endeavour is required to entitle us to his ble≈ø≈øing.

Shall the Plovvman burne his Plow, or Marriner his ship? becau≈øe God hath ≈øaid I vvill never leave thee nor for≈øake thee. Shall vvee not provide decent cloathing? becau≈øe vvee mu≈øt not take inordinate care for Raiment. Becau≈øe CHRIST ≈øayth, take no Care vvhat yee shall eat, shall vvee therefore expect another vvhite sheet from Heaven? Or vvith the ≈øuggard in the Fable, lye on the ground, and expect the falling of the figgs vvith Open mouth. Which is not to ≈øerve God, but to tempt him. Such idlene≈øse becomes none vvor≈øe than a ≈øouldier of CHRISTS band. The vvatch-man mu≈øt vvatch, though it be God that pre≈øerveth the citty. His vineyard mu≈øt be husbanded, & his Garden dre≈øt. Paul mu≈øt plant, & Apollos vvater, before God give the increa≈øe. God could have healed Hezekiah vvithout a Bunch of figs. Our Saviour, no doubt, could have ≈øpoken the vvord to the blinde man, and hee should have received his ≈øight; but that his actions might bee our Examples, hee u≈øes meanes for the Cure, hee anointed his eyes vvith clay, bad him vvash in the poole of Siloam before hee could ≈øee. And in the 27 of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, hee gives S. Paul all the ≈øoules in the ship. His promi≈øe could not faile, yet their ovvn ≈øedulity vvas required to their Safety; by ≈øvvimming & u≈øing broken pieces (you vvill find by the ≈øtory) they all came ≈øafe to the Land. For hovv certain ≈øoever things are in re≈øpect of him vvho knovveth the End of all things, as vvell of tho≈øe vvhich shall be, as tho≈øe vvhich are or have been, they are not ≈øo in re≈øpect of our knovvledge (as you have heard) vvherefore vvee mu≈øt not idly Ca≈øt our ≈øelves upon his Providence, but humbly ≈øubmit our ≈øelves unto it, allvvayes shevving our devotion in Prayers again≈øt an Evill, tho vvee cannot our Povver in overcoming itt.

Di≈øcreet Diligence mu≈øt accompany our Affection; Faith mu≈øt be our Anchor, & vvee mu≈øt Rovve vvith Feare, even vvith Feare & Trembling, in the lea≈øt matter of our Salvation. Not like tho≈øe vvho≈øe Faith dares ≈øpeak as boldy to their Maker as their Neighbour, and hear his Emba≈øsage vvith le≈øse reverence, nay vvith like familiarily, as the Me≈ø≈øage from an Acquaintance, ≈øearching into the very ≈øecrets of God, and pre≈øuming to learne, vvhat God hath refu≈øed to teach; A Generation vvhich may beknovvn by their Boldne≈øse, vvho take Chri≈øts Office upon them≈øelves, and vvill vveed out tho≈øe tares vvhich hee ≈øaid should grovv vvith the vvheat till the Harve≈øt. And like true Phari≈øees they ≈øeparate them≈øelves from the Congregation of their Btethren, thinking them≈øelves more Holy than they, & more skillfull in Gods Coun≈øells than if they vvere imediately in≈øpired from on high, intrepreting Gods Deepe≈øt Mi≈øteries vvithout an „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , at fir≈øt ≈øight, yea and that more ≈øanctifiedly too than vvith a Months preparation.

Daniel (I doubt not) as vvi≈øe a man & as holy as any of the≈øe meu, Eccle≈øia≈øtick or Layick ‚Ä¢ , vvill not pre≈øume to intrepret ≈øo much as a Dreame vvithout re≈øpite and con≈øideration; Hee fir≈øt Prayes, you vvill finde, vvith his Company to God for Mercy concerning the ≈øecret. Nor vvill He≈øter ≈øpeake unto her King, untill shee be a≈øsi≈øted vvith the prayers of all the Ievves in Shushan. And S. Iohn (as S. Ierome reports in his prologue upon S. Matthevv) intreated by the Bishops of A≈øia his Brethren, to vvrite his Go≈øpell, again≈øt the Heriticks Ebion & Cerinthus, fir≈øt required a publick Fa≈øt to be ≈øolemnized throughout the vvhole Church.

Such preparation in a Proportion is requi≈øite in our le≈øser affaires. Rashly to enter the li≈øts of any bu≈øine≈øse (e≈øpetially that vvhich is ≈øacred) is impudently to Challenge a Ble≈øsing not to entreat one, vvhich profane Neglect of Duty hovv slightly ≈øoever men e≈øteem of it, ≈øavours of Infidelity & Athei≈øme. For vvho can Confe≈ø≈øe a Deity and be ignorant of its concurrence to all actions, and vvho can knovv this, & vvithout great impiety, forbeare to implore its a≈øsi≈øtance.

To ask Helpe of God the Creatour can be no prejudice to man, his Creature; but his greate≈øt advantage & highe≈øt Honour. Nether do mans ordinary meanes & endeavours detract from Gods All≈øufficient Providence but declare its Povver. Wee ≈øceing the ≈ølenderne≈øse of our ovvne ≈øtrength, vvith greater admiration, acknovvledge his Omnipotence vvhich vvorketh all in all.

Our Good old Father Iacob here well knew the Povver & Mercy of God, yet doth hee not pre≈øume in a danger though hee be re≈øolved to beare it; but u≈øes his be≈øt meanes, his faithfull Heart & trembling Hand are imployed together: The one in providing Pre≈øents for the Ruler of Egypt, the other in ≈øending up Prayers to God. If the fir≈øt cannot per≈øvvade him, the la≈øt shall command him. Faith is the ground of his diligence, Hee fir≈øt relyes on Gods Mercy; and Feare the Rule of his actions, Hee goes about to pacify the Rule.

Well then (quoth hee) if it mu≈øt bee ≈øo, my ≈øons, do thus, take of the be≈øt fruits of the Land in your ve≈øsels, alittle balme, alitle Honey ≈øpices & mirrhe, nutts and Almonds, &c. His Prayers ≈øecond his outward meanes, And God Allmighty, ≈øayes hee, give you Mercy before the Man, that hee may ≈øend avvay your other Brother and Benjamin, and what ≈øoever happens, I will endure it, yea, IF I BE BEREAVED OF MY CHILDREN, I AM BEREAVED.
Sermon. II HITHERTO you have heard the nece≈øsity & manner of Submitting to the VVill of God. I shall now enter on the 3 Part. of my text, & shew you the Benefit redounding from ≈øuch ≈øubmi≈øsions.

Part. III This ca≈øts mee un avoidably upon a Common Place, and one of the mo≈øt Common of Common Places even that of Adver≈øity or afflistion, as often preached as felt. However there will be noe cau≈øe to pa≈øse it over, ≈øince I am naturally led thereto by the Time, as well as my Text, a Time of Iudgement, of VVar, & of Danger, threatning our Poor Church & Kingdom with a heavy mea≈øure of affliction, & large portion of this Bitter Cup, which I feare is like to bee felt, or ta≈øted (unle≈øse a ≈øpeedy Returne in Duty to God & the King prevent) by our ≈øelves, & our Po≈øterity. While temporall cro≈øses remaine (which dye only with Man) wee mu≈øt preach their Nece≈øsity & Benefit; The one as ab≈øolute, the other to the Godly certaine.

To Doe Good & ≈øuffer vvrong after CHRISTS ble≈øsed Example, is an E≈øpeciall part of Christian life & Duty. Your Diligence hath been required for the fir≈øt, the la≈øt requires your Humility upon the ≈øame grounds of Faith & Feare; whereto if you do add (≈øince Heaven frowns upon this Land,) a profound Humiliation, you will do more than God Expects at your hands.

Not to feare Affliction becomes a Rigid Sceptick, or ≈øen≈øele≈øs Stoick, not an affectionate Iacob, or tender hearted Io≈øeph. On the other ≈øide,
to be utterly ca≈øt downe in the Bed of Sorrow, fits not an Abraham, but a Cain. Both Good & Iu≈øt is God, ≈øaith holy David; Good & Gratious to teach patient ≈øinners in the vvay; but Ju≈øt all≈øo to punish tho≈øe, vvhich run on ≈øtill in their iniquity.
Happy then are tho≈øe troubled ≈øpirits (let mee minde them) where this Con≈øtellation appeares, where Feare acknowledgeth God a Iust Iudge, and Faith beleiveth him a loving Father.

Adver≈øity indeed, is the Di≈øcipline of Gods hou≈øe, under which hee brings up his Children, through feare of which hee bridles their inordinate affections, & by di≈øenabling and mortifying them workes an unwillingne≈øse to offend. For Example.

The Rich man ≈øpoiled of his Riches, ≈øees their uncertainty, and ≈øo flies back from his eager pur≈øuit of them to him that gave them. The Vain-glorious & ambitious man degraded from Court to Cottage, and after all his Indu≈øtry & endeavour to Ri≈øe, brought Low, & made an Object of Contempt, ≈øees plainly there is no Confidence in any humane Helpe, no not in the be≈øt and mo≈øt Potent of Princes, nor in any child of man (according to Davids ob≈øervation) teaching him to tru≈øt only on the King of Kings. The Good Father here in the text bereaved of his Children, confe≈ø≈øes they were but a broken ≈øtaffe, and when hee could not longer continue a Father, contented him≈øelfe fully that hee was the Child of God.

So prone is our Nature to all Voluptiou≈øne≈øse and uncleane≈ø≈øe‚ñ™ and ≈øo rebellious are our affections again≈øt any good, that nothing but this Wormewood can weane us from ≈øucking the dregs of worldly & ≈øen≈øuall Plea≈øures, or ≈øtop us in this Earthly pilgrimage from running headlong to de≈øtruction. Hee is certainly mi≈øerable, vvho never felt any mi≈øery, if wee beleive Seneca, and it is good Divinity in the Heathens own ≈øen≈øe. Hos itaque quos probat Deus, quos amat, indurar, Lib. Cur bonis viris mala accidunt. c. 4.
recogno≈øcit, exercet, quibus indulgere, quibus parcere videtur molles venturis malis ≈øervat. Very neare that of the Apo≈øtle, Heb. 12. 6. The Lord Cha≈øteneth vvhom hee loveth, and ≈øcourgeth every ≈øon vvhom hee receiveth, but re≈øerveth whom hee ≈øeemeth to pa≈ø≈øe by (Quibus parcere videtur, hee doth but ≈øeeme to pa≈øse them over) for greater punishment.

God le≈øse regards a thou≈øand beames in the Eyes of the wicked, than one Mote in the eyes of his people. I vvill not punish (≈øaith God by his prophet) your daughters vvhen they Commit vvheredom
nor your, ≈øons vvhen they commit adultery. Hos. 4. 14. But you vvhom I have cho≈øen of all the earth, vvill I punish for all your Iniquity. Amos. 3. 1.

Thus Gods People in this life are as it were travelling from Egypt to Canaan. Tho our deadly Pharaoh, the Enemy of mankind, be over whelmed in the red ≈øea of Chri≈øts bloud, that hee cannot throw us downe, yet can hee ea≈øt Rubs in our way to ≈øtumble us. Some Amerites there will bee ≈øtil to Oppo≈øe us. The Canaanite is yet in the Land. The Flesh & the VVorld erect Golden Calves, ≈øugge≈øt Murmurings, & Lu≈øts, whereby wee provoke God to wrath, and force him by affliction to Cha≈øti≈øe and correct us into the right way.

Our Journey is as theirs numb. 21. 22. from Bamoth to Pi≈øgath‚ñ™ from the vale of humility & Death, to the plain hill of Happine≈ø≈øe & Everla≈øting life. So S. Ier√¥me applies the≈øe words in his Epi≈øtle ad Fabiolam.

And this (before wee proceed) may al≈øo afford a proffitable le≈øson for this Worlds Darling. Hath any a≈øcended this hill of Happine≈øs? Let him not ca≈øt his ≈øcornfull eye on his brother in the vale, but look rather towards Ieshimon the wilderne≈ø≈øe ouer again≈øt him, pitty them which are in it, and prai≈øe God for his better Man≈øion. Let him not forget that the Hill whereon hee ≈øtands is Pi≈øgah, which S. Ier√¥me Interprets dolatus, Smooth as if it were plained, very ≈ølippery, with an Ea≈øy de≈øcent, from which the lea≈øt ≈ølip may ca≈øt him downe thither, whence with great labour hee got up making him feele by experience that a Relap≈øe is a double Fall. But this by the way.

Wee may take one type more of the Sts. afflictions from the I≈øraelites. There was never any honey (ob≈øerves the ≈øame Father) in their Sacrifices; neither were the lights vvhich burnt in their Tabernacles of wax which is ≈øweet, but of Oyle sharp and bitter. As if they ought not enjoy the lea≈øt Embleme or Shaddovv of Plea≈øure. But however it was withthem, certaine itis to us Chri≈øtians, that our Ioy & feli city is not in the Creature here belovv, but in tho≈øe things vhich are above, vvhere Cbri≈øt ≈øitts on the right hand of God, vvhereon vvee ought to ≈øet our Affections, & vvhich are the only object of a right mortified and faithfull Chri≈øtians Search. Our Light as vvell as Life is in Heaven, Where our Conver≈øation‚ñ™ all≈øo ought to bee, and vvhere vve shall by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Allmighty and a truely ≈øanctified u≈øe of Gods Vi≈øitations (Which are a chri≈øtians be≈øt directions) in the Conclu≈øion Arrive to our Everla≈øting comfort, if vve are not vvanting to our ≈øelves. CHRIST JESUS the Soveraigne
of men and Angells and Captaine of our Salvation, if wee readily & heartily follow him & Tru≈øt in him, vvill bring us (and it is only Hee P≈ø. 66. v. 12.that can bring us) through fire & vvater into a vvealthy Place. Hee is our MOSES to lead us (for wee cannot go without him) from Bamoth to Pi≈øgah through many Tribulations, through all the difficulties of our lives and callings, into the Kingdom of Heaven, & Port of our Salvation. And this is the end of Gods vi≈øitations. The Fire of Adver≈øity is de≈øigned to refine us, to purge away our dro≈øse, & to fit us for tho≈øe pure man≈øions, whereinto no uncleane thing can enter.

Who will not then cry out with David, P≈ø. 119. v. 71. in his ≈øufferings, it is good for mee that I have been afflicted. It is as nece≈ø≈øary a Duty to Prai≈øe God after Affliction, as to pray unto him in it, though wee may not pray for it, tribulations, in them≈øelves, being evill & the effect of Di≈øobedience. Had not man grown Rebellious, God had not vi≈øited, but becau≈øe of the vvickedne≈øse of his doing, Gods ≈øends upon him Cur≈øing, vexation & Rebuke, Deut. 28. 20. But Chri≈øt the Rock of our Salvation (ble≈ø≈øed be his name) has turned the edge of this ≈øword. So that (non e≈øt malum jam Pati, ≈øed malum facere.) It is not evill now to ≈øuffer, but to do Evill.
The Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt (like the tree of God shewed Mo≈øes Exod. 15. 25.) hath altered the nature of our troubled waters, they are no longer bitter & un≈øavoury, but plea≈øant & Whole≈øome.

list.head: E≈øpetially in the≈øe Operations following‚ñ™
list.item: 1. They increa≈øe our knovvledge, both of our Creatour, & our Selves.
2. They increa≈øe our Devotion, making us all≈øo more conformable to Chri≈øt our Head, & ≈øo fitter ≈øubjects for his Pitty & Compa≈ø≈øion.

div.p:
Fir≈øt they increa≈øe our knovvledge, &c. While our Outward man is con≈øumed the inner man is renewed. For as long as the body triumphes in his ≈øtrength, the ≈øoules whole imployment is to furnish the corporeall organs with vigour & power for their more ba≈øe Exerci≈øes. But tho≈øe parts di≈øabled by Adver≈øity to receive tho≈øe Faculties, they returne to the ≈øoule, and united worke more ≈øtrongly in a weightier matter, even in a divine Contemplation. There is now no fewel for Lu≈øt, no shews for Pride, every ≈øen≈øe failes to bring in tho≈øe
delight≈øome ≈øpecies, which in the time of bodily health overloaded the fainting ≈øoule. This Pri≈øon therefore of the ≈øoule thus, once, broken, she becomes active in her bu≈øine≈øse, & runs the vvay of Gods Commandements. Whereas before she only heard of God (as Job ≈øpeakes) by the hearing of the Eare, The Vail of the Temple once rent by ≈øickne≈øs, or other adver≈øity, now her Eyes ≈øee him. The Eye of her under≈øtanding shee more clearely apprehends his Povver. The Eye of her Faith shee more confidently relyes on his mercy.

Secondly This knovvledge inflames her Devotion, and renders us fitter ≈øubjects for his pitty. Wee mo≈øt Earne≈øtly ≈øue for a Remedy of Danger from him whom wee be≈øt know cares mo≈øt for us. While wee are in our Jollity, ju≈øt like the Prodigall, in S. Lukes Go≈øpell, wee look no further than our ≈øelves. And that I am afraid hath been one of the ≈øins of this Nation, & of this Place. A litle cro≈øs may drive us to our Neighbour, but when wee are driven to eat Huskes with the ≈øwine, in our greate≈øt Extremity, then (humiliatio in humilitate) our minds are humbled with our Bodies; then, & not till then, Nece≈ø≈øity becomes a vertue; I vvill (becau≈øe I mu≈øt) go to the Father.

God deales with his Children, as a Nur≈øe with hers, ≈øuffers them to ≈øtagger now & then, that they may looke the better to their feet. There is a Hand behind, which the Child ≈øees not, that holds him up. Our Heavenly Father indeed plunges us (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeake) here into the depth of Sorrow, that wee may dive into the depth of our own Heart; and to make us more ≈øen≈øible, punishs us by degrees (as hee did Iacob) fir≈øt with the lo≈øs of Rachel, then of Io≈øeph, aftervvards with famine & feare of Benjamin. Even as Io≈øeph dealt with his brethren, but as Io≈øeph al≈øo, tho hee began in wrath, hee ends in Peace.

Mercy follows Judgement and nothing but impenitency doth make a ≈øeparation. If God at any time be long in punishing, it is to teach his people more ≈øen≈øibly the guilt of their ≈øin; that ≈øo, by the better knovvledge of their guilt, they may be driven the ≈øooner to repentance the ≈øeat of mercy. Both which methods of Allmighty Gods dealing vvith his ≈øervants have been often experienced by the People of this land.

Rough hevvn timber and unpolishd ≈øtones, are unfit for any Princely Building, therefore God ≈øavves us (as it were) in pieces by Adver≈øity, ≈ømoothes our inordinate affections, & hevvs dovvn our
Rebellious lu≈øts, before vvee can become a meet Temple of the Holy Gho≈øt.

God vvell knovvs vvee have lo≈øt that image & ≈øuper≈øcription vvhich hee ≈øtampt us in, and therefore melts us anevv, as the Prophet ≈øpeakes, Jer. 9. 7., and purifies us in the fire of Affliction, that vvee may bee made fit materialls, in that day in the vvhich hee maketh up his Jevvells, Mal. 3. 17.

In a Chri≈øtian life then, as in the Almond tree, vvee mu≈øt expect a hard shell, tho there be a ≈øvvee kernell. Hardne≈øs, all knovv by Experience, thus many times conteines ≈øvveetne≈øs, and ≈øundry other u≈øefull quallityes, as comfortable Health often follovves after an unplea≈øant Potion.

Let us approve our ≈øelves therefore the ≈øervants of God, in much Patience, as dying but behold vvee live, as cha≈øtned but not killed: as ≈øorrovvfull yet allvvay rejoycing. 2. Cor. 6. 9. 10. Our Sorrovv is but Qua≈øi tri≈øtitia, tran≈øitory (it ≈øeems) as there noted, by the Apostle, a dreame or shaddovv of ≈øorrovv. But the Ioy of a true Chri≈øtian is other vvi≈øe, there is Ce ‚Ä¢ tum gaudium, it is not ≈øaid as Ioyfull but allvvay rejoycing.

Hath then God taken avvay our Worldly vvealth from any of us? It is (vvee may conclude) becau≈øe it should not deprive us of Eternall Happine≈ø≈øe. Applica
‚Ä¢ ion. IF the Dayes of Adver≈øity & Affliction, Brethren, be ≈øuch a hopefull ≈øeeds-time, wee, in our pre≈øent Circum≈øtances, are like, if wee ≈øovv in pious Teares, to have a plentifull crop.

A ce≈øsation granted in order to treat‚ñ™ The SWORD is drawn in the Midst of the Nation: God grant it may not bee too ≈øoon sheathed in one anothers bowells; nor VVhet by the pre≈øent Ce≈ø≈øation.
In≈øomuch that what party ≈øoever gaine the victory, both mu≈øt certainly, ≈øome way or other, in the Conclu≈øion, bee Con≈øiderable Loo≈øers.
It is a ≈øad thing that ≈øubjects to the ≈øame Prince, should in Words many times profe≈øs, & pretend, the ≈øame thing; and yet all the while fight again≈øt one another to De≈øtruction.
One Party, among other matters, declares for the Prote≈øtant Religion in generall; another for the Church of England, as by Lavv E≈øtablisht.

This cannot bee other, with hone≈øt meaning, than the very ≈øame cau≈øe, for the Church of England is undoubtedly a Prote≈øtant Church, and the be≈øt Prote≈øtant Religion (notwith≈øtanding all a≈øper≈øions) is profe≈øsed in that Church; & yet, in all probability, here is, in the Nation, a Quarrel begun (God forgive the Authours) which is not like to bee determined without the Shedding of much Chri≈øtian Bloud.

Or el≈øe, againe, One Party declares for the King al≈øo, (as the Lords at York) as well as the Prote≈øtant Religion, together with the Liberties and Properties of the Subject; Another for the King, & Antient Lavves & Governement in the Church & State. This likewi≈øe, without mentall re≈øervation, is no other than the former, & yet both Parties, you ≈øee, enter into a di≈ømall bloudy War to decide the Controver≈øy.

Tis certaine, that our antient Lavves & Government (≈øo much depending on Monarchy) cannot be pre≈øerved, by the De≈øtruction of the Prince; and true Liberty & Property can never be ≈øecured by the De≈øtruct on of the Antient Governement; no more can the right Prote≈øtant Religion.
Come, BRETHREN, let us all be well-advi≈øed before wee imbrue our hands deeply in one anothers Bloud, ≈øuch like Pretences & Beginnings had, once, no better con≈øequence.

Behold, I ≈øay, two Parties of the Kings ≈øubjects making the ≈øame Prote≈øtation, and yet all the while fight with one another, ≈øo that one of them cannot bee ≈øincere. If two Per≈øons declare for the King, & yet fall to Blows, one of them (pretend what hee will) mu≈øt certainly be a Rebell in fighting again≈øt the King.
I would, in Charity, thinke that you all conclude Rebellion a mo≈øt odious thing; and that few will (I am ≈øure no good man would) dip them≈øelves, in ≈øo hainous a crime knowingly and willfully.

The danger is that many worthy & Hone≈øt Gentlemen, as heretofore (and now in our Pre≈øent Iuncture) may be in≈ønared, before they are aware, into this foule Offence, ≈øo farre, that they cannot tell how to gett back againe: or (if they do them≈øelves) cannot hinder ill men from proceeding on, & effecting their ends by vertue of the Reputation which they have given to an ill cau≈øe.

I will therefore cea≈øe to contend in this place, who is the be≈øt ≈øubject or verie≈øt Rebell. Whether I, that declare my ≈øelfe for the King, & the Prote≈øtant Religion; or hee, that declares him≈øelfe for the Prote≈øtant Religion, & the King, is the mo≈øt Loyal, & the be≈øt Prote≈øtant.
I have here openly & frequently enough di≈øcoverd my Principles concerning Subjection. I am, Brethren, of the ≈øame minde I ever was, & ≈øo re≈øolved, by Gods Grace, to live & dye.

In≈øtead of ≈øuch di≈øputes, I'le endeavour to paint, & ≈øett before your Eyes, this abominable ≈øin that neither party wil owne. And (without telling you any more who are Rebbells) I'le plainly shew you, what is Rebellion, and what, it is to be Rebellious.
In pro≈øecution whereof, I'le keep preci≈øely (as well as I am able) to the very Termes, & Wordes, of the Church of England, in her Printed Sermons or Homilies, Published by Royall authourity.

Rebellion then, you mu≈øt know, is there e≈øteemd by the Church of England, whereever it is found, either among Papi≈øts or Prote≈øtants (either on the 5 of Nov. or on the 30. of Jan.) the wor≈øt, as it was the fir≈øt, of ≈øins.

In the fir≈øt of her Homilies again≈øt Rebellion, it is ≈øtiled the Root of all vices, & the Mother of all Mi≈øcheifs: and in the ≈øecond part. the vvor≈øt of all vices, & the Greate≈øt of all Mi≈øcheifs, at the Breaking in
vvhereof all ≈øins, & Mi≈øeries, did flovv in, & over-vvhelme the vvorld: The Authour of that accur≈øed ≈øin of Di≈øobedience (vvhich brings in all other at its heeles) being no other than LUCIFER him≈øelfe, vvho of the Brighte≈øt & mo≈øt Glorious Angell, for this very ≈øin of Di≈øobedience, & Rebellion again≈øt his King, became the Blacke≈øt & foule≈øt Fiend, and from the Height of Heaven fell into the Bottome of Hell. As our Church expre≈øseth it in the afore ≈øaid Homily.

Rebellion, in another place ≈øpeedily after, is ≈øtiled the Foule≈øt of all ≈øins, being, as it vvere, the Source & Originall of all other, and in≈øeparable from the Highe≈øt Pride & Contempt of God. Hee that nameth Rebellion, ≈øaith our Church, nameth not a ≈øingle, or one onely ≈øin, as is Theft, Murder, Robbery, & ≈øuch like, but (to ≈øpeake in the old language of the Homily) the vvhole Puddle & Sinke of all ≈øins again≈øt God & man; again≈øt his Prince, his Country, his Countrymen, his Parents, his Children, his Kinsfolkes, his Freinds, & again≈øt all men univer≈øally. I thinke I need not produce any more quotations, or arguments, out of this Repo≈øitory of our Church, to convince you, that Rebellion is the mo≈øt abhorred ≈øin; and that it can never prove a ≈øoveraigne ≈øalve (whoever are the Authours or ≈øupporters of it) for the King, Church, or Kingdome.

But that I may have a ≈øufficient foundation, for a pathetick di≈øswa≈øion from this ≈øin; it will bee requi≈øite to informe you fully, in right Church-of-England-Loyalty. And it can bee no other, that is taken, word for word, out of the≈øe her own authorized Sermons, which will bee mo≈øt effectually done, by ≈øatisfying you, in a particular manner, what the Church of England e≈øteemes to be Rebellion.

Fir≈øt, to vvith≈øtand, or u≈øe any force or violence to, Lavvfull Soveraigns, the they be never ≈øo vvicked, and do never ≈øo much abu≈øe their Povver, is Rebellious. Secondly, wee are informed that not only open Rebellion, or dovvn right Re≈øi≈øtance of the Lords anointed‚ñ™ but any kind of In≈øurrection, or COMMOTION, or Murmuring (one of our moderne vertues) is condemned as an intollerable VVickedne≈ø≈øe, in a vvell governed Kingdome, p. 67, of the ≈øame Hom. N ‚Ä¢ .Where you ≈øee, by the way, how much this Ages, and that Ages, Prote≈øtants, differ in their Sentiments of Loyalty.

I ≈øhall ≈øay no more to rectify your Notions Concerning Loyalty & Rebellion, than that our mother the Church of England (now ≈øadly Wounded by her own Children) who is Exceeding aver≈øe to this Hellish crime, doth in the≈øe her orthodox & Pious Compo≈øers (the ≈øtandard of our Sermons & divinity) Condemne it as di≈øloyall & Rebellious, not only to depo≈øe, de≈øtroy, or oppo≈øe, the King but to put him in feare, to Terrify, or di≈øturb his ≈øacred Per≈øon or Mind; valuable (as the ≈øcripture tells us) above ten thou≈øand of his ≈øubjects.

Common vvealth‚ñ™ and probably by none more than our Neighbouring One, vvho Upholds her unnaturall Inva≈øion by tempting Subjects to ‚Ä¢ ight again≈øt their Lavvful Soveraigne.

BRETHREN I am not ≈øo old as to have forgot, nor ≈øo young but that I do Well Remember, the ≈øpetious & holy Pretences of 41 vvhich vvere made u≈øe of to Ruine both Church & State. THE ≈øame nece≈ø≈øity vvhich drove mee from my Home, at the very time vvhich my Soveraigne vvas forced to vvithdravv from his ovvne Palace, compells mee to ≈øend the≈øe, as vvell as my other, Papers, to the Pre≈øs, to shevv the manner, hovv I parted vvith my Freinds & Flocks in the Bishoprick of Durham, and that the la≈øt Di≈øcharge of my Archidiaconall Office in a Tyme of trouble, vvas ≈øuitable to my pa≈øt life & Acttings, during more than tvventy yeares, in a time of Peace.

Hovv imperfect & in≈øufficient ≈øoever both have been, I never vvanted, through Gods Grace, Re≈øolution all a long to Oppo≈øe the Subjects in croaching on the Prerogative of their King; as heartily as I have vvith-≈øtood the Dutch their Invading of the Land. It vvill be no great ground of Admiration then to all vvho throughly knovv mee, that, at ≈øuch a Iuncture, I did dare ≈øpeake plaine English, to fortify my Brethren again≈øt Temptations, and encourage them, as I have done, in their Duty to God & the King. And I Ble≈øse Gods mo≈øt holy name, that hee hath been plea≈øed to be≈øtovv on mee, for the ≈øupply of my manifold Defects, allvvayes Chri≈øtian Confidence, in the Pulpit, vvho have not injoyed much of it any vvhere el≈øe.

By vvhat God gave mee boldne≈øs, at that time, to speak in the ears of a large & Publick Auditory of Clergy & Layity (not rashly but vvith the mo≈øt mature con≈øideration that I utter'd any thing in my vvhole life) they might perceive I did not intend to ≈øtay at Durham, if my Soveraigne should bee Banish'd from his Kingdom. As by committing the ≈øame di≈øcour≈øe to the Pre≈øs, after more ≈øerious thoughts & greater deliberation, all men vvill bee ea≈øily Convinced, that till my Soveraigne be re≈øtored (vvhich I do heartily pray for) I have no thoughts to returne.

Tho I found it very ea≈øy, & intelligible, hovv to behave my ≈øelfe under a Roman Catholick Prince, in the di≈øcharge of all Duties, incumbent on mee, as a Right Church-of-England-Subject, or Chri≈øtian, yet mu≈øt acknovvledge that I am void of Logick & other Learning to ≈øupply mee vvith di≈øtinctions, and furniture, nece≈ø≈øary to live under an V≈øurper.

And therefore if the Reader di≈øcover the vvhole cour≈øe of my life, as vvell as my vvritings, de≈øtitute of Craft to transforme my ≈øelfe into any shape, and change vvith the Government, let him not be a≈øtonish'd; or accu≈øe mee over rigidly, for not doing that, for vvhich I am not ≈øo vvell, as others, quallified, either by nature, or education.

It hath been my fate to have ≈øuck'd in other Principles, & to have been trained up under better Tutours; nay, po≈øsibly, in my vvhole Make, to be ≈øo contrived, and compo≈øed, that it is not in the Povver of man to nevv-mould mee, into that ≈øort of Animal, vvhich can blovv Hot & Cold vvith the ≈øame Breath, and is able to ≈øave his ≈øtake, vvhat ever Card turnes up trump.

To the≈øe vvho shall condemne it in mee‚ñ™ as a deplorable piece of Madne≈øs, or folly
to talk or vvrite avvay ≈øuch a Con≈øiderable Revenue, as Providence & my Kind Patrons have be≈øtovved on mee, (vvhich I am like to do by ≈øetting my name‚ñ™ to vvhat I print) I mu≈øt declare that I am one of tho≈øe Fooles S. Paul ≈øpeakes of, vvho that I may bee vvi≈øe am vvilling, in the ≈øight of the vvorld, to become a Foole, valuing my Innocency, & Quiet of Con≈øcience, more than I do the be≈øt Deanery, or Bishoprick in Chri≈øtendom. And as nothing yet hath tempted mee, I thank God, to Compliment avvay my Religion, (tho I have been by ≈øome ≈øo reproached) upon Gods rai≈øing & ≈øetting over us a Prince of a different Communion. So no Con≈øideration vvhat≈øoever (I rely on Gods Grace) shall be able to prevaile vvith mee to pro≈øtitute it, by falling dovvne to adore the multitude, or any Image (tho it be of Gold) that shall be ≈øet up by the People.

Tho≈øe therefore that attack mee by arguments, or Threats, in letters, to ≈øeduce mee back, and dravv mee into a Compliance vvith the nevv Government, that I might ≈øet my hand to she rai≈øing up the Babell vvhich they are building in England, may ≈øave their labour & ink. For till they have confuted the Doctrine vvhich they have preached, as vvell as the ≈øound Divinity of their Mother, vvhich they have for≈øaken, they may cea≈øe from offerring mee other arguments to convince mee. And till they per≈øvvade mee to ≈øet a higher value upon my money, than I do on the Grace of God, & prize my temporall intre≈øt more than mine Integrity (vvhich no magick I have yet met vvith all hath been able to effect, ≈øo as to fill my pockets) they may al≈øo forbeare to affright mee vvith Deprivation.

I have long con≈øidered, & ≈øtudied the point of Allegiance, vvhich I ovve to my only Leige Lord & Soveraigne King Iames 2, and to no other, and am firmely vvithout doubt, or ≈øcrupule, ≈øatisfied that my Religion vvill not permitt mee to ≈øvveare fidelity to any be≈øides him.

That the greate≈øt part of my Brethren notvvith≈øtanding the faithfull & frequent endeavours I have u≈øed to e≈øtablish them in Conformity & Loyalty, should for≈øake Gods Vice-Gerent, to do Homage to the Peoples, is an unexpre≈øsible greife to my ≈øoule.

To prevent the Incurring ≈øuch guilt, and the lamentable ≈øcandall of ≈øuch Apo≈øtacy, I did in due time (as may appeare from the date of the en≈øuing Addre≈øs) expo≈øe my ≈øelfe to much cen≈øure, by delivering my mind, to an Auditory, vvhich ≈øeem'd ready to run them≈øelves (as they have done) into that Yoke & ≈øervitude; vvhich I (vvho had greater temptations than others) vvas re≈øolved to run out of the Kingdom, & from my preferment, rather than ≈øubmit to.

And to demon≈øtrate that I am (after great thought fullne≈øs & much prayer to God to direct mee) of the very ≈øame mind here in France on Nov. 15. 1689, that I vvas in England on the ≈øame day of the month 1688, as vvell as de≈øirous to expre≈øse my vvillingne≈øs, to do all that in mee lyes, to avvaken tho≈øe out of their ≈øin, vvhich I could not confirme in their Duty; I am as vvilling to commit to the Pre≈øse the di≈øcour≈øe I then made. Tho I vvell knovv, that I shall, in ≈øo doing, in ca≈øe the≈øe Papers get into England, (and con≈øidering mens pre≈øent Genius & Actings there) be expo≈øed to the danger of running (as it vvere) the Gandelop.Gantlet through the Nation.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: IF this or the former Piece have the good fortune to find the way back to Durham, and fall into the hands of tho≈øe Per≈øons that were pre≈øent when they were ≈øpoken, (for who≈øe ≈øake they were fir≈øt deliver'd and ≈øince Printed,) they may chance to take notice, in the peru≈øall, (if their memories do not faile them,) that the Authour is more ≈øparing than heretofore, or ever u≈øed to be, in his Commendation of the Con≈øtit√∫tion of the Church of England, and more particularly in the Prai≈øe of its well compiled Liturgy, which he was wont, upon all occa≈øions, very highly to extoll; In which ca≈øe, they are de≈øired to under≈øtand and con≈øider, that the≈øe Papers have been Printed in a R. Catholick Country, where they could not be permitted to pa≈øs the pre≈øs without the peru≈øal, & approbation of R. Catholicks; and that it was a great mark of favour, and an e≈øpetiall token of their pre≈øent forwardne≈øs to concurre with, and encourage Loyalty, to ≈øuffer Sermons and A ≈øpeech, ≈øpoken by a Divine of the Church of England, to be printed here at all, notwith≈øtanding the ca≈øtigations which have been made, by the retrenchment of ≈øundry expre≈ø≈øions, & omitting all Compari≈øons which did carry with them any Reflections. And therefore the afore≈øaid people have no ju≈øt cau≈øe given them to conceit, that the Authour hath, in any re≈øpect, Changed his ≈øentiments of the Religion of the Church of England, which he hath ever profe≈ø≈øed, & where in he de≈øires and re≈øolues, by gods Grace, to live and Dye.

If the aboue mentioned Auditors, (who di≈øcouer too apparently, that there is among them at home, what ever is in the Authour abroad, a lamentable Change) or any other ≈øort of Readers, of our own, or of any Forreigne Nation, fancy him guilty of too much sharpne≈øs of expre≈øsion, they are intreated to remember, or to be informed, that what ever he hath utterr'd, in a tyme of great Heat & Hurry, hath been ≈øpoken again≈øt ≈øuch as did invade his own Native County with unexpre≈øsible inju≈øtice & unnaturallne≈øs, (as well as many heightning aggravations for want gratitude) and that it was a ≈øpeciall Duty in every one of his Character, & his ≈øtation, at that time to expo≈øe as much as they were able, an inva≈øion which was beyond all precedent, & without paralell. In ≈øo much, that if a ≈øatyricall Invective (of which the Authour was never a great louer) be at any time allowable, in the writings of a Divine, it cannot be denied, ≈øurely, but that it may pa≈øse here, in this In≈øtance: e≈øpetially Con≈øidering that he did very ≈øea≈øonably shew ≈øuch his indignation, even before the Forces that Landed had rowled to ≈øo great a number, but that they might have been Oppo≈øed, nay ≈øuppre≈øsed, by any one County of England, which would have shewed it ≈øelfe, right valiant, faithful, and unanimous.
