div.head: A ‚Ä¢ peech made by the Archdeacon to the Clergy of the Archdeaconry of Durham in the Church of St. Mary le Bovv on the 15. of Nov. 1688. vvith a Repetition of ≈øome cheife Matters contained in former ≈øpeeches ≈øince his pre≈øent Maje≈øties Acce≈øsion to the Crovvn.

div.p: Introduction. It is a Cu≈øtome in the Univer≈øity of Oxford, once in the yeare, in the Univer≈øity-Church, to have a Repetition Sermon. This, as wellas other her Cu≈øtoms, I make no doubt, is ≈øupported with Sub≈øtantiall Rea≈øon. An Auditory of Schollars and Learned men, Doctors & Divines, have not, as she ≈øuppo≈øes, allwayes ≈øuch faithfull Memoryes, but that they need a monitor.
It is no affront therefore Brethren, to thinke that the Grave≈øt Clergy, at the mo≈øt Solemne Vi≈øitation, may bee men of the like Infirmities.

Were I not then Convinced by the language of your Actions (Whereby you Speak as plainly as by your tongues) that you have either forgotten many things of moment ≈øaid unto you, or have done
much wor≈øe, that is, in plaine termes, undervalued & rejected them; I your Unworthy Archdeacon, might have cau≈øe enough, once in my life, to imitate this laudable Univer≈øity-Patterne, in making you a Repetion-Speech, which, tho long, will go downe with you the better, at a time, when, as at pre≈øent, you have no Vi≈øitation-Sermon.

And here it will not be ami≈øse to mind you, that, Repetition-Taske there, in the Church at Oxford, is the mo≈øt difficult Imployment of the whole yeare. So that you will have Small rea≈øon to imagine that I do betake my ≈øelfe to the like cour≈øe, ≈øo much for mine ovvn ea≈øe, as for your Edification. And as I shall imitate my Mother the Univer≈øity, in one re≈øpect, ≈øo shall I in an other. Shee doth not exerci≈øe the Patience of her Auditory, ≈øo far, as to bring to their view the ≈øub≈øtance of many or any Sermons of the whole yeare, but of the foure la≈øt imediately preceding Low-Sunday: viz. the Sermons preached on Good-Friday & Ea≈øter-Day with tho≈øe on the two following Fea≈øtivalls. No more shall I di≈øturb you with Hearing the Heads of any of my pa≈øt Addre≈ø≈øes, ≈øaving the four la≈øt, I meane tho≈øe, which I have made ≈øince the Death of our Late Gratious Soveraign. Tho I might invite you to look farther back, being not con≈øcious to my ≈øelfe, (God be prai≈øed) that I did ever with zeale pre≈ø≈øe any thing upon you, but what was well worth your Hearing, and con≈øonant to the known Rules of the Church of England. So without any more ado (praying for Gods A≈ø≈øi≈øtance) I enter on my propo≈øed imployment.

div.head: REPETITION OF THE SVBSTANCE OF FORMER SPEECHES.
SPEECH I.
div.p: THE former of the≈øe four Di≈øcour≈øes I made you in the Church of S. Nicholas, the three la≈øt in this where in wee are at pre≈øent a≈ø≈øembled. I shall according to our Oxford-Method entertaine you with the Cheif & Mo≈øt important Points in the ≈øame order which I ≈øpoke them.

Fir≈øt in that (after a con≈øiderable ab≈øence & a great Change‚ñ™) I did
Judge it meet to bring to your vievv, The Greatne≈øse of our Affliction, & our greater ≈øins vvhich provoked God at that time, & in that manner to punish us vvith the lo≈øse of a Meek & mercifull Father of our Country.

A Prince of ≈øo conde≈øcending a Race, that hee was (like his never enough to be admired and good natured Father) more concerned for the Ea≈øe & Property of his ≈øubjects, than for the ≈øecurity of his own Per≈øon & Prerogatives; A Prince of ≈øuch Exemplary long≈øuffering, bearing with ≈øuch innumerable & intollerable Affronts of his Authority, that hee did evince to all the world, that it was ≈øcarce po≈øsible for a Stuart ever to be a Tyrant: A Prince, what ever might be his own per≈øonall Infirmities, that had not one of tho≈øe gro≈øse Flavves in a Monarch, which do border upon Inju≈øtice & Cruelty to his People; A Prince, that did ≈øo abound in Acts of Grace to a ≈øtubborn & ungratefull Generation, that an Exce≈øsive Clemency had like to have proved his own, as it did his Fathers Ruine: La≈øtly a Prince under whom (God forgive our unrea≈øonable complaints) wee might have been (if w ‚Ä¢ e were not) one of the Happie≈øt Nations in the World.

The next thing which I offer'd to your con≈øideration, was, The Gratious Goodne≈øs of the pre≈øent King, in not only continuing but Protecting our Religion: VVhereby hee did in an unexpected, Ble≈øsed, manner, defeat the bitter Calumnies of his Malitious Enimies, vvho for ≈øeaven yeares before had mo≈øt ≈øeditiously hammer'd into the Spirits of the vulgar mo≈øt Di≈ømall & Dreadfull Apprehen≈øions of a Popi≈øh ≈øucce≈øsour. Hee thereby proving all tho≈øe (God be thanked) fal≈øe Prophets, who had in≈øinuated into the Peoples minds (to the ≈øcaring them almo≈øt out of their ≈øen≈øes) that as ≈øoon as the Duke of Yorke came to the Crovvne, vvee should have Ma≈øse ≈øaid in all she Cathedralls in England. To vvhich Act of mercy in the King, it vvas but an un≈øuitable & un≈øea≈øonable Returne (I could not omit the notice) to grudge his Maje≈øty, and tho≈øe of his Per≈øvva≈øion, the Exerci≈øe of their ovvn Religion, vvith impunity from the ≈øeverity of the Lavves, vvhil≈øt God kept us under the Government of a Prince of the Roman Communion: Witne≈øse the Untimely heat of ≈øome turbulent Spirits, in the Hou≈øe of Commons, vvhich a≈øsembled on the 19 of may after his Coming to the Crovvne, who flung a bone among that Augu≈øt a≈øsembly, vvhich vvas like to have brokn all their Teeth: furiously pushing on the then pre≈øent, & immediate Revivall of the Penal
Lavves, vvithout any exception of the Roman Catholicks, vvho had undeniable pretences, con≈øidering their Loyalty and ≈øervices in the Great Rebellion, to ≈øome re≈øpite during the Reign of a Prince of their ovvn Religion. But the Major part of that Loyall Parliament vvi≈øely fore≈øavv, vvhereto ≈øuch a prepo≈øterous proceeding did tend, and like faithfull Patriots did readily oppo≈øe, & ≈øoon Quench the flame of that ill-timed Zeal; re≈øolving vvithout any more adoe (Would God none had ever changed their minds) firmely to rely on the vvord of their Gratious Prince, for the ≈øecurity of their Religion & Lavves; dutifully expre≈øsing their ju≈øt Indignation again≈øt tho≈øe rash, as vvell as horrid Rebels, vvho did at that time, in≈øolently make a de≈øperate attempt to overthrovv our Antient Monarchy: The Parliament Pa≈øsing a Bill of Attainder, in the fir≈øt place, again≈øt the Arch‚ñ™Rebell & Head of that Republican Crevv, vvho vvere Wafted hither from the Lovv-Countryes; and then after vvards a≈øsi≈øting their Soveraign vvith their Pur≈øes & Per≈øons to the utmo≈øt of their Povver, till (by the Ble≈øsing of God) hee had vvholly ≈øuppre≈øs't a Dreadfull Rebellion; vvhich, hovvever ≈ømall it might be, in the beginning, might have prov'd fatall to the vvhole Church, as vvell as Kingdom.

On vvhich Wicked & Bloody De≈øigne, vve may novv make the more ≈øevere Reflections (as things have fallen out) ≈øince that vile Rebellion, (after it vvas hatch'd in Hell) had been harbour'd in Holland, among our Neigbours, vvho make a bad complement to England, for rai≈øing them from a poor di≈øtre≈øsed ≈øtate, in the dayes of Queen Elizabeth, to ≈øo High and mighty a Republick, as to give chec to the mo≈øt potent Crovvned Heads, even to the greate≈øt of their Benefactors: and from di≈øputing in the dayes of Charles 2 for the Soveraignty of the ≈øeas (an act in≈øolent enough) to contend in the dayes of King Iames 2 for the Soveraignty of the Land, and to fight for the Imperiall Crovvn of this Kingdome, if not to vvear it on their heads (vvhich it vvould badly become) to trample it under their Feet; vvhich vvould be the undoubted I≈ø≈øue of a Flemmish zeale, mixt vvith Gunpovvder & Brandy, tho never ≈øomuch varnish'd over vvith Pretences of Liberty, & Religion.

Wee may learne the Favour of the Hollander, in the ≈øtories of Amboina & Bantam. From Dutch Acts of Mercy (tho ≈øome I do behold vvould not be convinced a fevv dayes ago, that, if the Dutch
should land, they intended us any harme) the Lord deliver mee, and all the Kings Obedient Subjects. And let tho≈øe vvho abound vvith ≈øo unaccountable & ab≈øurd a ≈øort of Charity, only feel, & experiment their Compa≈øsion. And novv from this ≈øea≈øonable, and pertinent digre≈øsion I am led to my third particular of that Vi≈øitation-Speech vvhich I am Epitomizing. To vvit.
The un≈øpeakable & unde≈øerved Mercy of Allmighty God, in the ble≈øsed ≈øuppre≈øsion of that Diabolick Rebellion vvhere vvith the Enimies of our King & Church vvel-com'd our Soveraign to the Crovvne.

A ≈øad vvelcome for a poor Weather-beaten Prince nevvly come into the Haven after a long & terrible Storme; lately banisht from Kingdome to Kingdome, and (vvhich hee had rea≈øon to thinke none of the lea≈øt penances vvhich Heaven had impo≈øed upon him) driven into Holland among the Ducth, vvho it is a Wonder did not u≈øe Violence to him, ≈øince they did immediately, upon his Coming to the Crovvne, countenance & ≈øupport tho≈øe Rebellious mi≈øereants‚ñ™ that ≈øought his Royall Life. And vvho≈øe good vvill & vvell-vvishes, to tho≈øe unfortunate Rebells (vvho landed in the vve≈øt) may novv Clearly be di≈øcover'd, by the preparations vvhich they have been making ever ≈øince the Victory, given by God to our Soveraign, at King-Sedgemoor. Which di≈øappointment, it is plaine, greived them, ≈øince they are, at this very in≈øtant, maintaining the ≈øame Quarrell; publishing a no le≈øse Wicked Manife≈øto, or Declaration; only vvith this difference, that the≈øe treacherous Enimies (vvhich in this juncture of Affaires have impudently invaded us) ≈øeem a little more angry, than tho≈øe traytors vvhich landed at lime, vvith the God of Heaven, for po≈øtponing their Stateholders pretences to the Crovvne, by the Ble≈øsed Birth of a hopefull Prince (vvhom God pre≈øerve) To vvhom the Barbarous Dutch (and ≈øome more barbarous among our ≈øelves) have been more cruell than Bloody Herod in killing the Children, by endeavouring to prove him illegitimate & disinheriting him (vvhich Providence & the Kings vvi≈øedome & Care ≈øeems to have put out of di≈øpute) thereby de≈øtroying the Hopes & felicity of three Kingdoms, in depriving them of ≈øo unvaluable a Ble≈øsing as an heir Male, to ≈øucceed to & ≈øupport the Monarchy‚ñ™ But, to returne, the Remarkable Ju≈øtice & Vengeance of God, in cutting of vvith great ≈øpeed tho≈øe Traytors, la≈øt ≈øpoken of vvhich they had fo≈øtered in their Bo≈øome, and
a≈øsi≈øted vvith ve≈øsells and armes, to land and begin a Rebellion in England and Scotland, together vvith the many ≈øignall Providences of Heaven, in fru≈øtrating all their Wicked de≈øignes, bringing to nought all their mi≈øcheivous attempts, and making that Rebellion, intended for the Ruine of Church & ≈øtate, a meanes (as rightly improv'd it might have been) the longer to uphold both; should Convince (I ≈øay) even the mo≈øt ≈øtupid Dutch Under≈øtanding of the heavy di≈øplea≈øure of God again≈øt ≈øuch hatefull Hypocri≈øy, as‚ñ™ the Colouring over ≈øecular, unju≈øt, nay trea≈øonable & bloody Machinations vvith the profe≈øsion of Piety: One of the Motto's vvhich they, at pre≈øent, beare in ≈øome of their Flags (as reported) being pro libertate & Religione for the Pre≈øervation of liberty and Religion. That our Neighbours the Dutch, of all others, are become thus zealous & devout, & concern'd for the liberties and Religion of England (as they vvould have us imagine) is ≈øome vvhat unintelligible. Bibit Flander editque ben√®, hath been by vvi≈øe men heretofore a≈øsigned for the Flemmins Character; and I never ≈øince heard of his Reformation. Such SAVIOURS OF OUR CHURCH (God ble≈øse her) vvould be as bad as the late SAVIOURS OF OUR NATION. If Heaven vvere incen≈øed again≈øt us in ≈øuch a degree, as to put us under a nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øuch mi≈øerable Comforters, and freinds to ≈øupport us, it vvould be hard to knovv vvhich to choo≈øe: A Saviour from Am≈øterdam or Sala-Manca. All I shall farther ≈øay, before I proceed to the next particular, is, that as I do, vvith all my ≈øoule, thank & ble≈øse Heaven for Saving the Nation from one of the≈øe Saviours, ≈øo I pray vvith mo≈øt fervent Zeale (in conjunction vvith all truly loyall ≈øubjects) that vvee may, in due time, be ≈øaved from the Other; Tru≈øting in God, nay re≈øting vvell a≈øsured, that vvee shall have a gratious Returne of our Prayers, if our ≈øins prevent not. And ≈øo I ingage in my la≈øt particular of my fir≈øt di≈øcour≈øe, namely.
Our indi≈øpen≈øable Obligation both to God & the King, to live ≈øuitably to ≈øuch unexpected Ble≈øsings of Heaven, & unmerited kindne≈øs‚ñ™ of an indulgent Prince.

The mercy of God (you were then told) had been Wonderfull beyond expre≈øsion to our Gratious Soveraign, in fir≈øt re≈øtoring him with his Royall Brothers, after innumerable difficulties attending the Great & Long Rebellion, aftervvards pre≈øerving him from the
danger of many Bloody Battells in defence of this nation, again≈øt tho≈øe very enraged Enimies, vvhich would (notwith≈øtanding vvee feele their Malice) make the vvorld beleive (and ≈øome I find are ea≈øy enough to beleive it) that they are our kinde, nay Religious Freinds: In the next place delivering him, from that never to be forgotten danger of the Deep, vvhen the GLOCESTER perish'd on the Lemon & Oare vvhere God many vvayes manife≈øted, that hee vvas a Prince vvhich Heaven took into it's ≈øpetiall & Extraordinary Protection: Then re≈øcuing him from a greater than any of the former danger,, even from the Madne≈øs of the People, from the fury of the Rabble, from the Rage of the incen≈ø'd Multitude, vvhich could not refrain from the highe≈øt of Affronts, ≈øtabbing in Effigie: Judging him unvvorthy of the re≈øpect due to a Kings Brother, tho a Turk or Pagan‚ñ™ not remembring him for a vvhile ≈øomuch as in their Prayers or Cups. Which ≈øpleen & Contempt of his ≈øacred per≈øon, increa≈øed to ≈øo high a Pitch (I then ob≈øerved) that many, of all degrees & Quallities (≈øetting them≈øelves again≈øt him) vvould bee ≈øatisfied vvith nothing le≈ø≈øe, than √† barbarous Exclu≈øion of him from the Imperiall Crovvne, vvhereto Allmighty God in ≈øpite of Men & Divells has brought him‚ñ™ vvith great Honour & to our Comfort: God, in vvho≈øe Governance are the Hearts of Kings, putting it into his Royall mind to di≈øpell the Fears & Jealou≈øies of his people, by the fir≈øt Act hee did in Councell, before hee had vviped the Tears from his Eyes for his beloved Brother; And aftervvards making him a Ble≈ø≈øed In≈øtrument of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing that fir≈øt (Dutch) Rebellion, vvhich I dare ≈øo to ≈øtile, ≈øince it vvas formed in Holland, the Comon Receptacle of Chri≈øtendom for Rebells & Traytors, and ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull a Forge for Trea≈øonable practices, that tvvo pro≈øcribed Mini≈øters (fitter to be Smiths than Divines) have there hammer'd out a ≈øecond more Divellish Con≈øpiracy. Such Goodne≈øs of God to our Royall Family, not leaving it de≈øtitute of a Prince of the right line, but ≈øettling upon the Throne ≈øo accomplish'd an one in all re≈øpects, that if hee had been of our Ovvn Religion, vvee should have thought our ≈øelves loaded vvith more Happine≈øs than vvee had been able to beare. This Mercy I≈øay, in rai≈øing a Gratious Princs (tho of a
different Faith) to be the Defender of ours, in crushing a Rebellion like a Cockatrice in the shell, which aimed more at the de≈øtruction of the Church than the Crowne, is ≈øo unparallell'd a Ble≈ø≈øing as de≈øervs Everla≈øting Prai≈øe, and an eternall obligation to conforme our lives to the Will & Commands of our Earthly as vvell as our Heavenly King. Which vvee cannot do (give mee leave on ≈øuch occa≈øions allvvaies to be your monitor) till nee do approve our ≈øelves truly Genuine, obedient ≈øons of the Church, as vvell as Dutifull Complying ≈øubjects (I knovv no difference in tho≈øe tvvo Epithets of Obedient & Complying, tho the la≈øt hath been turn'd into a reproach) in all things vvhich are not Contrary to the Clear Word of God. But I vvill, for a vvhile, ≈øtop ≈øuch inlargements, as vvell as ≈øet a Period to my promi≈øed repetition of the mo≈øt important Heads of the fir≈øt of my four Vi≈øitation-Di≈øcour≈øes, propounded to be brought to your Vievv. Which I have inlarged by unavoidable digre≈ø≈øions, Occa≈øion'd by the pre≈øent vvicked and treacherous Inva≈øion. I shall ≈øooner pa≈øse through the Heads of the ≈øecond remaining ones, without ≈øuch additionary Reflections, and bring all, I tru≈øt, with in the compa≈ø≈øe of le≈ø≈øe time, than what is allowed for both Sermon and ≈øpeech at a Vi≈øitation.

div.head: SPEECH. II.
div.p: THe cheife points of my ≈øecond di≈øcour≈øe which I shall lay before you, are, as followeth.

Fir≈øt our pre≈øent Kings further Expre≈øsion of his Gratious Good ne≈øse and Conde≈øcen≈øion in the ≈øea≈øonable & happy Renevvall of tho≈øe vvhole≈øome & Ecexllent Directions to Preachers, vvhich vvere publish'd by his martyr'd Father, and ≈øet forth, a ≈øecond time, by his Royall Brother K. Charles the 2. in the yeare 1662. Injoining ≈øuch a Regulation of the Pulpit (out of which have i≈øsued our former and our pre≈øent Flames ready to devour us) ≈øuch Exact conformity to our Rubrick, ≈øuch frequent Publication (in all parochiall Churchs) of the Doctine and di≈øcipline of our Church, ≈øuch re≈øpect to the Lords day, and cheifly ≈øuch a Training up of the
Youth, & Catechi≈øing them in the Book of Common Prayer, as was the mo≈øt likely meanes, (valuable infinitely beyond all our Di≈øputes & Harangues from Either Pulpit or Pre≈ø≈øe) to pre≈øerve, the Church of England. And which wee Clergy had greedily embraced (God forgive us that fatall Error of Neglecting them) had wee not laboured under ≈øome kind of Infatuation.

Secondly, that bitter Invectives a gain≈øt the Pope of Rome (vvhil≈øt vvee live under a Prince of the Roman Communion) omitting the more ≈øure vvayes to pre≈øerve our Religion, allovved by this, and the la≈øt Good King, as vvell as biting declamations again≈øt the non-Conformi≈øts in the late Kings Reign, by tho≈øe vvho vvere them≈øelves but ≈øemi-Conformi≈øts, vvere an Effect of very blameable & dangerous Zeale, and had mightily increa≈øed our ≈øchi≈øme and vveakened our Church: It being not Satyricall Harangues, in the dayes of K. Ch. the 2. (as I then told you, & ≈øtill thinke ≈øea≈øonable to repeat) again≈øt the Fanatiks, which did without a Compleat Conformity to our Rules, ≈øignalize a Right Church-of-England-Divine. No more than furious Railing, or hot Di≈øputing again≈øt the Pope, or Church of Rome, in the pre≈øent Reign of K. James. 2. Can give an undeniable Demon≈øtration, that wee are Good Subjects, or firme Prote≈øtants. Neither of which can evidence us (God knowes) to be the legitimate J≈øsue of that Church vvhich vvas never guilty of Boi≈øterous, and unmannerly Zeale, but allvvayes profe≈øt and taught, not only a deep veneration for Maje≈øty, but Chri≈øt like Meekne≈ø≈øe and Moderation: Exhorting her Children to Honour the King, as vvel as Feare God, and to be ju≈øt to all, even to the vvor≈øt & mo≈øt implacable of her Enimies or Impugners.

Thirdly I shevv'd the indi≈øpen≈øable Duty of every one of us, to betake our ≈øelves to a more indubitable Cour≈øe, than the former, of maintaining our Religion by tho≈øe lavvfull meanes (and much more effectuall than the other) vvbich vvere allovved by the King as vvell as our Church to ≈øave our ≈øoules, that is, by living according to our Doctrine, rather than by Talking for it, & mo≈øt particularly by ≈øtudying and practi≈øing our Common Prayer Book; not Spending our Povvder & Ball in needle≈ø≈øe and impertinent pickarings, but laying up a ≈øtore of Ammunition, & furnishing our ≈øelves by the fore≈øaid pre≈øcribed Cour≈øes vvith Courage & Magnanimity again≈øt a Day of Battell.

The fourth & la≈øt Point recommended to your Con≈øidetation then, at that Juncture of Affaires (and is ≈øtill vvorthy to be thought of) vvas, vvhether that Subtile & Malicious ≈øpirit (vvho often transforms him≈øelfe into an Angell of Light, effecting his vvor≈øt De≈øigns under the di≈øgui≈øe of Holine≈øs) dot not v≈øe pretended Zeale again≈øt, as vvell as Fears & Iealou≈øies of Popery‚ñ™ as the mo≈øt likely and ≈øucce≈øse full ≈øtrategem to bring it in. I vvas then and am ≈øtill of that Opinion. And, for Gods ≈øake, do not despi≈øe this hone≈øt Caution.

div.head: SPEECH III.
div.p: THUS having di≈øpatch'd the things mo≈øt vvorthy of notice, contained in my ≈øecond di≈øcour≈øe as vvell as the fir≈øt, I shall attempt to bring to your vievv the mo≈øt ≈øignificant Heads of the third.

And here Waving ≈øundry Arguments then laid before you, to ≈øubmit to your Soveraigns Will and Plea≈øure, even, in the mo≈øt uninntelligible of all his Acts of Mercy, J meane, that Including the Fanaticks in his Declaration for Liberty of Con≈øcience. Exce≈øs of Favour & liberty granted to his ovvn, as vvell as our Churches enimies; as all≈øo pa≈øsing over the Characters of a right Loyall, and unalterably Obedient Subject to the King, and of a true, right bred ≈øon of our Church, together vvith that Man of Indifference, that pretends to be both, & yet is neither, vvhich I did then very largely ≈øet before you, as vvell as the motives to become the tvvo fir≈øt, that is, Good ≈øubjects, & Good Chri≈øtians; Waving, I ≈øay, the≈øe and ≈øome other matters, that time vvill not permitt mee to reflect on, I shall only exerci≈øe your ears at pre≈øent, vvith hearing four Cautions, or Directions, vhich I recommended to my Auditory, in the Conclu≈øion of that Charge to the Clergy, to vvit.

Fir≈øt, that, that ju≈øt, rea≈øonable, and moderate Ground of Feare, vvhich every VVi≈øe man ought to have, in our Circum≈øtances, might drive u ‚Ä¢ more clo≈øe home to the Throne of Grace, and Gods Altar and make us all acquaint our ≈øelves, better than ever heretofore, vvith our Hearts & Con≈øciences; taking ≈øuch care of the internall exerci≈øe
of Grace & vertue in the ≈øoule (vvherein cheifly is the Kingdom of God) & living in ≈øuch Obedience both to God & the King, as become the be≈øt Chri≈øtians & Subjects lea≈øt that our Mercifull God & Gratious Prince (on vvho≈øe Grace & f ‚Ä¢ avour our Felicity did then greatly depend) should for our pa≈øt, or future provocations be incen≈øed, and deprive us of the Liberty vvee injoyed, in the Exerci≈øe of our E≈øtablish'd Religion.

The ≈øecond Direction vvas to take care of the young Generation‚ñ™ and never to ≈øuffer any Youth to depart from the parishes, or families, or approach to the LORDS SVPPER, vvith out due Instruction, and a ≈øufficient degree of knovvledge and Devotion. (Hic labor hoc opus e≈øt‚ñ™) And if you vvere for any vvorks of ≈øupererogation, I prayed you to practi≈øe them in this cour≈øe, permitted to us (Ble≈ø≈øed be GOD & his VICE-GERENT) nay required of us by his Maje≈øtie in his pious DIRECTIONS to PREACHERS, as before mention'd; vvhereto vvee all ought (as I then Caution'd you) to keep clo≈øe, and the neglect vvhereof hath much contributed, vvithout di≈øpute, to our pre≈øent mi≈øery.

A Third Advice vvas to bevvare lea≈øt a Vulgar notion of Loyalty‚ñ™ & obedience to your Superiours in Church & State‚ñ™ might debauch y ur Vnder≈øtanding, and make you more ≈øu≈øpitious of your Governours Inchroaement on the Peoples priviledges, than of the Peoples Sacrilegious Inva≈øion on the Prerogative of GODS VICE GERENT. When vvee cannot di≈øcover in England (e≈øpetially in the family of the Stuarts) any One In≈øtance of the f ‚Ä¢ ir≈øt; but may every day find out lamentable Examples of the latter; And that you vvould remember & be a≈ø≈øured, that the Religion of your Soveraign did not one jot either le≈ø≈øen, or ≈øomuch as re≈øtrain, the Authority or Povver, vvhich hee received from GOD and not from his ≈øubjects; as al≈øo be more afraid of, and aver≈øe to Popular Tiranny, than the Abu≈øes of Government in a Monarch; vvho may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have, as vvell as his ≈øubjects, knovledge, Grace & Con≈øcience of Duty to his Soveraign in Heaven, to re≈øtrain him from an extravagant exerci≈øe of his Povver; and to informe him, that his Account to God, vvill be more heavy than that of his ≈øubjects in ca≈øe of Male-Admini≈øtration.

My fourth & la≈øt Coun≈øell vvas to be ju≈øt to all men, both to the Romani≈øt and Di≈øsenter. That your Aver≈øion to the Doctrine of
any Party (tho never ≈øo Contrary to your ovvn) should not, in any manner, exceed your Love & Concerne for the Religion you profe≈øs'd‚ñ™ and tempt you to encourage barefaced Violations of Truth & Ju≈øtice, vvhen it is in the Concerne of an Enimy, or Adver≈øary to your Opinions.

div.head: SPEECH IV.
div.p: THERE remaines novv only the la≈øt of my foure Addre≈ø≈øes to be brought to your vievv (before I ingage in my Conclu≈øive Reflections) vvhich con≈øi≈øted of three heads, & vvherein I ≈øpoke by vvay of Caution (I de≈øire you to remember) rather than accu≈øation.

Three things I did advi≈øe, and be≈øeech you in a particular manner, to take heed and be vvare of; (And ≈øo I shall in the name of God, as long as I have the Honour to be your Archdeacon) Things vvhich really portend much vvotfe than mo≈øt grounds u≈øually a≈øsigned in this ≈øu≈øpitious Age for Fears & Jealou≈øies.
The fir≈øt vvas, A prepo≈øterous zeale again≈øt our Adver≈øaries, accompained too often vvith a ≈øpirit of Contradiction.

And vvhich di≈øtills more aver≈øion into us, and di≈øgu≈øt again≈øt our Adver≈øaries Per≈øon, than Principles; Inclining us to Oppo≈øe, & confute him right, or vvrong, Concluding all to bee evill in our Antagoni≈øts (tho oftentimes very Commendable) and fondly Over-vveening all to be Good (tho ≈øome times very unchri≈øtian) in our ≈øelves, and others of our Per≈øvva≈øion. A mallady, vvhich hath been long the Di≈øea≈øe of our Nation. Our Poor Church, ever ≈øince the Puritan Faction began, labouring under the ≈øame, in ≈øuch degree, that a Spirit of Contradiction hath been Commonly made the Cheife ≈øtandard & mea≈øure of many mens Religion & Devotion, and the di≈øtance they kept from the vvays & Sentiments of their Oppo≈øers, look'd on as an infallible Mark of the vertue of their ovvn Per≈øons, and Truth of their profe≈øsion. Which Opinion and Judgement of matters (tho never ≈øo popular) are very fal≈øe Weights & Mea≈øures. By rea≈øon, at this rate, the vvor≈øt men mu≈øt allvvayes be the greate≈øt ≈øaints, ≈øince in them dvvdls
mo≈øt Hatred & animo≈øity, & bitter Aver≈øion to all that is not their ovvne: Horrid vices, are u≈øually the Parents of this ≈øpirit, vvhich I ≈øet before you, & de≈øire you may all Loathe.

The ≈øecond thing I caution'd you again≈øt, vvas, mens Declining in Loyalty & Love to their Prince, on account of his Religion; Which doth not in any manner di≈ø≈øolve or abate the Bonds of Duty & Re≈øpect in the ≈øubject. But on the Contrary Favours received from ≈øuch a Prince (≈øuch as vve have received as I shevved then more largely) oblige ≈øubjects to ≈øome more officious re≈øpects than are to be paid to a kind Prince of our ovvn Per≈øvva≈øion.

The third thing vvhereof I told you that vvee ought to bevvare, vvas, Ingratitude to both God & the King, for tho≈øe ≈øpetiall Mercies and Acts of Grace, vvhich vvee receive from one and the Other, even during our Murmurrings and Complaints. Ingratitude to the King, I then informed you vvas in≈øeparable from Ingratitude to God, A Good & Gratious Prince being a Choice Gift of Heaven, & one of the greate≈øt ble≈ø≈øings vvhich a Nation can enjoy. And hee that vvill not from the Bottome of his Heart returne his thanks & Prai≈øe for ≈øo ine≈øtimable a Jevvel, is a moun≈øter of Unthankfullne≈øs to the Common Governour of the Univer≈øe, the Greate≈øt of Benefactors.

div.head: Reflections on ≈øome of the points repeated, & the circum≈øtances of the Nation, at the time of the delivery of this ≈øpeech in reference to the Inva≈øion.
div.p:
AND novv, Reverend Brethren, I have, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of God finish'd the Task vvhich I propo≈ø'd; (to vvit,) of Refreshing your memory vvith the recitall of the mo≈øt important matters vvhich I recommended to your Con≈øideration, in all my Publick Vi≈øitation-di≈øcour≈øes ≈øince the Death of the King. And I am ≈øure that there is not one of them, but is very vvorthy of your thoughts, e≈øpetially in ≈øuch a Juncture of Affaires, as obliges every man in authotrity, to u≈øe the mo≈øt povverfull Arguments,
vvhich ever vvere u≈øed, to rai≈øe men to a high pitch of Loyalty, & affection to the Crovvn of England.

I might very properly, & profitably farther reflect and inlarge on any of the pa≈øt particulars, in the≈øe our Circum≈øtances. But I shall confine my ≈øelfe cheifly to the tvvo la≈øt, vvhereon I did mo≈øt breifly Touch, as mo≈øt pertinent for our Meditation, in this day of Rebuke & Trouble.

All men are novv, I ≈øuppo≈øe, ≈øufficiently Convinced (vvho do not labour under ≈øome de≈øperate Delu≈øion) of the Mi≈øcheivous de≈øigne of our Treacherous neighbours; vvhom vvee shall bee ashamed nay a fraid any more, ≈øurely, to ≈øtile Freinds, or to cry they vvill do us no harme, (language wherevvith my eares have been long grated) it being novv by Proclamation Trea≈øon ≈øo to do.

If the Prince of Oranges landing vvith 14000 Traytours (or ≈øupporters & Abettors of Trea≈øon) at his heels (the particulars of vvho≈øe forces you have in the la≈øt Gazette, together vvith ≈øome Heads of his Rebellious Declaration) vvill not convince men, that there vvas ≈øuch a thing as an Evill intended Inva≈øion, and that there can be no good de≈øigne to our Liberty, nor Religion, by ≈øo manife≈øt a Violation of both, I shall give them up for lo≈øt, for men void of common ≈øence, and not ≈øpend any more paines or breath upon them.

As soon as his Maje≈øty told us, in his late Proclamation, that hee had undoubted advice of a Wicked De≈øigne to invade, & Conquer his Kingdom, I did (& thought it my duty ≈øo to do) firmely beleive it, and have ever ≈øince accordingly, in my poor ≈øphere, not only offer'd my mo≈øt fervent Prayers to Heaven, for the protection of our Gratious King, Church & Kingdom, but have done all that in mee lay, both by vvord & example, to exhort every per≈øon Committed to my Charge, to defend our King and Country.

And if all per≈øons had been as forvvard, as my poor unvvorthy ≈øelfe, to give credit to, & rely on the Word of our Prince (vvhich I have not yet doubted) the Nation had been, it is manife≈øt, in a better ≈øtate of Preparation. Tho God be prai≈øed, his Maje≈øtyes vigilance hath been ≈øuch, that (if his Officers continue faithfull) the Kingdom is in no bad po≈øture to receive, & requite
the malice of our Enimies: triumphing, at la≈øt, as gloriously over the≈øe inveterate Foes as hee did three yeares ago, over the la≈øt rebellious villains, vvhich landed in the ≈øame Country.

Thirty thou≈øand vvel-di≈øciplin'd & loyall ≈øubjects, under the banner of ≈øo valiant a Prince, as ours, are able undoubtedly, by the ble≈ø≈øing of God (de≈øpaire not) to encounter any Prince in the vvorld, attended on, but vvith 14000 Rebbells. By vvhich appellation I do no inju≈øtice, ≈øince in the Ca≈øe of Rebellion & Trea≈øon, as in that of murder, all companions are adjudged to be acce≈ø≈øaries, and ju≈øtly are to under go their triall, as vvel as the principall Actors.

The Goodne≈øse of our own Cau≈øe, & the Badne≈øs of our Enimie's, is as cleare as the ≈øun, & put beyond all mann'er of doubt, or ≈øu≈øpition. Neither of which can be brought into Que≈øtion by any per≈øon, but ≈øuch an one, as having ≈øuck'd in ≈øedition with his milk, is Antimonarchicall (whiles hee pretends to be Antipapi≈øticall) in his nature, and ≈øo much more zealous for the Name of Prote≈øtant (the wor≈øt thing in it) than for the Religion of Prote≈øtants, as to become a Well-willer to Turks again≈øt Chri≈øtindom, wishing ≈øucce≈øs to Infidells, becau≈øe Cerent Tecli, Bearing the name of a Prote≈øtant (a Rebell and an Apo≈øt ate, or as bad) is one of their number.

Wee mu≈øt not think ≈øo bla≈øphemously of the Deity, that the God of Heaven (a God of Purity & Truth) can have more favour to ≈øuch a Rebellious Rout, than to a Loyall Army fighting under the Royall ≈øtandard of their lavvfull Prince in defence of an antient Monarchy, & mo≈øt excellent Government.

No, no wee mu≈øt not imagine, that God (who is of purer eyes than to behold any iniquity vvith approbation) can have regard to ≈øuch a Gathering together of the frovvard and In≈øurrection of VVicked Doers (as holy David heartily Prayes again≈øt in the 64. P≈øalme) vvho have vvhet their tongue like a ≈øvvord, and shoot out their Arrovvs even bitter vvords. Where Davids Character of the Wicked (you vvil ea≈øily perceive, if you vvill take, the pains to peru≈øe the whole P≈øalme) exactly agr√©es with our Invaders. Both the wickedne≈øs & ≈øecrecy of their Undertaking having been ≈øuch as hee de≈øcribes. But as his Character & Complaint in the former part of the p≈øalme doth well agree with tho≈øe of our Enimies; ≈øo, I tru≈øt in God,
and heartily pray, that the latter & prophetick part, may be verified of them likewi≈øe. v. 7. 8. 9. But God shall ≈øuddenly shoot at them vvith a ≈øvvift arrovv, that they shall be vvounded, yea their ovvn tongues shall make them fall; in≈øomuch that vvho ≈øo ≈øeeth them, shall laugh them to ≈øcorne‚ñ™ And all men that ≈øee it shall ≈øay, this hath God done; for they shall perceive it is his vvorke.

Many con≈øiderations, together with Gods Providence, in bringing this and other pertinent p≈øalms to the Churche's u≈øe, ≈øince certain intelligence of the Enimyes landing, do (for my particular) incourage mee to put my Tru≈øt in God, that hee will not give us up, (I am ≈øure hee will not unle≈øse our ≈øins ri≈øe to a higher Pitch than theirs) as a Prey to the≈øe our Malitious Enimies.

If all orders of men among≈øt us, vvho have transgre≈øs'd his righteous Lavvs, and render'd (to u≈øe the words of our pre≈øcribed prayers) both his Mercies & Iudgements ineffectuall to our amendment, do but unfeignedly confe≈ø≈øe to God, & Heartily repent for ≈øuch their Provocations, turning avvay from their wickdne≈øse (for vvhich it is not yet too late) Hee‚ñ™ vvill be plea≈ø'd to turne avvay from his vvrath, vvhich novv hangs over our heads, & doth greivously threaten us.

But let us all re≈øt a≈ø≈øured, that vvee of England can never be throughly reconcil'd to Almighty God (and ≈øomuch I dare in his name to a≈ø≈øure you) vvithout repenting of our Ingratitude (of the late Odious unparallell'd Ingratitude) to our Soveraign, as vvell as him≈øelfe. Which brings mee home to the Topicks, that are of all other, at this time, mo≈øt pertinent for our Con≈øideration. Which Ingratitude, I ≈øay your Ingratitude to God & the King; vvhich among other ≈øins, & innumerable impieties, (many of vvhich I feare cry for veageance) doth dare Heaven, not only to cha≈øti≈øe us it ≈øelfe, but to make us to be rebuked of our neighbours, and a By-vvord among the Heathens, ≈øuffering us to be laught to ≈øcorne, & had in deri≈øion of tho≈øe that are round about us: The lea≈øt vvhich the be≈øt of us, at this Cri≈ø ‚Ä¢ s, may ju≈øtly dread for our late (as vvell as former) vvretched requitalls, that vvee have made for the Mercy & Bounty of our Father in Heaven & his Deputy on Earth. I shall not omitt the repetition there of (tho late carriages & tran≈øactions per≈øuade mee, it vvill be unplea≈øant to ≈øome
of your ears) ≈øince out of Gods Rods vvee may at this very in≈øtant pluck a fe≈øcue to teach us our le≈ø≈øon.

Wee have impudently defied HEAVEN, by all imaginable Provocations, but by nothing more (I am not afraid, nor ashamed, yet to harp upon my old ≈øtring) than by our contempt of it, in making bold vvith it's VICE-GERENT. Tho God hath ble≈øs'd us English, vvith a more happy Race of Kings than any Nation in the World can boa≈øt of; yet it is notorious, that no people under the ≈øun, have transgre≈øs'd more egregiously by murmuring & Complaints, or that hath Copied out vvith more exactne≈øs the unthankfullne≈øse, Infidelity, & Di≈øtru≈øt of the Impenitent & hardhearted. Ievves, Both in reference to God him≈øelfe in Heaven, and their Conductors, MOSES & AARON, here on Earth.

If God in his vvrath had ≈øent us a vvicked Heathnish Per≈øecutour, a Nero, a Caligula, or Diocle≈øian, to Reigne over us‚ñ™ vvee mu≈øt vvith Confu≈øion have confe≈øs'd, that it had been much le≈øse than vvee de≈øerv'd; And yet vvee (the mo≈øt incorrigible people, I thinke, under Heaven) are ≈øo ≈øqueamish, that vvee cannot dige≈øt a Chri≈øtian Monarch, Gratious & mercifull even to Wonder: A Prince, vvho hath demon≈øtrated him≈øelfe, beyond all gain≈øaying, to be a true ≈øon of K. Charles the Martyr, vvho vvas A King (I am per≈øvvaded) of the greate≈øt clemency that ever vvas upon the face of the Earth; cannot dige≈øt, I say, a Soveraign endovved vvith all the≈øe Graces (and a multitude of other Kingly Qualyties relating to War & Government) merely becau≈øe hee is not of our opinion, in point of Religion; tho hee gives us no other di≈øturbance in the exerci≈øe of ours, than to de≈øire liberty, for him≈øelfe & party to enjoy their ovvn.

Since vvee have thus Ungodlily Brovv-beaten Strugled vvith, and in a manner Di≈øclaimed, if not rejected, ≈øuch a Chri≈øtian Prince, God in his Ju≈øtice threatens to give us up a Prey to our Enimies, & the vvor≈øt Ma≈øters upon the face of the Earth.

Our abhorr'd Ingratitude to his Royall Brother & ≈øelfe (vvithout putting in to the ≈øcales our other innumerable ≈øins & impieties) may give us ju≈øt ground to feare, that our incen≈ø'd God may de≈øigne to teach us ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and ≈øubjection by ≈øo ≈øevere a Method, as to make us (vvho have been yet one of the free≈øt and mo≈øt happy Nations of Europe) TRUCKLE to an Up≈øtart-Commonvvealth,
to an Antimonarchicall Generation, vho by their continuall shelt'ring, encouraging, and a≈ø≈øi≈øting of Traytors, proclame their Emnity to the very name of King; and that they vvould not leave (if they could have their vvill) one Crovvn'd Head in Chri≈øtendom,

But let us not be di≈øcouraged, or de≈øpond over much. Our condition (Ble≈øsed be God) is far from de≈øperate. England cannot be de≈øtroyed, unle≈ø≈øe it de≈øtroy it ≈øelfe. If vvee vvill, in this our day, but for≈øake our ≈øins, and ≈øtoop fir≈øt to the God of Heaven, and aftervvards to his Anointed ≈øervant, our Indulgent Soveraign, as far as hee hath for this la≈øt month pa≈øt conde≈øcended to the reque≈øts of his People; flinging the vvor≈øt of Traytours, our ≈øins out of our Bo≈øomes, and I do not doubt, but that vvee shall ≈øoon drive the Dutch victoriously out of the Land.

div.head: TO CONCLUDE.
div.p:
IT May perchance, Brethren, ≈øeem a little out of the road to employ in this my ≈øole Charge to the Cergy (as I have done) the whole time alloted both for Sermon, & the other ordinary Application. But I pray con≈øider that, I ≈øpeake to you in avery extraordinary Time, vvhich requires every one of us (Publick Per≈øons) to do if hee can, ≈øomething extraordinary in the di≈øcharge of his Duty, And be≈øides, tis a time of danger and vvar, vvhich may be attended on, if God in his mercy doth not prevent, vvith Blood & Confu≈øion. So that I cannot a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelfe (t'vvould be a ≈øin not to feare vvhen God threatens) that I may live to ≈øpeak to you in this Place any more (Anceps fortuna belli) tho I declare I have not ≈øuch dreadfull Apprehen≈øions, as ≈øome may have, of this unnaturall War, but ≈øupport my ≈øelfe vvith a good mea≈øure of Confidence, that God vvill give the King ≈øpeedily the necks of his Enimies, ≈øince hee hath by his late Gratious Conde≈øcen≈øions, and a≈ø≈øurances regained (I am vvilling to hope) the Hearts of his Freinds. Which de≈øireable i≈ø≈øue nothing can vvithold Heaven from be≈øtovving upon us, but Impenitency‚ñ™
& more particularly, the vvant of Humility to Confe≈ø≈øe the Errours vvhich vvee, the Leaders of our flocks, have been guilty of, & to ovvne the fal≈øe ≈øteps vvee have made, to the Mi≈øguiding of our People.

I do, as vvell as the King, next under God, rely on the brave antient valour of the English Nation: English men fighting vvith ≈øvvords, vvhile their Enimies put their Tru≈øt, cheifly, in Lyes, & Libells.

When our Royall, & Pui≈ø≈øant Soveraign appears in the head of his Troops‚ñ™ His Example, ≈øure, mu≈øt needs animate and create Valour in the mo≈øt di≈øpirited Covvard. And had I not indi≈øpen≈øably devoted my ≈øelfe, to ≈øerve my King, by ≈øerving our Church (and obliged my ≈øelfe to pray rather than fight for his Grovvn) I vvould be the fir≈øt man that should run to the Royal Standard, and plea≈øe my ≈øelf to thinke, that in defence of my King & Country, I should have the Honour of ≈øome of my Ance≈øtors, to fall in the Feild, or be buried in th√© Deep.

Let not my Earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe (Brethren) make you Conceit, that I ≈øu≈øpect your Loyalty & Allegiance, vvhich I hope, & de≈øire, you vvill all ≈øpeedily manife≈øt by a loyall Addre≈ø≈øe to his Maje≈øty, to shevv your Abhorrence ofthe Inju≈øtice and Unnaturallne≈øs of the Inva≈øion, and that you vvill ever, in remembrance of your Oathes, ≈øtand by him & ≈øerve himto the Uttermo≈øt, vvith your Lives & Fortunes.

It is the indi≈øpen≈øable Duty of a faithfull Vi≈øitor to quicken his Clergy, in ≈øuch an Exigent. And vvith Integrity of Heart I novv do it; that I may give you true Mea≈øures, vvhereby you may ≈øet right your People.

I do acknovvledge my ≈øelfe a very feeble (tho, I hope, hone≈øt) ≈øupporter of the Church, & Crovvn of England. But hovvever, I have not ≈øo bad an Opinion of my ≈øelfe God be prai≈øed, as to be ashamed (here among you) either of my Life, or Doctrine.

And to evince that I am not, I have this day repeated, the ≈øub≈øtance or Cheif Heads, of vvhat I have l'ayd before you, during the la≈øt foure yeares of my Office: vvhich, none can deny hath been a time of great temptation & triall.

div.head: I COMMEND YOV TO GODS BLESSING and Direction.
div.p: I'LE ≈øay but one vvord more (and God knovves vvhether it may not be the la≈øt I may ever ≈øay in this place) and it shall be this.
CONTEND AND FIGHT, AS WELL AS PRAY AS HEARTILY AS YOU PLEASE AGAINST OUR INSOLENT NEIGHBOURS, THE DUTCH, BUT CEASE TO DISPUTE WITH YOUR PRINCE.

THE DEANE OF DURHAMS REASONS FOR HIS WITHDRAWING INTO FRANCE, IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE PRINCE OF ORANGES INVASION, And Driving the King, by the Svvord, out of the Kingdome of England. IN CERTAINE LETTERS. A LETTER TO HIS BROTHER THE EARLE OF BATHE.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT TO THE READER.
div.p: THE Reader is de≈øired to under≈øtand, that when the Authour fir≈øt ≈øet pen to Paper, ≈øoon after his Landing in France, in the Month of March la≈øt pa≈øt, that hee did not de≈øigne to print this and the en≈øuing Letters, or the foregoing Di≈øcour≈øes; His intentions, at that tyme, being only in a few lines to di≈øcharge the Obligations which hee did in Civility, rather than Religion, owe to his freinds & Relations (≈øpirituall & naturall‚ñ™ in England, after ≈øo ≈øudden a ≈øeparation & mighty Revolution, by informing them in an ordinary way of writing: ffir≈øt of what pa≈ø≈øed in reference to him≈øelfe & Cures Eccle≈øia≈øticall, during the di≈øturbances occa≈øioned by the Prince of Orange; ≈øecondly that hee did continue (by Gods Grace) to bee the very ≈øame Per≈øon, that they did di≈øcerne him to bee at Parting, & which hee had ever profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe, even an Unalterable firme ≈øon of the Church of England as fir≈øt e≈øtabli≈øh'd as well as a right loyall ≈øubject to his ≈øoveraigne: re≈øolv'd never to Owne any new fabrick built on the ruines of the Old, more than ≈øubmit to a new ≈øouveraign fet up by ≈øubjects in the room of Gods Lawfull Vice-Gerent.

But the changeablene≈ø≈øe of Times and variety of Publick occurrences, which did render it difficult for per≈øons in his circum≈øtances, to fix po≈øitively in any determination, cau≈øed him on ≈øecond thoughts, to Undertake the inlargement of the ≈øaid Letters, for the ≈øatisfaction of his owne con≈øcience, rather than their curio≈øity‚ñ™ & likewi≈øe to publish to the World the Account of him≈øelfe & Actings which hee ≈øends to his Brother, & Bishop, & together with the whole≈øome Advice hee gave, at parting, to the members of Durham Cathedrale, & Clergy of his Juri≈ødiction. To the end that no per≈øon what≈øo ever under his authority might be ignorant of his Behaviour & Stedfa≈øtne≈ø≈øe,
in a tyme of great Apo≈øtacy, but be throughly informed & well a≈ø≈øured (the better to keep them from Falling) that hee did, to the very la≈øt Up≈øhot, practice the Doctrine which hee ever Taught; and was not ashamed, by his la≈øt ≈øervices for the Publick at Withdrawing, & by his fir≈øt imployment of his Pen after Landing, to proclame him≈øelfe one of tho≈øe indi≈øputably loyall Subjects, that could obey actively in all commands not ≈øinfull, Whatever his king bee, either by his Practice-in Point of Moralls, or by his Profe≈ø≈øion in regard of his Religion; nay‚ñ™one who was more ambitious to ≈øuffer with his afflected Prince abroad, than to keep his Preferments at home (tho in their kind ≈øome of the be≈øt in England) with a Blemi≈øh of being acce≈ø≈øary to the Rebellion, as his con≈øcience a≈ø≈øured him hee should have been, if hee had (after his manner of Preaching and Practice) but ≈øtayed at Durham, & ≈øate ≈øtill without oppo≈øing tho≈øe who were (hee conceived) labouring, by dethroning his ≈øouveraigne, to Unhinge the Antient Government both in Church & ≈øtate; or el≈øe held his tongue, & ≈øtopd his Pen, after hee was got, by √† happy Providence, out of the reach of the Kings Enimies; to gaine the liberty whereof it was one cheif part of his de≈øigne in leaving the Nation.

Which liberty, & opportunity hee thought him≈øelfe in all good con≈øcience the more readily & heartily obliged to embrace, ≈øince hee was debarred the Pulpit, & deprived of the ordinary Publick exerci≈øe of his Mini≈øtry; being not contented to preach by his example only, but according to the Rule of the Apo≈øtle S. Paul, out of ≈øea≈øon, as vvell as in ≈øea≈øon, by Letters, Advice, and Exhortations, at all Times, on all Places, on all fit occa≈øions, & to all Per≈øons (to whom his Duty bound him to Apply him≈øelfe) as far, and as well, as hee was able: His zeale by √† kinde of Antiperi≈øta≈øis (the defection reaching his own, till this time, ever loyall family) being increa≈øed as well as his re≈øolution.

But how ≈øo many of ≈øuch Antient, Noble, Hou≈øes, and till this late Epidemicall infection in a mo≈øt exemplary manner faithfull to the Crown, ≈øhould be tainted in the lea≈øtwi≈øe, with the horrid ≈øin of Rebellion, hee cannot devine, nor give any rea≈øon for the ≈øame, unle≈ø≈øe the Air of England did begin to grow as contagious as the Plague of Athens, which bred more di≈øea≈øes in mens Soules than in their Bodies, corrupting (as it is Storied) their very moralls.

Yet, what ever intoxicating ‚Ä¢ virtue may have been in the cli me, under the Planet that reigned in 88. that all should bee true‚ñ™ which i ‚Ä¢ reported of ≈øome of his ovvne Kinred, hee begs pardon if hee prove a very Infidell: It being not in the Povver of all the Logi ‚Ä¢ ians in the vvorld to Convince him, that it is po≈ø≈øible for one de≈øcended from his Dear Loyall Father Sr BEVIL GRANVILLE to dye a Rebell, more than it is probable, that the lately Landed English rebells should long prosper, or ≈øub≈øi≈øt, in Ireland, vvhere no venemons Bea≈øt can live.

The≈øe Con≈øiderations, together vvith the difficulty of ≈øending large Packetts, by the Po≈øt into another Kingdom, the danger of mi≈øcarriage at a Juncture vvhen fevv letters Went Without Openning; the Seriously and vvell vveighing the vote of the (Pretended) Hou≈øe of Commons to forbid all intercour≈øe vvith France after the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt; and more Especially the frequent Reflection on his Bodily Infirmities (fearing hee might never bee in the like condition of ≈øtrength & under≈øtanding to Unburthen his Con≈øcience, if hee ≈ølipped ≈øo faire all Occa≈øion) did cau≈øe him to make as much ha≈øt as hee could to commit his thoughts thus to vvriting, and to Communicate them by this ≈øure method of Printing his Letters, vvhich vvere not compleated till the end of October la≈øt. Wherein if nether the Reader, nor Per≈øons to vvhom hee vvrites (more than in the di≈øcour≈øes preceding) finde any Excellency of ≈øtile or matter, of Moderne Policy, or modish Learning, they may yet meet vvith vvhat the Authour is more proud of, and in this pre≈øent Age & Juncture very Extraordinary, as vvell as more valuable; That is to ≈øay, Hone≈øty & Courage enough to be faithfull to his King la≈øt yeare in ≈øpight of the mobile, & this yeare in ≈øpight of the U≈øurpation.

div.head: TO THE EARLE OF BATHE.
div.p:
THAT I never ≈øomuch as once pre≈øented my Duty to your LP. ≈øince I Left London, nor gave you any account of my ≈øelfe during the Months of Oct. & Nov. la≈øt pa≈øs'd, I need not, I conceive, make any Apology. All Cerimonious re≈øpects being then svvallovved up by the Great Concerns & Tran≈øactions of the yeare 88, that Annu ‚Ä¢ Mirabilis vvhich vvholy imployed the Head & Hearts of all men. And ≈øince that time, my Roling Po≈øture, Change of mea≈øures, & Re≈øolutions occa≈øioned by the uncertainty & Change of Affaires & Per≈øons at the Helme, together vvith the cro≈øse Accidents, vvhich I have by Land & ≈øea met vvith all (through vvhich God hath of his mercy vvell carryd mee) vvould not permit mee to ≈øalute you vvith that formality as became mee, vvherefore I have hitherto continued ≈øilent; But being novv mor ‚Ä¢ fix'd and Ea≈øy, and got vvhere I have been aiming Ever ≈øince I left my ≈øtation (on the 11. of Dec.) I cannot ≈øo farre forget my ≈øelfe as longer to deferre the pre≈øentation of my humble Duty & Service, & give you ≈øome Account of my behaviour and motions la≈øt Winter, together vvith my pre≈øent State & Condition, both as to Body & Mind. I have retained that honour & Duty for you that
I have given le≈øse credit than any other to vvhat I have met vvith concerning you, either in vvritten, or Printed Nevves, (vvherein. I have met vvith many things vvhich have troubled mee) and I hope you vvill bee plea≈øed to have the Goodne≈øs, to afford ≈ømall regard to any Reports or di≈øcour≈øes concerning mee vvhich may have „Äà‚óä„Äâ to your Eares Contrary to the Tenour of vvhat I vvrite.

A bout the End of ≈øept. la≈øt, on the fir≈øt Intelligence of the Dutch Inva≈øion, I retired to my Cures in the Country. Fir≈øt to ≈øedgefeild & then to Ea≈øington, u≈øing my utmo≈øt zeale & di≈øcretion, in my private di≈øcour≈øes, as vvell as publick Sermons, to e≈øtablish my people (in so ≈øad a Day of temptation when ≈øome ≈øtars of the fir≈øt magnitude fell from Heaven) in the E≈ø≈øentiall Duties of ≈øubjection & Allegiance to their Soveraign, shevving that ≈øubjects vvere upon noe Con≈øideration what≈øoever, nether of Religion, Liberty, nor life, to Re≈øi≈øt, or De≈øert, their Lavvfull Soveraigne, tho hee vvere no better than ≈øuch an One as S. Paul lived under, vvhen hee vvrit the Epi≈øtle to the Rom. not only a Heathen, but a Cruell Per≈øecutour, A Nero, A Caligula, or A Diocle≈øian; And that Subjects to a Chri≈øtian Prince, and to a Prince ≈øoe Mercifull & Gratious as ours, by con≈øequence vvould bee infinitely more Guilty, if they should Rebell again≈øt, or Re≈øi≈øt him, merely becau≈øe hee profe≈øs'ed a Different Religion.

After I had endeavoured thus to approve my ≈øelfe a faithfull shepherd in taking Care of my Country Flocks, I repaired to my Deanery at Durham, vvith the hone≈øt De≈øigne of demon≈øtrating my fidelity to my Soveraigne, & my Mother the Ch ‚Ä¢ of England being per≈øvvaded that their Intte≈øts could never bee ≈øeparated. Wherefore I ≈øummon'd my Brethren the Prebendaries together into Our Chapter-Hou≈øe; vvhere I propounded to them, the A≈ø≈øi≈øting of the King in ≈øo ≈øad an Exigent vvith their Pur≈øes, as vvell as their Prayers, vvith vvhich motion all pre≈øent complied, giving readily their Con≈øent vvith their voices, as all ab≈øent (≈øaving one) did by their letters: vvhich occa≈øion'd an Act of Chapter to the Effect follovving, tovvit, that the Deane should advance an hundred pound & Every Prebend fifty for his Maje≈øties Service tovvards the rai≈øing of Hor≈øe & Men, if occa≈øion should require, & to bee di≈øpo≈øed of, to the afore≈øaid Ends & Purpo≈øes, in ≈øuch manner as our Bp. should appoint.

And this I did, not thinking it any very con≈øiderable Service to the King to give him 700 (to vvhich ≈øumme it vvould amount) but that this Act of ours might bee an Occa≈øion of ≈øetting the vvheele a going (and at that time t'vvas not too late) through the Kingdom. Conceiving it no ≈øin (in ≈øuch an Extraordinary Juncture) to lead the van in Point of Loyalty to my Prince; ≈øince the Dioce≈øse & Archdeaconry of Durham in Particular (none can deny) had been all along during the Time of Bishop Con≈øins & ever ≈øince a notable Example to the vvhole Nation of Conformity to the Lavves, & dutyfull regard to his Maje≈øties Honour and Intre≈øt.

In the next place Remembring that I bore another Eccle≈øia≈øtick Office & Dignity in the Church of Durham about the beginning of Nov., I ≈øummond all the Clergy of my Archdeaconry together, (vvho met on the 15.) labouring in the Ab≈øence of my Superiour, the Bp. (vvho vvas gone up to London) to give them right mea≈øures in point of Church of England Loyalty & Religion; laying before them the Indi≈øpen≈øable Nece≈ø≈øity of their per≈øonall A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of their Soveraign, as far as any vvere Obliged, and Exerting their zeale to ≈øecure their Flocks that they might not be ≈øeduced from their Allegiance, by the Canting Sophi≈øtry, & Di≈øtinctions of the Age.

And tho the zeale I there Evidenced in my Vi≈øitaction Speech, hath had ≈øince as formely small effect (as is too vi≈øible by the Clergyes generall Compliance vvith their nevv Gevernours & Government, & renouncing their old) yet it vvill ≈øerve at all times to proclame, that their Archdeacon did on that Occa≈øion (as hee had done before) faithfully deliver his ≈øoule.

Fourthly Beleiving it might bee ≈øome Service to his Maje≈øtie, for both Clergy & Layity to shevv their ABHORRENCE of that unnaturall Inva≈øion vvhich vvas then ffeared, I moved fir≈øt my Brethren of the Chapter, & aftervvards my Brethren of the Bench, to Joyne vvith mee in an Addre≈ø≈øe of that Nature to his Maje≈øtie, but the fir≈øt Refu≈øing, and the la≈øt (all but tvvo) vvaving the ≈øame, I thought my ≈øelfe (the mo≈øt publick per≈øon in the Bishops Ab≈øence) obliged to give A demon≈øtraction of my ovvne Loyalty vvhich I vvas not afraid to do, (tho the Prince of Orange vvas at that tyme advanced as far as Salisbury) and accordingly on Nov. 27. ≈øent to his Maje≈øtie by the Po≈øt an A≈ø≈øurance thereof in an
