Whereof wee have now a late, & perhaps more Notable In≈øtance than ever was in the World: An Attempt ≈øo Abhorred & Unnaturall: A I act every wayes ≈øo unju≈øtifiable; & an Impiety ≈øo Daring, that it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily, in the Conclu≈øion, pull down Heavy wrath, if not Speedy Vengeance, both on the Contriver & the Acce≈ø≈øary; Inviter & the Invited, or on their Po≈øterity. If an extaordinary deep Humiliation before God, & a ≈øincere Repentance, ≈øome what an≈øwerable to the Greatne≈ø≈ø of the Provocation, do not in due ≈øea≈øon appea≈øe his Indignation.

Of which Heinous Guilt it concerns every one, who hath been unfortunately dipt therein (as every Complier with, as well as Promoter of, the new Government in England certainly is) with greate≈øt ≈øpeed, & care to purge him≈øelfe. And I do hope & Pray that all tho≈øe, to whom I do pre≈øume here in this paper to Addre≈ø≈ø my ≈øelfe, will take the≈øe things into timely & deep Con≈øideration: washing off tho≈øe Staines of Disloyalty, that may have involved any in the
Guilt of an Unparalled U≈øurpation, wihch I am afraid expo≈øes poor England to God Almightyes Impending Judgements more than all the former ≈øins of out ≈øelves or Fore-Fathers.

That I have, for my own particular, practi≈øed the very ≈øame Loyalty & hone≈øt zeale in reference to the Service of my Soveraigne (tho A Roman Catholick,) that I did to his Royall Brother; And have not, that I can di≈øcover upon the mo≈øt diligent ≈øearch, willfully & knowingly, made one Fal≈øe Step towards the late Irregular & Inju≈øtifiable Method of Pre≈øervation of our Religion & Lawes, by the Ungodly Practi≈øes & meanes of INVASION & USURPATION (which hath in good truth layen both a Ga≈øping) is a Felicity which doth not only wonderfully ≈øupport, but ≈øometimes almo≈øt transport mee, amid≈øt my pre≈øent Exerci≈øes of Patience. And will make mee rellish the wor≈øt Air, or U≈øage, that I can meet with abroad, where there are no Fogs, nor Fumes, rai≈øed by Rebellion, better than the be≈øt Air or Proferment in England, or any other Country where there Are. And here I should beg pardon, for this pre≈øent Trouble & Conclude, having been I feare too tedious, but that I ≈øtand obliged, lea≈øt I preach in vaine, to answer one Objection, which it is ea≈øy to fore-see will be made again≈øt my Doctrine, and may carry more Appearance of Rea≈øon therewith than any Other.
To wit.

Chri≈øts Example pretended for ≈øubmi≈øsion to the Prevailing Povver; ≈øince his acknovvledging Allegiance to bee due to Tiberius Cae≈øar; vvho≈øe Predece≈ø≈øors had ≈øo lately changed the Government of Rome by the Senate, did by that Act of his give liberty to vs‚ñ™ lavvfully to yeild our Allegiance to any vnju≈øt prevailing Povver, vvhat ever it bee.

This difficulty being ≈øolved by the Forementioned learncd Doctor of our owne Church & Nation, of undeniable Authority & an Eminent Confe≈ø≈øour in the Great Rebellion, I'le give the Answer in his owne very words without the lea≈øt variation. Which is ≈øo ≈øub≈øtantiall an one, that it is ≈øea≈øonable at this in≈øtant to be expo≈øed to view. And if there were no other De≈øigne in my writing would ju≈øtify the Publication of this letter.

In short his words are the≈øe. The ≈øtate of the Government of Rome, at that time when Chri≈øt Je≈øus lived‚ñ™ mu≈øt bee con≈øidered di≈øtinctly what it was. It is true indeed that Julius Cae≈øar had (not many yeares before) wre≈øted the Power out of the Senates hands, and Changed the Government violently: but before this time of Tiberius,
whereof wee ≈øpeake, the bui≈øne≈ø≈øe was ≈øo accorded betwen the Senate & the Emperours, that the Emperour now Reigned unque≈øtionably without any Competition of the Senate: In him the Power was quietly ≈øeated, the money ≈øuper≈øcribed with his Image, and Edicts ≈øent out in his name, and hee looked on by all (with out any Rivall) as inferiour to God only. In which ca≈øe of his acknowledged Power, Chri≈øt being borne in his Dominious, thinkes not fit to make a Que≈øtion of his Right, where there was none made by the Romans, or to di≈øpute Cae≈øars Title (However acquired by violence at fir≈øt) when they from whom it was taken did acquie≈øce, & di≈øputed it not. Which Ca≈øe how different it is from other forcible U≈øurpations (where the legall Soveraigne doth ≈øtill Claime his Right to his Kingdomes, and to the Allegiance of his Subjects, no way acquitting them from their Oathes, or laying down his Preten≈øion, tho hee be for the pre≈øent Ouerpowred) is ea≈øily di≈øcernible to any who have the Courage & Fidelity to con≈øider it, & is not by his own Intre≈øts bribed, or frighted from the performance of his Chri≈øtian Duty. It being withall mo≈øt certaine, that it belongs not to the conveniences or advantages of ≈øubjects to determine, or prevaile any thing in the Bui≈øne≈ø≈øe of Princes Rights.

This, one of the mo≈øt formidable Objections & Arguments for ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to an unlawfull prevailing Power, being thus effectually an≈øwered, I shall not thinke it paine-worthy, in a letter, to multiply other of le≈ø≈øe difficulty, which by con≈øequence may more ea≈øily be blowne away.

And indeed I ≈øuppo≈øe it needle≈ø≈øe, at this Time of Day, to fall to ≈øtrong rea≈øonings to evince the un≈øincerity of the Preten≈øions of the Contrivers, & Promoters, of this late unhappy Change of Government in Church & State; they them≈øelves having de≈øtroyed all the Plau≈øibility of their own Profe≈ø≈øions & Declarations.
Fir≈øt. The Prince of Orange di≈øowned that hee came to Conquer, or meddle with the Crowne, and yet mo≈øt willingly accepted thereof at the very fir≈øt offer of the People.

Secondly. The Exerci≈øe of the Kings Prerogative in di≈øpen≈øing with ≈øome Lawes, on Extraordinary Emergencyes, was thought a Burden Intollerable; But it hath been no Crime ≈øince in the Subject to di≈øpen≈øe with all; They having got (as they thinke) what they have long Contended for, the Supremacy in their own hands.
Thirdly. The Introducing of Arbitrary Power was the Dread of mo≈øt men, & now they are contented to enjoy nothing el≈øe.

Fourthly. It was Judged unpardonable Tyranny in our Soveraigne‚ñ™ to touch the meane≈øt of his ≈øubjects in Point of Property; but it is a laudable vertue in the Subject, to u≈øurp upon, nay di≈øpo≈øe of the Crowne.

Fiftly. The English were Overwhelmed with Jealou≈øies of introducing Popery & promoting the Intre≈øt of France. And all the while have gone the direct way to bring the wor≈øt of their Feares on them≈øelves, by Driving the King & Prince out of the Kingdome.
Sixtly. In a word. Sundry other Things, which were deemed nn≈øufferable in a lawfull Prince of Gods Ordaining, are now Practi≈øed without di≈øgu≈øt by an U≈øurper, & King of the Peoples making.

Hee that is not yet perfectly Convinced of the Hypocri≈øy of the≈øe Pretences & Procedings (which I hope the mo≈øt Eminent of our Clergy & Nobility by this time are) ≈øeemes to have neither Eyes to ≈øee, Eares to heare, nor Heart nor Head to con≈øider & Under≈øtand.

I shall conclude with A Memorable Saying of our Royall Martyr King Charles the 1. on his Ob≈øervation of a like ≈øpirit of Delu≈øion which in his dayes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the generality of the People of the ≈øame Kingdomes, in Dethroning, nay Murthering, their Lawfull King, & one of the Be≈øt of Princes, at his owne doores.
"Soe ea≈øy is that Leger de main which ≈øerves to delude the Vulgar.

That the Almighty & Wi≈øe God, who in his ju≈øt di≈øplea≈øure for our ≈øins & ingratitude to Him≈øelfe & his Vicegerent, hath for the pre≈øent made the Chutch & Monarchy of England A Notable Monument of his Wrath, would bring all High & Low, who have contributed to ≈øoe Heinous a Guilt, in his due tyme, to ≈øuch a ≈øight & ≈øen≈øe of their Crimes, that they may give to the world an undeniable Demon≈øtration of the Truth of their Repentance, labouring with all their Might to redre≈ø≈øe the Scandalls they have given, by an unparalelled Apo≈øtacy from the Principles of our Church, & an abhorred Defection, in point of Loyalty; is the hearty & humble Prayer of

closer.signed: Your Lordships mo≈øt humble Servant & Affectionate Brother, DENIS GRANVILLE

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
div.p: THat the Printing of this letter with the following Addre≈øs & Queres, may not appear to your ≈øelfe, as I fore-≈øee they will to all Zealous Contrivers & Supporters of the U≈øutpation in England, an act of not only deplorable Folly, but downe right Frenzy, I humbly Crave your permi≈ø≈øion to in≈øert a few lines by way of Po≈øt≈øcript.

I am not ignorant, but that this attempt may render me ab≈øolutely incap√†ble of all the favour you have shew'd me, ≈øince my Flight into France, in your voluntary kind interpo≈øition to ≈øecure my Revenu; & that it mu≈øt al≈øo expo≈øe me for a ≈øubject of Common Talk & Cen≈øure thoughout the Nation. But ≈øince an un blemis'd Loyalty is infinitely mote valuable than the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of this world, & that, I was per≈øvaded that the Cour≈øe‚ñ™ which I did, by Gods grace, Steer, was the mo≈øt effectual way to ≈øecure that, the very Reputation whereof I e≈øteem far beyond the Rents I had at Durham, Ea≈øington, & Sedgefeild; nay moreover ≈øince that my pa≈øt Life, & la≈øt Deportment in England, had not been all of a piece, if I had not done as I did; You will not, I tru≈øt, condemn my Cariage, however contrary to the Maxims & Temper of the Reigning Generation, as unworthy of your Hou≈øe & Family.

What I have done, I have perform'd, thanks be to the Almighty, in the Integrity of my Heart & Innocency of my hands, & the ≈øence & Con≈øideration here of (the I≈ø≈øue of things exery day more & more convincing me that I was in the Right) doth afford un≈øpeakable Comfort to my ≈øoule.

My Feeding of ≈øome Friends, in my voyage from Scotland hither, with Expectation of an Inter-view in Kent, & talk of a Pa≈øsport (the fit≈øt of which I did not intend, & the la≈øt, if I could get away without it, I did not de≈øire) is a crime I do a≈øsure my ≈øelfe of Gods pardon for, & of tho≈øe friends likewi≈øe whom I deluded & di≈øapointed, when God shall be pleas'd to ≈øend us a happy meeting.

As for that more unpardonable ≈øin where with ≈øome do reproach me, & whereof I cannot ≈øo well clear my ≈øelfe before the World (but is the only one, thanks be to God, that the World can accu≈øe me of) I me ‚Ä¢ n my Ignorance & Imbecility to fill my Coffers & Pockets ≈øo ful as ≈øome more
frugall & crafty than my ≈øelfe have done in le≈øs time, with a ≈ømaller E≈øtate or Revenu, I am like to do a ≈øad Pennance for it here abroad in a Forreigne Kingdome. And the Friends & Relations I leave at home, will not, I hope, add affliction to affliction (if they will not help me with their Pur≈øes) by loading me with their Cen≈øures; e≈øpecially con≈øidering two la≈øt Acts of mine to demon≈øtrate the ≈øincerity of my Repentance for it: Fir≈øt that I did voluntarily diminish my Revenu very con≈øiderably, by Rent-Charges to ≈øatisfy my own ju≈øt Debts; Secondly that I look'd on my long Neglect to practize Frugality as ≈øo great a ≈øin, that I did as voluntarily put my ≈øelfe into a kind of white sheet to atone fot the ≈øame, by confe≈ø≈øing it to God & the world, in a ≈ømall Peice I printed in the year 85.

This is my Comfort, that no per≈øon in England is like to loo≈øe by me, unle≈øs by his own proper Choice, & if one man doth ≈øo, he mu≈øt thank him≈øelfe rather than blame me. If I ≈øuffer Deprivation to his lo≈øs, he mu≈øt quarrell with God & the King, who≈øe Commands have unavoidably oblig'd me to hold fa≈øt my Religion & Loyalty. And if the Sacrificing of both, or either of them, was in my Judgement too dear a purchace of my Revenu for my ≈øelfe, no one could rea≈øonably expect that I should undergo it for an other.

Hoping that the≈øe few Hints may give ≈øome ≈øatisfaction to all, but the Malitious Authors of our pre≈øent Mi≈øery, I shall not enlarge this Po≈øt≈øcript farther, than to acknowledge with all thankfullne≈øs the kindne≈øs which you have shew'd me in procuring A Di≈øpen≈øation for mee (notwith≈øtanding I have contradicted your Example) which I e≈øteem thegreater Obligation, at tho≈øe friends hands who were in≈øtrumentall therein, ≈øince they did it without my Privity or Motion.

BY the Publication of the following ADDRESS & QUERES it may appear, tha the Author is not affraid (notwith≈øtanding the Obloquy he did a while undergo, in the yeat 88, for his dutifull compliance with the King) to owne tho≈øe notions of Loyalty, which he did endeavour to infu≈øe into all per≈øons committed to his Charge; and al≈øo that he is not asham'd, to proclaim to all the world (in ≈øpight of the Cen≈øures he mett with all) that he did, & doth, hold the following Queres in the affirmative; being of opinion that to hold them otherwi≈øe is to place ≈øome of the King's Supremacy in the People.

div.head: An ADDRESS vvhich the Dean of Durham ≈øent to his Maje≈øtie, ≈øpeedily after the Prince of Orange landed [upon his Brethen their Refu≈øall to joyne vvith him, becau≈øe the Superiour Clergy had not Addte≈øs'd before] to shevv his Abhorrance of that Unnaturall Inva≈øion; vvhich Addre≈øs vvas intercepted by the Lord Lumley & other Lords vvho had ≈øeiz'd on York; as mention'd page 3.

opener.salute: To the King's mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øtie.

div.head: The Hearty & Humble Addre≈ø≈øe of your Maje≈øtie's ever loyall, and faithfull, Subject, & Servant, the Dean of Durham.

opener.salute: MAY it plea≈øe your Sacred Maje≈øtie

div.p:
In time of an Inva≈øion as in a common Inundation, or Calamity by fire, VVhen every body is bound in duty to pre≈øerve the Hou≈øe, Citty, or Country, vvhereof he is a member, vvithout u≈øuall ceremony or compliment to Superior or Equalls, I do judge it an Indi≈øpen≈øable Duty of every Faithfull & right Loyall ≈øubject to ha≈øten to a≈øsi≈øt his Soveraigne vvith his pur≈øe, as vvell as his prayers, to the utmo≈øt of his povver & ability; & therefore not daring to ≈øtay till all my Betters have given me example in Addre≈ø≈øing before me, or all my inferiour Brethren have agreed on a forme to Addre≈øs vvith me, I do heartily offer to your Maje≈øty all that I have to ≈øpare for your pre≈øent ≈øervice, thinking nothing mine ovvn, in ≈øuch a time of danger, but vvhat is ≈øufficient to ≈øuffice nature: A≈øsuring you vvithall that I do not only from the very bottome of my ≈øoule Abhorre & Dete≈øt this Treacherous & Vnnaturall Inva≈øion of the Prince of Orange, together vvith all the other VVicked, Rebellious, & Bloody De≈øignes of his Adherents, vvhether
Enemies at home or abroad (and more particularly of tho≈øe among us, vvho have lately revolted from their Allegiance) but do vvith great Indignation Renounce all manner of Violence, Force, & Contempt of Authority, offer'd to your Sacred Per≈øon, or Government, either by the Rabble (the very dreg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the Mobile) in the Citty, as vvell as Rebells in the Field; Conceiving gs a great ≈øin to u≈øe any Compul≈øive Arguments to Con≈øtreine or Terrify Gods Vice-gerent into a Compliance vvith the VVill & De≈øires of his ≈øubjects, be they never ≈øo much for the good of him≈øelfe, Church, or Kingdome: having learnt in the Communion of my Mother the Church of England (vvherein I am firmly re≈øolv'd to live & dye) other principles than to teach my Supreme, or any of my Superiours, vvhat He or They ought to do, vvith a ≈øvvord in my hand, or compell a Soveraigne Monarch‚ñ™ vvhether he vvill or no, to do his duty & gratifie his people ≈øooner than he is inclin'd, or his ovvn Nece≈ø≈øity (vvhereof he is the be≈øt Iudge) vvill permit: Satisfying my≈øelfe mo≈øt thank fully vvith the repeated a≈øsurance, vvhich yeur Maje≈øty hath already given of our Religion, Lavvs, & Liberties ‚Ä¢ , together vvith all your pa≈øt & pre≈øent Gratious Conde≈øcentions to remove the Fears & Iealou≈øie of your people, Re≈øolving to ≈øtay your lea≈øure for the Calling of a Parliament, & all other means & methods, vvhich are in your Maje≈øties ovvn choice, for the ≈øecuring your ovvn Royall Per≈øon, or E≈øtablishment of your Government in Church or State.

QVERES Put by the Dean of Durham to ≈øome Young Clergy men to an≈øvver privately in his ovvn Study (near about the time his Maje≈øty ≈øent forth an order to read his Declaration for liberty of Con≈øcience) vvhich being treacherously ≈øtolen avvay, or fal≈øely tran≈øcrib'd, upon the interception of a letter to a Friend, vvere di≈øpers'd & canva≈øs'd up and dovvn the Coffee-Hou≈øes of London, & other parts of England (as mention'd pag. 7.) and are for that rea≈øon printed.
1. Whether a Subject is not bound to comply vvith his Prince in every Command, or Rea≈øonable Intimation of his plea≈øure, vvherein he is not in Con≈øcience bound to the contrary?

2 Whether a Subject is not bound to comply vvith his Prince in ≈øome things, vvhich he conceives not only inexpedient but ≈øuch as may tend to the Prejudice of the Flourishing condition of the Church (provided the Being of the Church be ≈øecure) if a lavvfull Prince of a Different Religion doth ab≈øolutely command them, & vvill not be ≈øatisfied vvithout Compliance vvith ≈øuch Command?

3. Whether the Church of England vvas not an e≈øtablish'd Church before the enacting of the Penall Lavvs? If ≈øo, vvhether it is not better to comply vvith his Maje≈øty in con≈øenting to take avvay tho≈øe Penall Lavvs vvhich his Maje≈øty de≈øires to be abrogated, than hazard the Being of our Church, by provoking the King on vvho≈øe Favour vvee depend?

div.head: TO THE BISHOP OF DURHAM.
div.p: So Suddain and violent a ≈øeparation betwixt a Bishop and his Dean, as hath been occa≈øion'd betwixt your Lordship & my ≈øelfe, by our late ≈øtupendiou ‚Ä¢ Revolution, is a matter of too great importance to be pa≈øs'd over in ≈øilence, by one who was driven from his ≈øtation by the impetuo≈øity of that dreadfull ≈øtorm, which lately fell on, and overthrew our Church and State. I conceive it therefore my duty to informe your Lordship, not only where, but what I am, in this age of mutability, which hath produced, I think, almo≈øt all kind of changes, among men of every Quality, Degree, & Calling, but that which Doctour B. speaks of, in his letters concerning his travells into Italy; I mean the change of ≈øex.

I need not, my Lord, give You any particular account of my behaviour, or u≈øage, in England, after your Lordship was call'd up to London about Michaelma≈øs la≈øt, or of the manner of my E≈øcape, ≈øince your Lordship was certified, by letters from my ≈øelfe, in the months of Oct: and Nov: la≈øt, of mo≈øt matters of moment relating to the Church and County of Durham (tho I had the honour & ≈øatisfaction of receiving an answer to few of them) and may come to the knowledge of other things, by the relation of my deportment, which I have publish'd in my printed letter to my Brother the Earle of Bathe; whereto I crave leave to
refert your Lordship, & all who are inqui≈øitive after me.

I shall only embrace this occa≈øion ≈øolemnely, & publickly, to a≈øsure your Lordship, in generall, that I did faithfully, and with as much punctuallity as I was able, di≈øcharge tho≈øe Tru≈øts which were committed to me, in every one of the places, and offices, which I had the honour to beare under your Lordship; & maintain'd my Po≈øte in your Ab≈øence, not with≈øtanding mighty di≈øcouragements, till it was not po≈ø≈øible for me any longer to ≈øtrive again≈øt that Torrent, which had hurried all matters, in that & other parts of the Nation, into great di≈øorder & confu≈øion.

When I ≈øaw there was no po≈øsible means left for me, but to ≈øink, by endeavouring to oppo≈øe what was irre≈øi≈øtable; or ≈øwimme down the ≈øtream (which no argument not example of the age could, I thank God, prevaile with me to do.) I was under a nece≈øsity to turne a≈øide, and withdraw my ≈øelfe, beholding matters a while at a di≈øtance; rather than in my own ≈øtation & place of acting; ≈øince I carried about whi ‚Ä¢ h me an unalterable loyall heart, which would not ≈øuffer me to runn (as mo≈øt did) with the multitude; & on the other ≈øide wanted both ≈øtrength of mine own, & the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of others, effectually to oppo≈øe that unruly & many headed mon≈øter. But did not re≈øolve to leave the Kingdome, & commit my Flock & Family alone to Almighty God's protection & care, (as I afterwards did) till I had a powerfull example, which a dutifull ≈øubject ought to be proud to follow, and a Precedent which may ≈øet me above the cen≈øures of any per≈øon in the three Kingdomes.

When my Soveraine was forc'd from his own pallace, nay driven out of the Realme, it was time for tho≈øe who were firmly re≈øolv'd to adhere to, & ≈øuffer with Him, to yeild to that force & nece≈ø≈øity, which A mighty Potentate, by complying with, proclaim'd to be invincible. Having then the honour to be one of that number (& glorying that I am ≈øo) it would have been a prepo≈øterous cour≈øe for me (who never play'd my game ≈øo as to ≈øave my ≈øtake) to have ≈øtay'd at home, or in England, when I was no longer capable to ≈øerve Him, in tho≈øe offices wherein I was plac'd; and while I had no other
pro≈øpect, but that of a pri≈øon, without doing what was impo≈ø≈øible for me to do, I mean bow down to Baal, or in plain English, ≈øubmit to an U≈øurper.

This occa≈øion'd my Flight fir≈øt to Carlisle, & from thence upon it's declaring for the P. of Orange; & change of Governour, to Edingburgh, & from that citty, upon intelligence of an Imbargo, into France, (as is ≈øet forth more at large in the former letter to my Brother) to have the honour & ≈øatisfaction, which is no ≈ømall con≈øolation to a loyall Subject in Banishment, of doing homage to the Royall Family, & viewing our hopefull young Prince, who will live, I tru≈øt in God, to con≈øtreine his Enemies to confe≈øs (what they were, I doubt not, alwayes per≈øwaded of in their hearts) that he is the legitimate ≈øon of King Iames the 2: and one of the greate≈øt ble≈øsings, which God ever be≈øtow'd on the English Nation.

As for my part (how great a parodox soever it may appear to ≈øome) I am fully convinced of the truth thereof, as I alwayes was of Gods wonderfull Goodne≈øs & Providence, in bringing his Father, our Gracious Soveraine, through all his troubles, to the Crown. And I fear, that our abhorr'd Ingratitude towards God for two ≈øuch ine≈øtimable ble≈øsings, as the ≈øecurity of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion by an Heire Male, & tho≈øe Halcyon dayes, which we for two years enjoy'd (and might have enjoy'd longer had it not been our own faults) under a Gracious Prince of a conde≈øcending race, have above other ≈øins pull'd down God's judgements, & contributed towards the mi≈øerry we now groan under, & the greater mi≈øery which hangs over our heads, & out of which we can never be deliver'd, but by the extraordinary a≈øsi≈øtance of the ≈øame mercifull & gracious God and King, whom we have above mea≈øure provoked and incens'd.

I have never been asham'd, I thank God, to owne ≈øuch ≈øentiments, as the≈øe, amid≈øt all the delu≈øions, which the generality of men of a contrary opinion have layen under, & the greate≈øt Obloquy & Contempt, which by them hath been ca≈øt on every one, who ≈øtuck clo≈øe to his Maje≈øty (as I thank God I have done to the utmo≈øt of my power) in a≈øserting his Prerogative. But I need not affirme this to your Lordship, or any within your Dioce≈øse, having ≈øufficiciently proclaim'd my judgement
concerning the≈øe matters, in the pulpit, both in the Cathedrall & other Churches, after his Maje≈øty's happy acce≈øsion to the Imperial Crown, & the Birth of the Prince of Wales.

Towards the Filling up the mea≈øure of that Iniquity, wherewith our ju≈øt God would no longer di≈øpen≈øe, & whereto our Kings, our Princes, & our Prophets, nay all the people in the land, (to ≈øpeak in the Evangelical Prophets phra≈øe,) have contributed more or le≈øs, I know, that I my ≈øelfe [a wretched mi≈øerable ≈øinner] have ≈øadly help'd in every one of my capacities, & heartily beg pardon of God through JESUS-CHRIST for my share of the guilt. But it is to me an un≈øpeakable comfort, that neither my Enemies, nor my own Con≈øcience, can accu≈øe me of tho≈øe ≈øins, which do ≈øeem to be the more immediate ingredients of God's wrath, & which certainly more than others have provoked him, in ≈øuch Manner, & by ≈øuch In≈øtruments, to punish Us.

For I have heartily, from the bottome of my ≈øoule, rejoyc'd at our Gracious Soverain's mounting the Throne, at Gods ble≈øsing him & us with a hopefull Prince. I have been all along, without murmuring, contented with his Government. I have had allwayes more jealou≈øy of the ≈øubject, than of my Soveraigne. I have thought our ≈øelves (as it hath proved) nearer a Rebellion, than the Introducing of Popery. And la≈øtly I am not, no not in the thoughts of my heart, guilty, in the lea≈øtwi≈øe, of that Perfidiousne≈øs, & Ingratitude, to my Soveraigne, or Inju≈øtice & Vnnaturalne≈øs to my Fellovv-Subjects, of calling in Forreigne a≈øsi≈øtance for our Pre≈øervation. Or if I had, it should have been any Nation in the world rather than our Neighbours of Holland, being not ignorant of their dealings with the English both at Amboina & Bantam.

Tis highly probable, my Lord, that the≈øe very things which I here alledge for my ju≈øtification, & wherein I ≈øo much glory, will be received with deri≈øion, and objected again≈øt me as my crimes, & that mine & other men's forwardne≈øs to obey, & comply vvith, the King, has contributed to his Fall. This is a fate, which I am ≈øure it will not be po≈øsible for me to avoid, ≈øince that, before I left the Nation, I had this lay'd to my
charge, by ≈øome, who to ju≈øtify their own ≈øawning on the Mobile, out of Fear or Intre≈øt, began to lay all the guilt of the King & Kingdome's overthrow to the door of the King & his mo≈øt obedient ≈øubjects; as in Oates's & Tong's plot, ≈øome brought in our late gracious Soveraigne as concern'd in a de≈øigne again≈øt his own Life.

But I would crave leave, here, to know who are the Objectors. If they are ≈øuch as have renounced their Allegiance to their lawfull Soveraigne, I may ≈øave the labour to an≈øwer them; they being not qualified to cen≈øure & accu≈øe me, for helping to what they were well pleas'd with, & de≈øir'd should be brought to pa≈øs.

If they be ≈øuch as will not, at la≈øt, ≈øubmit to the change of Government, & take new oaths, tho they have been too far concern'd in, & have too much contributed to, the ≈øetting up an u≈øurp'd power (by a greater Complai≈øance with the Prince of Orange, than I have been guilty of towards my Soveraigne) I reply, that the Doctrine of Non-re≈øi≈øtance which we have alwayes, till of late, been fond of, ≈øet forth at large in our Church-Homilies, doth ju≈øtify my behaviour; whereof any one may be ≈øoon convinced that will be pleas'd to take the paines (which I have lately done) of ≈øeriously peru≈øing, ≈øtudying, & analizing the Homilies published by authority, Concerning Obedience, & again≈øt vvillfull Di≈øobedience or Rebellion; From whence, no more than from the Holy ≈øcripture, can I learn any Medium betwixt Re≈øi≈øtance & Compliance. He that doth not comply with Expre≈øs & Po≈øitive commands of his Soveraigne, when he beleives tho≈øe commands lawfull, doth in ≈øome ≈øort re≈øi≈øt Him; that ≈øaying of our Lord, in this ca≈øe, being certainly applicable, He that is not for me is again≈øt me.

But the≈øe, & like cen≈øures, will not, my Lord, in any great mea≈øure afflict me. It hath been my fate to be, from my Youth, inur'd to ≈øuch, & greater, exerci≈øes of patience. Indeed I might be induced, rather to ≈øu≈øpect my Loyalty and Fidelity to my Soveraigne, If I should now e≈øcape Scot-free & not be pelted at by tho≈øe, who out of the ≈øame mouth can blow hot & cold, obey a lawfull Prince, & obey an U≈øurper; who≈øe unju≈øtifyable proceedings (ble≈øsed be God) my ≈øoule doth dete≈øt &
abhorr, being founded in that Laodicean temper, loath≈øome to God & Goodmen, which I have labour'd ever ≈øince I have born any publick office in Church or State, as far as it was po≈øsible for me, to oppo≈øe.

Your Lordship, I am ≈øure, (which is my comfort) will be none of tho≈øe, who shall load me with reproaches, for my dutifull Complyances whith his Maje≈øty, ≈øince your example, (which did out run others) as well as your advice, did powerfully invite me thereto. And ≈øince your Lordship hath been ≈øo kind as to atte≈øt, with your mouth to his Maje≈øty, that I was never backward to concurr with You, in any thing which was for the King's ≈øervice. Wherefore I shall ≈øpend no more ink to di≈øturb your Lordship with inlarging on ≈øo unnece≈øsary a Topick. But I shall take care to ≈øtrive (by God's grace) to make good the Character, which your Lordship was‚ñ™ pleas'd to give of me la≈øt year to the King, you was not, my Lord, any wayes deceiv'd in your atte≈øtation, neither shall his Maje≈øty (I tru≈øt in God) in his expectations from me.

The remaining paper then‚ñ™ my Lord, will be more ≈øignificantly imploy'd in laying, before your Lordship & the World, the Rea≈øons, why I have not govern'd my ≈øelfe by your Lordships example ≈øince October la≈øt, as I did before, & cannot be prevail'd on now to comply with the People's, as I did with the Lord's Annointed my Leige & Dread Soveraigne.

It was, I know, ≈øadly bewailable for per≈øons in ≈øuch publick ≈øtations, & ≈øo nearly related, as the Bishop & Dean of Dutham, to draw two wayes, as we did (I mu≈øt confe≈øs) after your Lordship was pleas'd to pre≈øent a paper of Advice to his Maje≈øty, to comply with the demands of the Multitude.

And it was the more to be lamented, that ≈øuch divi≈øion should happen, in a juncture of affairs, & Concu≈øsion of the Church & State, that requir'd the Uniting of all per≈øons in every body Eccle≈øia≈øtick & Civil (all which ≈øtrength was little enough) to uphold our Soveraign Lord's Crown & Dignity; which we, both, were ≈øtricktly by our repeated oathes (and po≈øsibly more than all others by particular obligations, having receiv'd our preferments by his favour) ingag'd to maintaine, & which were more dangerously than ever ≈øtruck at by Enemies at home & abroad.

I was a≈øtonish'd, my Lord at ≈øo ≈øuddaine & unexpected, a change, & was, out of re≈øpect to your Lordship, one of the la≈øt that, in the Citty & Church of Durham, gave credit to the reports (wherein your honour was concern'd) which bu≈øied for a while the mouth of almo≈øt every per≈øon in the County.

That, that very method which we were affraid, nay well a≈øsur'd of, before parting, was likely to de≈øtroy our pre≈øent Government & Governours (things portending as badly as in forty one) should ≈øo immediately (according to your own expre≈øsion) become the only, & mo≈øt a≈øsur'd, means of the Pre≈øervation of the Kings per≈øon, & e≈øtablishment of his Government in Church and State, gave me occa≈øion beyond all mea≈øure to admire. And what should move your Lordship, of all men in the Nation, in an unusuall way, to advi≈øe his Maje≈øty ≈øo to do, is not yet di≈øcover'd by me, th√¥ it often imployes my thoughts.

This change of Mea≈øures in your Lordship my Dioce≈øan, who≈øe Coun≈øell, Example, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, I did more than ever need and expect, at ≈øuch a de≈øperate Cri≈øis, did wonderfully weaken mee in the di≈øcharge of all Duties incumbent on mee, either as a Church-man or Ju≈øtice of the Peace, and did put mee under an unavoidable nece≈ø≈øity of abating in my zeale to attempt ≈øundry things, and ingage in ≈øeverall De≈øigns, which could not be pro≈øecuted, much le≈øs accomplish'd, without the concurrence of my Bishop and Lord Lieutenant.

This did likewi≈øe incapacitate me to cen≈øure, or ≈øo much as curb tho≈øe in≈øolent Young Clergy-men, who before your Departure were arriv'd to ≈øuch a pitch of blodne≈øs, as to expo≈øe by undecent in≈øinuations in the Congregation, not only their Dean, but Bishop, for Obedience to the King. And which impotency of mine was, the very Sunday after, made con≈øpicuous, by an other indi≈øcreet Sermon preach'd in the Cathedrall pulpit, which I was forc'd to pa≈øs by without ≈øo much as admonition (only denying the Preacher the cu≈øtomary re≈øpects of an invitation to my table) for fear of a ≈øecond affront. Since in≈øtead of a≈øsi≈øtance from tho≈øe, who were ≈øworne to give me that, & much more, I met with reproaches, & was told in the publick di≈øcharge of the Deans office, that I vvas vvell enough Serv'd in that my Bishop had left me in the Lurch.

I had no small difficulty to bear up again≈øt & repell tho≈øe Arguments, which were brought, the la≈øt year, out of the other Province, from the example of great & venerable Prelates, which my intirely devoted heart to honour and obey my King, would not permit me to immitate, tho mode≈øty would not allow me openly to condemn. But when tho≈øe, who labour'd to shake me off from my foundation of firm Loyalty, & to betray my Innocence, by perswading me to enter into the Herd, di≈øcernd mee void of my la≈øt ≈øupport, & depriv'd of the example of my own Bishop & Father in God, they attackt me (your Lordship my imagine) with too great ≈øtrength and rudene≈øs, for a ≈øingle Dean, without Countenance of Superiour, or Concurrence of Inferiour Brethren, any longer to with≈øtand or oppo≈øe, with any con≈øiderable effect.

Tho God Almighty (prais'd be his holy Name) endow'd me, in that day of Triall, with ≈øo much courage, as to attempt to do it, in ≈øuch manner, as may hereafter prove to Edification; never changing my Note nor Mea≈øures (when all began to dance after an outlandish Pipe) as long as I ≈øtay'd on the Place. Witne≈øs my Sermons I preach'd on the 5. & 9. of December‚ñ™ two dayes before I fled, & the Sunday after the Generality of the Citty & Country had, with open Armes & Mouths, receiv'd a Di≈øcontented Lord, who the week before ≈øeiz'd on the Town for the P. of Orange‚ñ™ & prophan'd both your Ca≈øtle, & the Markett Cro≈øs, with the reading of a Trea≈øonnable Declaration, as is related more at large in the foregoing letter.

I could not accord, I mu≈øt confe≈øs, with ≈øuch Example of your Lordship, nor with the Example of others, in being ≈øilent, or ≈øitting ≈øtill, in a time of imminent Danger, VVarr‚ñ™ & Tumult, when good Nature, as well as good Con≈øcience, dictated to all faithfull Clergy men & Chri≈øtians, not only to li≈øt up their voices like a Trumpett, but to employ all their hands to have re≈øtrain'd the unruly multitude, which had got the Bitt in their Teeth, & were runing madly to a Change of Government, and Depo≈øition of their King; & in that towards their own De≈øtruction; ≈øince the Monarchy, as well as our Church, was like to receive (as it hath done) an incureable
blow, by an other Di≈øgrace & Banishment of a lawfull Soveraigne of the ≈øame Stock & Race, which had been once before barbarously treated beyond expre≈øsion, & in ≈øuch degree, that the English Nation, for a while, became an object of Contempt & Indignation among the very Turks & Pagans.

However matters might appear to your Lordship, & other Prelates above at London, (as I ought in duty to conclude, by their & your Actings, that they did otherwi≈øe than to me below) I could not di≈øcover, when my eyes were mo≈øt open, & clear'd by ≈øerious & fervent Devotion, that any thing or cour≈øe tended more to the pre≈øervation of the King's Crown, & ≈øecurity of our Church under Him, than our unfeign'd ≈øubmi≈øsion to our ≈øupreme Moderatour & Governour, & our vigorous & con≈øtant oppo≈øition of ≈øeditious Incendiaries & Male-contents, who any wi≈øe Irritated, or Inflam'd the People, or did undutifully capitulate with the King, being agitated (as was apparent) by an humour of Popularity, & that Republican ≈øpirit which was gone forth into the Nation, which ought to have been with≈øtood ≈øomuch the more, by how much it had gotten ≈øtrength, & numbers, to terrify ≈øome of our greate≈øt Leaders in our very Sion, as well as our Jeru≈øalem; who put them≈øelves into a mo≈øt dangerous Po≈øte [the head of the Multitude] not out of di≈øaffection to the King, I am perswaded, ≈øo much as out of fear of that ungovernable Bea≈øt, who will make le≈øs ≈øcruple to pull off the B ‚Ä¢ sho'ps Lawnsleeves & the Earle's Coronets, than either of them, in the Convention, did to deprive their Lord & Soveraign's head of the Crown. And I mu≈øt confe≈øs my ≈øelfe ≈øo short ≈øighted, or hard to be convinced, that I cannot as yet ≈øee, or owne, that I then made a wrong judgement of things, or, on that account, labour'd under any Errour.

Would God, that all tho≈øe, whom I dare not deny to be, as they think them≈øelves, very much wi≈øer men (tho they did approach as much towards rudene≈øs in withs≈øtanding, as I did towards Flattery in complying with the King) had not too late di≈øcern'd the pernitious fatallne≈øs of the contrary Errour, in endeavouring to bring Gods Vice gerent to Terms, whereby the Soveraignty of our Defender of the faith, was ≈øo weaken'd,
broken, & shatter'd, that he was not able to protect either Church, or State, or ≈øo much as his own Sacred Per≈øon from the hands of the Rabble‚ñ™ nay not ≈øecure his very pocketts, at la≈øt, from the Fate of me his unworthy ≈øervant, & other his Subjects, I mean, from being in our flight pick'd & rifled.

Hinc illae lachrim ‚Ä¢ . And I make no que≈øtion, but that if Tears would redre≈øs what is pa≈øt, thou≈øands of tho≈øe, who murmured & complain'd of the King, would shed whole rivers to re≈øtore the King, the Church & the Kingdome to the Circum≈øtances (as bad as they then thought them) which they were all in but la≈øt year. But God knows it is now too late to make u≈øe of ≈øuch feeble means, for the recovery of what is lo≈øt, flouds of tears being not like to prevaile, unle≈øs accompanied with a holy violence, & conjoyn'd with ≈øincere & hearty prayer, i≈øsueing out from a truely penitent heart, & deeply humbled Soule.

Wee have, God knows, madly gra≈øp'd our Religion, our Liberty, & our Laws, out of the hands of our own lawfully de≈øcended, mercyfull, Prince, who manife≈øted all a long, & even at the la≈øt upshot, that he carried about him, as he profe≈øs'd, a truly English heart, & who≈øe Intere≈øt it was (whatever was his Maje≈øtys Religion) to uphold them all; Gra≈øp'd them away, I ≈øay & put them into the power, & at the mercy of Forreigners, who≈øe Humour & Inclination it is, as well as Intere≈øt, to de≈øtroy them all; whereof a few months are like to afford Us more lamentable Demon≈øtrations, as we have rea≈øon to apprehend, by the Tran≈øactions of five or ≈øix that are pa≈øt.

By the≈øe few hone≈øt reflections, on the mi≈øerable E≈øtate of my Native Country, & more particularly on the Cathedrall & Archdeaconry of Durham (which I cannot here reflect on without often ≈øitting down & weep) your Lordship may perceive, that I am the very ≈øame, that You found me, when You entred on your Dioce≈øs 17. years agoe; & left me in the month of Octobet la≈øt, bearing the Brunt of that dreadfull Hurricane, which was then coming out of Holland, & ≈øtrugling with that in≈øatiable Hydra, which did widely gape for the Crown and Myter, & is like after devouring it's ≈øupports (like a Jugglar) to di≈øgorge a Commonwealth.

I am indeed, my Lord, on all accounts, & to all intents
& purpo≈øes, the very ≈øame that I have ever been; intirely devoted to the Honour, & Intere≈øt of the ROYALL FAMILY OF THE STVARTS, & ≈øo unalterable & ≈øteddy a Practi≈øer, as well as Profe≈øsour, of the old Church-of-England-Religion (& more e≈øpecially of tho≈øe di≈øtinguishing Doctrines which do ≈øignally honour our Church, & which were, whil'≈øt practis'd, ≈øo lovely in the eyes of all, as to prevaile with a Rom: Cath: Prince at his mounting the Throne to continue and protect her) that I can by the power of no temptation, or Arguments of Dutch Divinity, be induced to do any certain ≈øinfull act to pre≈øerve her, whether by way of re≈øi≈øting my lawfull Soveraigne, or complying with an U≈øurper.

I ≈øay, my Lord, that I am, both by Nature & In≈øtinct, a perfect Abhorrer of that Diabolick ≈øin of Rebellion, however varnisht over by the Father of lyes, & by what Names or Titles ≈øoever it be dignified or di≈øtinguish'd. And, in the ≈øame temper of mind, I do here declare to your Lordship (which I de≈øire may be communicated to every Per≈øon in your Dioce≈øse under You) that I am re≈øolv'd, by the grace of the Almighty, to end my dayes.

Greiving that your Lordship hath, by doing homage to a Superiour which I cannot owne, ab≈øolv'd me, in a great mea≈øure, from the Canonicall Obedience, Duty, & Re≈øpect, which I did once owe You, (& whereby I am capacitated to take greater freedome with your Lordship‚ñ™ than 'twas lawfull for me to doe in former letters, as well as debarr'd of of begging your Benediction, with the ≈øame delight I have done formely,) I re≈øt.
div.closer:
MY LORD Ro√ºen July the 1. 1689.
Your Lordships, &c‚ñ™ DENIS GRANVILLE.

div.head: To the Vice-Dean & Prebendaries of the Cathedrall Church of Durham.

opener.salute: MR. Vice-Dean & other Prebendaries of Durham.

div.p: Tho the bodily Infirmities I now feele, as well as the greater ones I have ≈øtruggled with ≈øince I left Durham, [intimated in a letter from Edingburgh] have been, and are, ≈øufficient to excu≈øe my Ab≈øence, and may ju≈øtify me in the eyes of God & Man, for leaving, for ≈øome time, ≈øo cold and moi≈øt an air, as the North of England, and repairing into a Clime more warme and benigne, Yet I, who have been, all my dayes, a Lover of Plain-dealing, think not fit to conceal, any longer, the more ≈øub≈øtantial rea≈øons, which did at fir≈øt hurry me away from You, and do ≈øtill detain me abroad.

Till I was well got out of the reach of tho≈øe New Governours, whom I could neither owne, nor obey, and from whom, for that very cau≈øe, had hopes of ≈ømall favour, I was, as well as my Betters, nece≈ø≈øitated to u≈øe, the mo≈øt plau≈øible Arguments I could with Innocence, for a Voyage into France, without declaring the bottome of my de≈øigne. And Providence, at that time, furnishing me with one very Authentick, and rea≈øonable enough [to witt, upon the returne of a dangerous Cough to go once more into a Country, from which I had receiv'd formerly con≈øiderable advantage, in point of Health,] I should have been much to blame, if I had not made u≈øe thereof, as I did, in order to my E≈øcape.

On this account (in my letter to You, & di≈øcour≈øe with tho≈øe I mett in my journey) I in≈øi≈øted on little el≈øe, than what related to my then growing Indi≈øpo≈øition, which was come to a great height; neither did I (God be thank'd) meet, or conver≈øe with any ≈øo unrea≈øonable, or inqui≈øitive, as to demand ≈øtronger motives, than the recovery and pre≈øervation of my health, (the next valuable Ble≈ø≈øing to the Salvation of my Soule,) to authori≈øe my de≈øigne of ha≈øtning into this Kingdome: famous for it's Soveraigne & Beneficial air for all Con≈øumptive Con≈øtitutions; & the virtue whereof, tho I am not got into the mo≈øt ≈øalutiferous Region, I now already, in a very great mea≈øure perceive.

But tho all I alledge be very true and real, yet I dare not deny that other and greater matters (≈øet forth in a precedent letter) did fir≈øt put it into my thoughts, and incline me to quitt my Station, and without which, had the danger of my life been never ≈øo great, I mu≈øt confe≈øs, that, I think, I had never more thus left my Charges, after ≈øo con≈øiderable an Ab≈øence heretofore (to recover my health) from my Offices & Cures.

In plain English then, I declare to all the World, that the true Cau≈øe of my ≈øuddain flight was, that I carried about me a Con≈øcience more untractable, and le≈øs pliable to an U≈øurpation, than mo≈øt I left behind ‚Ä¢ , as proce≈øs of time hath made too apparent. My Con≈øcience (≈øuch as it was) did oblige me, to the utmo≈øt of my Strength, to oppo≈øe all u≈øurp'd power (as I did to the la≈øt, wittne≈øs all the Congregation pre≈øent in the Quire the Sunday before my departure) and then, I need not tell You, it was not fitt for me to ≈øtay there, any longer. I might u≈øe the word impo≈øsible rather than unfitt, ≈øince I could not with good Con≈øcience ≈øtay. Id tantum po≈øsumus (≈øayes the Civillian) quod jure po≈øsumus.

I cannot deny that every one of You, and all tho≈øe Clergy in the Nation, which were ≈øatisfied and re≈øolv'd, to Submitt; that is to ≈øay renounce your Allegiance to your Lawfull Soveraigne, and ≈øwear new to tho≈øe, who have ungodlily, and unju≈øtly, depos'd him, have done politickly enough to remaine at home, ≈øit ≈øtill, & hold your Tongues; at a time, when
the Right Church-of-England-Religion, (according to the be≈øt notion I have of it) nay Chri≈øtianity in generall, required all faithfull Preachers to lift up their voices like a Trumpet, to oppo≈øe the madne≈øs of the People, & ≈øtop them in their Carreer to De≈øtruction.

But I, your unworthy Dean, who, without doubt or ≈øcruple, beleived it, at that time, as I do at pre≈øent, a peice of dete≈øtable Rebellion to joyne with any, in a Con≈øpiracy again≈øt our Kings Crown, as well as Life, (and de≈øire to be torne with wild Hor≈øes rather than ≈øo to do,) did as politickly, (and I am ≈øure more hone≈øtly) in withdrawing.

But I de≈øire You to remember, that I did not ≈øtir from my Po≈øte, till the Citty of Durham was polluted by the Reading of a Declaration, which by a late Proclamation of the King's was pronounced trea≈øonable; & that there wer√® not four publick Magi≈øtrates, nor one Mini≈øter in the Town, had the Courage any wayes to oppo≈øe it, or declare their di≈øsent thereto: a v ‚Ä¢ ry feeble ≈øupport for a Dean re≈øolv'd [as I then declar'd I was, & now declare a new that I am] to ≈øtick clo≈øe, by God's grace, to the Crown of my only lawfull Soveraigne King Iames the 2., his Heires, & Succe≈øsours: knowing no difference betwixt the Duty & Obedience I owe to a Prince of the Prote≈øtant, & to a Prince of the Roman Faith.

Nay I de≈øire you moreover to con≈øider, that I did not runn avvay & for≈øake my flocks, as ≈øome may be apt to object, when I ≈øaw the Wolfe coming, but after I ≈øaw him come, & with open mouth ready to devoure, & had my ≈øelfe in ≈øome ≈øort ta≈øted his Fiercene≈øs.

By which time, the Wicked Contrivers of this ≈øad Revolution had accomplish'd what they had been long endeavouring, ≈øtript the King of all his Supports, put him under a nece≈ø≈øity, as well as his mo≈øt faithfull Subjects, to fly into an other Nation, & shewn their Good Will towards the Di≈ø≈øolution of the Government.

And farther, and above all this, tho I could not ≈øtay longer in Durham, without being defiled by concurring, or confined for
oppo≈øing, I did not leave England, till the 20. of January; nor fly out of the Kings Dominions, till the Subject, who was tender enough of his own Property, had after innumerable Violations of the King's Prerogative, pre≈øum'd to dis≈øpo≈øe of the very Crown.

For The crovvn offer'd to the Prince of Orange on Ashvven≈ødayAshwensday was over, before I took shipping in Scotland. A Di≈ømal day, a day, which I shall mark in my Calendar, with a note of deeper Humiliation than before; A day, which, by all truely devoted Soules to the Honour & Intere≈øt of the Imperiall Crown of England, will be remembred with more Regrett than Ashwensday 53. A day indeed, once thought fitt for the Inauguration of an Cromvell declar'd Protector on Ashvven≈øday 16 ‚Ä¢ 3. U≈øurper; who th√¥ in all other re≈øpects odious & infamous, had not the boldne≈øs to ≈øeize on the Crown, nor the People of England, at that time, (th√¥ plunged over head & ears in Rebellion) the Timidity nor. Stupidity, to offer it to him, who without all di≈øpute might then with le≈øs ≈øin, & with more prudence, have put it on his Head‚ñ™ (it having for a while before been depo≈øited and unimploy'd,) than ≈øome body ≈øince ≈ønatch'd it from the Head of his own Uncle, nay Father.

This is, Gentlemen, the true & real cau≈øe of my withdrawing. And if You plea≈øe to be mind full of the criticall time vvhen, the manner hovv, & the cau≈øe vvherefore, being al≈øo ≈øo ju≈øt to your Dean, as not to looke barely on his going away, but con≈øider it as circum≈øtantiated, and allowing me ≈øo much Charity (who have alwayes exercis'd greater towards my Dependants) as to beleive I did, at lea≈øt, mean well then, and do ≈øpeak true at pre≈øent, I am willing to beare all other ccn≈øures you can load me with, for this late hazardous undertaking, which however it may be mi≈ø-under≈øtood, in England, (over which, as of late, there ≈øeemes ≈øtill to hang ≈øome notorious cloud & mi≈øt, which ≈øtrangely ob≈øcures mens under≈øtanding) and deem'd an act of Fear or Folly; yet I am, God be prais'd, fully per≈øwaded that it was the mo≈øt hone≈øt, the mo≈øt couragious, & thc vvi≈øe≈øt Act of my who≈øe Life. And do ince≈øsantly prai≈øe his name, that he was pleas'd to endow me with his grace, (pa≈ø≈øing by many more capable to do him ≈øervice,) at that very time, and in ≈øuch manner as I did, to Beare vvittne≈øs to the Truth.

1, For my Flock, had I (who≈øe notion both of Religion
& Loyalty had caus'd me all a long to act at an other rate fail'd by a ≈øordid & truely mean compliance, I had certainly done them irreparable wrong, by thwarting my pa≈øt Doctrine, & de≈øtroying the example of my whole Life.

2. As for my Revenue, th√¥ I po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd the be≈øt Deanery, and po≈øsibly the be≈øt Archdeaconry, & one of the be≈øt Livings, in England, A Faithfull Chri≈øtian ought not ≈øo highly to value them, as to put them into the ≈øcales with his Con≈øcience. The≈øe two particulars granted, I leave all men to judge, whether it was an unwi≈øe act of mine, all things con≈øider'd, to withdraw vvhen, & in ≈øuch manner, as I did. I do well a≈øsure my ≈øelfe, that it will be e≈øteem'd otherwi≈øe, by all tho≈øe that do not deny the truth of this undoubted maxime, that Hone≈øty is the be≈øt Policy. And I do comfort my ≈øelfe, that my poor exploded Notions of Hone≈øty & Religion, Loyalty to my King, & obedience to the Precepts & Rules of the Church, will yet come in vogue before I leave the World (tho I have too much rea≈øon to apprehend, that, unle≈øs the change of air pre≈øerve me, I shall not be a long liv'd man (however they be run down, & rejected in this intoxicated Age, which hath, in a manner, captivated men's Sen≈øes, as well as their Under≈øtandings.

I that am, the Lord be thanked, happily deliver'd, for a while, from the Foggs of my own Country (which were ≈øadly increas'd ≈øince it's late Alliance & Communication with Holland) do no more doubt, than I cea≈øe to pray for, the King's glorious, & ble≈øsed Re≈øtauration. That joyfull Day in ≈øpight of Men & Devils, will come, as ≈øoon, as the Church and Kingdome are, by a profound Humiliation & ≈øincere Repentance, prepared for ≈øo choice a ble≈øsing. And when it doth come, or is nigh approaching, it will infallibly open men's eyes, & cau≈øe them clearly to di≈øcerne their pa≈øt egregious folly & facility, in ≈øuffering them≈øelves to be ≈øo ≈øoon overcome, by ≈øuch deplorable Delu≈øion, as not to di≈øtinguish betwixt the felicity of living under an undi≈øputable lawfull & gratious Prince (of the mo≈øt mercifull and eligible Race and Qualifications) & bearing
the Yoke of an U≈øurper, who≈øe Crown mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be maintain'd, as it is gotten, by the Sword. And who≈øe Reigne, tho it begins in nomine Domini, & is usher'd in by a shevv of Religion, & ≈øeeming love of Liberty, & Lavves, ≈øoon becomes greivous, & his little finger felt much heavier, than the Lawfull Predece≈ø≈øour's Loyns.

It will not be needfull to pretend to the Spirit of Prophecy for this Di≈øcovery, the la≈øt eight or nine Month's experience doth powerfully evince the Truth of what I affirme. There doth ≈øeem already to be eyes enough open, if their hands were at Liberty, [and good ≈øwords in them] in Scotland, & England too, as well as Ireland, to deliver tho≈øe mi≈øerable Kingdomes from reall Tyranny & Presbitery, which are not like to be found much more tollerable, for the late inju≈øtifiable, as well as unintelligible method of Exclu≈øion of Popery, & pretended Arbitrary Povver.

All tho≈øe who were come to, & could exerci≈øe, their Under≈øtandings, from the year 41 to the year 60, cannot forget the un≈øufferable Slavery which the three Kingdomes underwent‚ñ™ upon the unhappy Conjunction of tho≈øe foremention'd un≈øeparable Twins. The horrid Rebellion of tho≈øe dayes was le≈øs odious than the pre≈øent one; which is accompanied with the highe≈øt Aggravations; le≈øs odious I ≈øay, or at lea≈øt le≈øs unnaturall, (than that under which the be≈øt Subjects & Chri≈øtians in England at pre≈øent groan) in ≈øundry re≈øpects, had not the former been deeply dyed in the blood of King Charles the Martyr. And yet all the Religion, & great o≈øtentation of Purity of the Go≈øpell, wherewith it was introduced, & at la≈øt, after a floud of Loyall blood, ≈øubmitted to, by an infatuated Generation, ended at length in down right Enthu≈øia≈øme; which, by breaking of Fences, & tearing up Foundations, let in a Deluge of all kind of Prophanene≈øs. The Priviledges & Properties, as well as the Liberty of the Subject, were got into the hands of ≈øuch mi≈øerable Keepers, as kept them all to them≈øelves: in ≈øuch ≈øort, as ≈øcarce any Per≈øon. You do well remember, could be Ma≈øter of them, or meet with them, but at Wallingford Hou≈øe. In a word, after inexpre≈ø≈øible violence & Inju≈øtice, Cutting off ≈øundry Pillars of Church & State, & mo≈øt tho≈øe well fix'd Church of England-men [Clergy
or Layicks] who had the valour to with≈øtand the U≈øurpers of tho≈øe dayes, all matters, at la≈øt, run into Anarchy & Confu≈øion. And the Babell, which had been twenty years in building, after a short tottering, at the Death of their Cheif Upholder, fell, & crush'd it's ≈øelfe with it's own weight, and cover'd all their Antimonarchicall machinations with it's Ruines.

The ≈øerious & ≈øober review of all pa≈øt Tran≈øactions, from the begining of the long & great Rebellion home to the Dutch Inva≈øion, to witt; of the fir≈øt ≈øtupendious wickedne≈øs of the Enimies of the King & Church of England: The wonderfull long ≈øuffering of a ju≈øtly Incens'd God; His unconceivable Goodne≈øs and Compa≈øsion at length in a reall delivery of the Nation, & our Church, [from not only the mo≈øt Arbitrary power, which had been before exerci≈øed, but from the utmo≈øt malice of all it's wor≈øt Adver≈øaries, who were watching to devour her] The wretched Requitall of God's mercy & Love, made to Heaven, by the mo≈øt Real (I fear none can excu≈øe them≈øelves) as well as pretended Friends of Crown & Myter, in repaying ≈øuch unexpre≈øsible Bounty with Contempt and Ingratitude; &, at la≈øt, the mo≈øt deplorable Folly & Madne≈øs of the People of England, in being catch'd by, nay running into, the very ≈øame Snares, wherein they had been once before intangled, by the Subtilty of the Devil, almo≈øt to their utter De≈øtruction. The recalling to mind & thorough Con≈øideration, I ≈øay, of ≈øuch, & the like pa≈øsages, should have made us, methinks, wi≈øe enough to have avoided, in due ≈øea≈øon, the ≈øame Trap which was again laid for us, & into which we are a ≈øecond time fall√©n. At lea≈øt, one would gue≈øse (or else we are become perfectly ≈øtupid & in≈øen≈øible) should awake every one to look to his After-Game, for fear we may be remedile≈øsly depriv'd of the remaining part of our Felicity, which is bound up in the life of our di≈øtre≈øs'd Soveraigne, & his legitimate I≈ø≈øue, by our gratious Queen-Con≈øort, who hath evidenced her ≈øelfe, in the≈øe & former innumerable Troubles of our afflicted, & thrice banisht Prince, a notable Example of Submi≈øsion & Patience, & who ought to be for being made, by God, the happy In≈øtrument of bringing us the Ble≈øsing of a hopefull Heir Male, for ever Dear to the English Nation, & all faithfull Subjects to the Crown of England.

If ≈øuch extraordinary Dealings of the God of Heaven, varied to every man's capacity & condition; If neither God's ≈øpeaking by a still voice, nor in the VVhirlevvind, neither by the Sunshine of mercyes, nor the Thunder of his Judgements, [that dreadfull Clap, whereinto the late black Clouds driven into England out of Holland, broke very fatally, to the unhinging of the whole Fabrick of our Government both in Church & State,] will reclaime us, & make us ≈øen≈øible of our mo≈øt real Intere≈øt, & Happyne≈øs in a mo≈øt de≈øireable & w√©ll‚ñ™ e≈øtablisht Monarchy & Epi≈øcopacy, [& a gratious Prince, according to the heart's wish of every right loyall ≈øon of the Church of England, ≈øave that he doth not ptofe≈øs our Religion;] nor reduce us to that intire obedience & ≈øubmi≈øsion to the King and Church, which the wi≈øe di≈øpen≈øations of a loving & long-≈øuffering God ≈øeem, above other things, by many repeated Summon≈øes, loudly to call for, there remains nothing but a Fearfull looking for of Iudgement. I know no Salve for our ≈øore; nor can di≈øcover any thing which can mollify ≈øuch ≈øtony hearts, or mortify ≈øuch corrupt natures; that have lamentably defeated our heavenly Father, in all his methods to do good unto us; & ≈øave us. And I, who have never been (all that know me mu≈øt confe≈øs) a man of exce≈øsive fear & jealou≈øy, as to the Publick, mu≈øt ≈øink down into di≈øpaire: & conclude that the people of England, the other Day, an object of envy to all the Nations round about us, are ≈øignally mark'd out for God's di≈øplea≈øure, & will be made a ≈øtanding Monument of his Wrath to all ≈øucceding Ages‚ñ™

But I shall not detaine You longer with Reflections on the State of England. It will be a Duty more incumbent on me to con≈øider the Circum≈øtances of Durham, & therein tho≈øe of the Cathedrall Church, my ≈øpeciall & more particular Charge, wherein I have been by the Favour of my King, rather than my own merit, ≈øet to Pre≈øide.

And indeed I cannot thoroughly reflect on that Church & Citty, wherein I have (by God's permi≈øsion & the Kings kindne≈øs) had the honour, for the la≈øt 27. years, to be dignified, without melting into Tears. To con≈øider that the Bishoprick & Cathedrall Church of Durham, which had ≈øo well approv'd them≈øelves both to his late‚ñ™ & pre≈øent Maje≈øty, & u≈øually
exceeded others in expre≈ø≈øions of Loyalty, should now lye undi≈øtinguishable, & incorporated into the Ma≈øs of Rebellion, which the wi≈øe & ju≈øt God is pleas'd to permit to oppre≈øs the whole Land, peirces my very Soule.

It was one of the mo≈øt painfull mortifications I ever met with, the weeke before my Departure, to di≈øcerne my ≈øelfe de≈øerted by all the Citty-Clergy in my hone≈øt zeal for the righteous Cau≈øe of my Soveraigne; In ≈øuch ≈øort, as not to di≈øcover, then on the place, any one Eccle≈øia≈øtick, neither in the Cathedrall, nor any Parochial Church, or Chappell, with in the Precincts of that Citty, who had the courage, at that juncture, to own openly, either in the Pulpit, or in his Conver≈øation, his oppre≈øs'd Prince's Intere≈øt‚ñ™ and Honour, by shewing ju≈øt Indignation again≈øt that Trea≈øonable Attempt, which was then in≈øolently made again≈øt his Crowne & Dignity, in reading publickly, & with great formality, the Prince of Orange's Declaration.Rebellious paper mention'd in this & former letters; Tho every man, who was not a mere Ideote, mu≈øt comprehend, that that very Act countenanced was in effect the pulling up the ≈øluce, & letting in a Stream of Rebellion to overflow the whole County.

This was, I declare, to me a mighty exerci≈øe of Patience, & did among other Pre≈øsures, which po≈øsibly contributed much to my crazy condition la≈øt Winter, heavily afflict me. But when I look farther, & at this day, regard the State Eccle≈øi≈øia≈øtick of the whole County, & di≈øcover but three of all my Brethren of the Clergy through the whole Bishoprick of Durham (as I am made beleive by Report) who have had either the Integrity, or Courage, to ≈øtand their Ground, again≈øt a new & unlawfull Oath of Allegiance to a Prince, ≈øet up by the abhorr'd treachery, & unheard of Ingratitude, of the People [Subjects] who have no authority, in our anciently Hereditary Realm, to di≈øpo≈øe of the Crown, I am above mea≈øure a≈øtonish'd & overwhelmed with greif. Which greif is unexpre≈øsibly augmented, when I con≈øider that the members of that Body, or Community whereof I have the honour to be Head, have incurr'd the ≈øame Guilt. And tho≈øe Eminent Per≈øons, which, as Salt, by their Examples‚ñ™, ought to have ≈øea≈øoned the whole Dioce≈øs, are rendred uncapable to reprove their Inferiours, & reprehend the ≈øins of the Times.

Alas! if Re≈øi≈øtance of the higher powers, be, by ≈øome Moderne Divines & Di≈øtinctions, refin'd into a Vertue, is Perjury no ≈øin? If the Sacred Authority of our Earthly God (the ≈øtile in Sripture allow'd to a Lavvfull Soveraigne) be fallen into ≈øuch deplorable contempt among Subjects, that there is little Regard given either to their Promi≈øes, or Commands, is the Maje≈øty of the God of Heaven become ≈øo mean & cheap, that men, nay Divines, dare cancell the Obligation of an Oath? And the calling God to witne≈øs the truth of what we promi≈øe become void, & of no effect, as ≈øoon as our Intere≈øt tempt us to break it? If ≈øo, then farewell all Religion, nay Conver≈øation and Commerce among men. If the Bonds of a Sacred Oath are not ≈øufficient to hold men, ≈øurely nothing can.

The Evills & Mischiefs, which mu≈øt, unavoidably, attend a ≈øin ≈øo univer≈øally committed through the Kingdome, even by the Leaders & Guides of Chri≈øt's Flock, are more & greater than it is po≈øsible for any to conceive or fore≈øee.

Such a Notorious Contradiction of your own pa≈øt Preaching & Practice, mu≈øt, I fear, render you very cheap among≈øt tho≈øe People, which you have drawn into a Snare by a very ≈øinfull Example, & who have too much ≈øen≈øe not to di≈øcern the illne≈øs thereof, tho they want Courage to re≈øi≈øt it.

I am ≈øorry that the nece≈øsity which I am put to of delivering my Soule, con≈øtreins me here to declare thus much, and that you have very often, in my Pre≈øence, preach'd fal≈øe Doctrine, if your pre≈øent Proceedings & Compliances are ju≈øtifiable.

It's now a more ≈øea≈øonable time than it was a Preachers in the Cathedrall Church of Durham, as vvel as el≈øevvhere, began to Caution their hearers again≈øt implicite Obedience, vvhereby they did, at that time, meane all Complian ‚Ä¢ s vvith K. I. Iames. 2. year agoe for us Eccle≈øia≈øticks, who cannot swallow implicite Faith, to teach our Hearers to beware of implicite Obedience. If it were dreadfull & dangerous while we liv'd under a gratious Prince of an undoubted Title, who≈øe exce≈øsive Goodne≈øs & Forwardne≈øs to rely on his Subjects hath prov'd his Ruine, is it become otherwi≈øe under the Government of a Prince, who hath by Violence wre≈øted a Crown from the very Father of his own Prince≈øs, & his own near Relation? who by ≈øuch an act of unparaleld Inju≈øtice, & inexcu≈øable, & palpable, defect of Veracity, (in having at his fir≈øt Entrance gro≈øsly contradicted his own Declaration) gives more ju≈øt Grounds, than both his Uncles, or his Grandfather ever did, of Jealousy &
Fear, & to conclude that he intends to Rule as he Conquer'd the Kingdome, propo≈øing to him≈øelfe no other motives, in his future Government, than he did in his fir≈øt Inva≈øion. And what they were it will be needle≈øs to recite to any but tho≈øe, who were, during the months of Oct: & Nov: la≈øt, fa≈øt a sleep. And what will become then of our Religion, Libertyes, & Lavvs, it will be easy enough to devine.
O Fortunatos nimium bona ≈øi ≈øua norint &c.

The Review of our pa≈øt Felicity, tho≈øe very Ble≈øsings we enjoy'd, and ≈øadly overlook'd, during the Reigne of our pre≈øent Soveraigne, mu≈øt needs greivously torment our Hearts; & give us occa≈øion of pining away with ju≈øt vexation & anger at out ≈øelves. Since it is not po≈øsible now for us, in all humane apprehen≈øion, to ≈øwimme back to ≈øuch our [sottishly neglected & lo≈øt] Happine≈øs, but through that ≈øea of blood, which Tyrants & U≈øurpers commonly shed, in pro≈øecuting & accomplishing their Machiavellian De≈øignes. And it is matter of no ≈ømall moment for men, e≈øpecially Churchmen, to examine thoroughly, & impartially‚ñ™ how much of the Guilt will lye at their own Doores. As a great mea≈øure thereof mu≈øt, it is without all Di≈øpute, re≈øt at the door of every one, who hath knovvingly and vvillfully contributed to the Fall & Banishment of his Lawfull Prince, whereby he is put under a Nece≈øsity, out of Ju≈øtice to his ≈øon, to recover his own by the Sword, which by Force & Violence, as well as the abhorr'd Treachery of his own Subjects, were taken from him.

And I do be≈øeech You to be a≈øsur'd, that in now recommending to You (whom God hath plac'd under my Authority) ≈øo Sea≈øonable, & nece≈ø≈øary a Task as this ≈øort of SELFE-EXAMINATION, I do manife≈øt that I am (as I have done often in other matters) your faithfull Friend, as well as,

div.head: To the Clergy of the Archdeaconry of Durham.
div.p: Among the many applications, which, upon my withdrawing, and leaving the Nation, I have been oblig'd, out of common decency as well as good con≈øcience, (con≈øidering the publickne≈øs of my circum≈øtances,) to make to my Relations, Naturall & Spirituall, I might, without cen≈øure, or blame, omit all Laborious penning down of my thoughts for You, the Clergy of my Archdeaconry, having for more than twenty years together, with the greate≈øt indu≈øtry & be≈øt zeal I was able, from year to year, by word & letter, & ≈øometimes in Print, not only incited you at my Vi≈øitations, faithfully & diligently to execute your offices; but plainly & fully deliver'd my ≈øoule, at my la≈øt, & more memorable, Vi≈øitation, on the 15: of the never to be forgotten month of Nov: 1688 (ten dayes after our late [Dutch-Prote≈øtant] Gunpowder-Trea≈øon) Brotherly advi≈øing, nay earnestly pre≈øsing, you, to ≈øtand the Te≈øt in that great day of tryall, that you might not have lo≈øt either the honour or reward of Confe≈øsors for a Righteous Cau≈øe; in A≈øserting whereof, I am willing (and re≈øolve by Gods grace) to ≈øacrifice my life, as I have done my Revenue; if the wi≈øe God should thinke fitt to call me to the one, as he hath done to the other.

To demon≈øtrate undeniably to your ≈øelves, & all that hear'd
me that day, that I was not, among all my weakne≈øses, afraid or ashamed to owne my pa≈øt life & Doctrine, & to compleat the Office of a Vi≈øitor, as hone≈øtly & heartily as I began, I cho≈øe, you may remember, to lay before you the cheife heads of all the Good Coun≈øell & Advice, which I had given you at the former Conventions of the Clergy of my Jurisdiction, for four years together; even the four la≈øt extraordinary years, that is to ≈øay, ever ≈øince his gratious Maje≈øtie, our Liege Lord & Soverigne King Iames the 2:, mounted his Throne; tho I had too much rea≈øon, then to apprehend, by your long neglect thereof, & running counter to the principles & practice of your Archdeacon, it would badly ≈øuite with your palates, which at that time, to my greife, appear'd, & ≈øince, without all di≈øpute‚ñ™ are found, not only vitiated, but poi≈øon'd, by the Leaven & Magick of the Age.

It was ever my hopes, that his Maje≈øtie's Loyall County of Durham (the appellation which my gracious Ma≈øter King Charles the 2: was wont, as I have often minded You, to afford Us) would have re≈øi≈øted longer than any Dioce≈øs in England, by vertue of the Good Government which was very ≈øea≈øonably, & more effectually than el≈øe where, therein ≈øet on foot at his joyfull Re≈øtauration.

How little prevalent, & un≈øucce≈øsfull ≈øoever my poor & weak endeavours prov'd towards your e≈øtablishment, I could not imagine, that the Clergy of the Bishoprick of Durham, could have ≈øo ≈øoon forgotten (much le≈øs have fru≈øtrated) the precepts, & Example, given them, by ≈øo great a Bishop Co≈øins.Confe≈ø≈øor, and ≈øtout Champion of the old orthodox Church of England, as had happily reviv'd good order, & conformity to the Churche's Rules among them.

But ≈øince we find, by ≈øad experience, that it is ≈øo, & that even the very Leaders have apo≈øtatiz'd, from their Duty to God and the King, It becomes me (who dare not follow their Example) to do all that I can, to prevent the People of my Archdeaconry, from being ≈øeduced thereby.

You know, I have labour'd faithfully, & with zeale more than ordinary, to a≈øsert the King's cau≈øe from the yeare 1678 (through all the Combu≈øtions occa≈øion'd by an Infamous Impo≈øtor,) home to the Dutch Inva≈øion, & at that very time, even on the 15 of
Nov. 1688, brought all the whole≈øome advice which I had given at ≈øeverall Vi≈øitations, to your view in one Addre≈øs, (as before mention'd,) which I have printed for your farther edification, & my own ju≈øtification. And in the next place, I knew of nothing better that I could do, than to preach to you by my example, in leaving my Station, & my Revenue, (when I could not be permitted longer to discharge a good con≈øcience,) rather than involve my ≈øelfe, in the guilt of an u≈øurpation. Which act of mine, how grealy ≈øoever it may have been cen≈øur'd, I e≈øteem as the be≈øt ≈øermon I ever preach'd in my life, the reflection on which affords much comfort to my ≈øoule; ≈øince thereby I clear'd my ≈øelfe from the guilt of renouncing my Allegiance, as the generality have done, which will prove an eternall blot to the Nation, not excepting the Clergy of the Church of England.

Tis too late, now to give you Cautions again≈øt Perjury, or to ≈øett before your eyes, how much more heinous it is in a Prie≈øt, than in a Lay man, becau≈øe the greate≈øt part of you allready have swallow'd a new oath to an U≈øurper. And to informe you in the obligation that lyes on you, to repent of, rather than keep the oath you have taken, is to conclude you (what I ought not to do) not only bad Chri≈øtians, but very weak Divines.

There is no man that under≈øtands any thing of Religion, but knows that a rash oath only obliges to Repentance; whereof that there might be ≈øome MEET AND WORTHY FRUITS brought forth among the Clergy of my Jurisdiction, would prove to me great matter of Con≈øolation; & if it were done very ≈øpeedily, it would be a great extenuation of their crime, & afford good ground to hope, they were overborne with the Boi≈øterou≈øne≈øs of a Violent Sorme, rather than did willfully plunge them≈øelves, in ≈øo horrid a guilt.

Let not the fear of loo≈øing your po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, (which I thank God has not prevail'd on me) tempt you to lye, one moment, under ≈øo in≈øupportable a load. The enjoyments of your Livings will be ≈øadly purchas'd, by the increa≈øe of ≈øo enormous an Impiety. And there will be a lamentable Precedent left to your flocks, if You, the Pa≈øtours, have not ≈øufficient ≈øincerity to make a ≈øpeedy Confe≈øsion of your ≈øin, & courage enough publickly to owne the ≈øame by giving glory to God & taking shame unto your≈øelves. There
can be no more effectuall way to redeem your own honour than by re≈øtoring Gods. Nothing contributed ≈øo much to the glory of St. Augu≈øtin as his Confe≈øsions, & Retractations, & con≈øequently nothing can be more to your's, than to betake your ≈øelves to this E≈øsential part of Repentance, I mean the Confe≈øsion of your Crime, whereby you have ≈øcandaliz'd your flocks.

You that have taken an unlawfull oath to ≈øave your Benefices, have thereby put your ≈øelves under a greater nece≈øsity of parting with them, or retaining your guilt. For nothing lefs, than ≈øo, ≈øeems to be a ≈øufficient evidence of ‚Ä¢ your ≈øincerity. God hath ≈øo ordered it, by his divine providence, that a ≈øinner alwayes mi≈øses of his aim. Tho≈øe that betake them≈øelves to unlawfull cour≈øes, to ≈øave their lives or e≈øtates, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily for≈øake them, & enter on ≈øuch as are diametrically contrary to the former, or loo≈øe their ≈øoules, which are infinitely more valuable than both. Repentance ought to be e≈øteem'd by every ordinary Chri≈øtian a Returning from ≈øin, yea ≈øuch a Returning as requires the treading out the very ≈øtepps, which the ≈øinner made in order to the commi≈ø≈øion of it. And ≈øurely, then, what ≈øoever is binding in the Di≈øciple, mu≈øt be much more obligatory in the ≈øpirituall Guide.

But I shall not dive too far into particulars, & chalk out the exact method, & manner hovv you shall make reparation, for the wrong which You have done, by ≈øubmitting to an U≈øurper, both to the King & Church of England. I have rea≈øon to beleive, that all of you know your duty well enough, & many I am ≈øure, better than I can in≈øtruct you; ≈øince the Prerogative of the King, Pa≈øsive-obedtence & Non-re≈øi≈øtance were preach'd up with more zeal, by you in the Bishoprick of Durham, than they were by others in any Dioce≈øs in England. Where Conformity to the orders of the Church, & Execution of other Laws of the Land, were ≈øo well practis'd (tho not as they ought to have been) that the BISHOPRICK which anciently was ≈øtil'd the Land of Prei≈øts, was generaly reputed the Seat of thorough-Conformi≈øts.

You on the place of acting, mu≈øt ≈øee, more clearly than I can, at this di≈øtance, (tho your eyes have been in a great mea≈øure blinded by the ≈ømoak of a Rebellion) the fitte≈øt manner & opportunities of making ≈øatisfaction for your egregious Apo≈øtacy.

I shall therefore, rather than pre≈øcribe the means, mind you of your indi≈øpen≈øable obligation to do the thing, & ≈øo redeem your honour, & redre≈øs the ≈øcandall you have given, to the increa≈øe of your own ≈øin, & the un≈øpeakable greife of my ≈øoule; who did faithfully labour to make every one committed to my charge, ≈øuch as God hath given me grace to approve my ≈øelfe; even an unalterable Loyall Subject to King Iames the ≈øecond, as well as ≈øo legitimate a ≈øon of the Church of England, as can never be per≈øwaded, that it can be for her Intre≈øt to contradict her Doctrine; Which, as I have hitherto profe≈øt, & held fa≈øt amid≈øt all the bla≈øts of Temptation, (from what ever point of the Compa≈øs they have blowne) I am re≈øolv'd by the Divine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to practi≈øe unto the end; in ≈øpight of the mo≈øt prevalent examples, or malicious cen≈øures, u≈øed now as arguments, or engins, to overthrow mee.

That ≈øuch a Generall neglect of Church-Order among the Clergy, through the Nation, (as I long, and loudly complain'd of, and warn'd you again≈øt,) should be attended on by ≈øo fatall an Y≈ø≈øue, as an Vniver≈øall Defection, should not be a thing perfectly new to You, to whom I addre≈øs my ≈øelfe, ≈øince you, your≈øelves, can be my wittne≈øses, that I have often faithfully foretold, that an Univer≈øall Semi-conformity would end in as Univer≈øall Semi-Allegiance: & would God we had not found, by lamentable experience, that it had done much more, by producing that degenerate offspring, who have not only imbrew'd their hands, in ≈øo horrid a crime, as the dethroning their lavvfull Soveraigne, but like Vipers have, in a manner, eaten out their very Mother's Bovvells.

I do not doubt but that Almighty God hath, by this time, brought to your memory ≈øome of tho≈øe ≈øea≈øonable cautions & memento's, which I have plainly lay'd before You, in the publick di≈øcharge of my Archidiaconall office, with ≈øome greater force & effect on your ≈øpirits, than they had at their fir≈øt delivery. I cannot have ≈øuch prejudiciall thoughts of you, as to imagine otherwi≈øe, ≈øince Divine Providence led me, often, to ≈øuch ≈øuitable Topicks, as might have prevented, by God's ble≈øsing, (had they been generally in≈øi≈øted on by all tho≈øe who had Eccle≈øia≈øticall Juri≈ødiction, and not been rejected by the people,) much of our pre≈øent mi≈øery; the ill effects of which are like to be felt by the
≈øucceeding generation; tho we should be ble≈øs'd, to morrow, with ≈øuch unde≈øerv'd felicity, as all good Chri≈øtians long for, I mean the ≈øpeedy Re≈øtauration of our Soveraigne, Religion, Liberties and Lavvs.

If any of my Brethren prove not only unkind, but ≈øo unju≈øt as to deny, what I affirme, in reference to the ≈øea≈øonable advice which I did, from time to time, recommend to them, the papers which I have by me, containing the heads of my Vi≈øitation-Di≈øcour≈øes, which had better luck than ≈øome of my money & plate, in e≈øcaping the hands of the Rabble, who treated me roughly enough, in my fir≈øt-flight from Durham, can te≈øtify for me, & demon≈øtrate to the mo≈øt malicious of my Contemners or Oppo≈øers, that I was, during my ≈øtation among you no, unfaith≈øull & negligent, tho vveak & un≈øucce≈øsfull, Vi≈øitor.

There are many things I have ≈øaid, that I am ≈øure you cannot ea≈øily forget, which, tho they had not their fir≈øt de≈øign'd effect on you, may con≈øequently de≈øerve ≈øome of your con≈øideration. It would be very gratefull to me, to be inform'd that I am not mi≈øtaken in this particular, but that my pa≈øt per≈øwa≈øions to do your duty, may opperate, as good coun≈øell hath often done, in length of time & at a great di≈øtance.

Some de≈øireable fruit, in the conclu≈øion, (which I don't di≈øpair of) from tho≈øe numerous young plants, that I had, for 26 years together, with great care & pains, vigilantly water'd, will, amid≈øt all the mortification I undergoe, revive my ≈øoule, & compen≈øate, in ≈øome mea≈øure, for that lamentable crop which I have hitherto reap'd, from the ≈øeed I have ≈øown, having met withall, at leaving my ≈øtation, little other return of my labours, than Almighty God did, E≈øaie the 5:. where, after the Heavenly Hu≈øbandman had dig'd & dre≈øs'd his vinyard, & graciously expected, it should have brought forth grapes, it brought forth, (as our's & other Dioce≈øses have done,) vvilde grapes, which mu≈øt be acknowledg'd, after ≈øuch heavenly Cultivation, a wretched Retribution.
Heartily praying that the Allmighty would ≈øtrengthen tho≈øe few who ≈øtand, and rai≈øe up all who are fallen, I commend my whole jurisdiction to Gods Ble≈øsing, & re≈øt
