div.head: POSTCRIPT.
div.p: HAving in the preceding letter omitted to reply to one cen≈øure, whereto I am lea≈øt willing to an≈øwer (being more de≈øirous to Ju≈øtify my ≈øelfe than accu≈øe my Brethrrn) I cannot forbeare to take notice thereof in a Po≈øt≈øcript. I meane, that of Singularity; to ‚Ä¢ it, that my being the only dignified Clergyman of the Church of England, that doth, at pre≈øent, attend his Ma≈øter in his Exile, ought to make mee Su≈øpect my Zeale. This is the Judgement of my Enimies, that is to ≈øay, of the COMPLIERS with the U≈øurpation in England. But if any of them, or others, twitt mee with Singularity at this time, I shall be the le≈øs ≈øurprized therewith; ≈øince the Non-Compliance of the Clergy, under my Authority, in that ≈øtrict Order and Conformity, which I ever thought my ≈øelfe obliged to practi≈øe (and did ob≈øerve, I thank God, in ≈øuch a degree as to evince the practicablene≈øs of tho≈øe duties, which ≈øome men's ‚Ä¢ loth repre≈øented impo≈ø≈øible) hath render'd mee ≈øo, for neare 30 yeares together. And that I have been ≈øo, I meane not di≈øcouraged to keep up, as clo≈øe as I could, to the Church's Rules (tho I have wanted the Example, & Company of any right and thorough-paced Conformi≈øt ≈øince the decea≈øe of my ever honour'd Brother, Archdeacon Ba≈øire) is at this Juncture no di≈øcomfort to mee. For if God had not endowed mee with Grace, and Re≈øolution to have perform'd my Duty, in a Time of PEACE & QUIET, I should never have been enabled to do it in a Time of Trouble; and to With≈øtand that Raging Torrent which hath over-flowne our Church and ≈øtate.

div.head: A Letter to Mr. Iames Hope Curate of the Parish of Ea≈øington, & Mr. Wm. Kingford Curate of the Parish of Sedgefield, in the Bishoprick of Durham, ≈øub≈øtituted by Dr. Granville to ≈øerve the afore≈øaid Cures.
div.p: Amid≈øt all the mortifications & exerci≈øes of Patience, which have been occa≈øion'd to me, by the late Revolution of affairs in Church & State, & more particularly by the Defection of the Clergy of my own Jurisdiction, nothing has created ≈øo much di≈øquiet, & ≈øo la≈øting a di≈øturbance to my mind, as that there should happen any ≈øcandalous failure in either of you, my more peculiar Deputies, & fellow Labourers in the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt.

Tho the members of that Community whereof I am Head, together with the Clergy of my Archdeaconry, began to take different mea≈øures from mee, which gave mee too ju≈øt grounds to fear that they would, (as they afterwards did,) Bovv dovvn to Baal, in shaking off their Allegiance to their Leige Lord and Soveraigne, & ≈øubmit to an U≈øurper, yet I did comfort my ≈øelfe with ≈øtrong hopes, that you, my immediate Supporters,
would ≈øtick by me, & endeavour to the uttermo≈øt of your powers to uphold me (again≈øt the violence of that ≈øtorme which threatned‚ñ™) notwith≈øtanding our different ≈øentiments, & apprehen≈øions touching ≈øome matters in relation to the tran≈øactions of the year pa≈øt. But, after all tho≈øe my Expectations, that one of my Crutches (give me leave ≈øo to terme you ≈øince I did ≈øo e≈øteem you) should break, in a time of Danger & Difficulty, is to me great ground of greife & trouble.

That about the begining of the year 1688, I & you should ≈øometimes differ in our opinion of things, (when there began to bean unhappy Divi≈øion among the Clergy, not exceptting the very Fathers of the Church of England,) afforded no great matter of wonder or admiration, But in the month of December following, when all eyes were (or ought to be) open'd, by a real unnaturall Inva≈øion, & ≈øaw all the ha≈øte imaginable made violently to u≈øurp the Crown, by the Dethroning of a Lawfull & gracious Prince, ≈øtrikes me with great a≈øtonishment; e≈øpecially con≈øidering my earne≈øt & unwearied endeavours, by the utmo≈øt conde≈øcention & rea≈øonings, to informe you of the ill de≈øignes carried on (which I had the good luck you mu≈øt now acknowledge to fore≈øee better than your ≈øelves) again≈øt the Church as well as King of England; that one of you, I ≈øay, (God be prais'd it is not both) with whom I had taken ≈øo much pains to keep ≈øteddy, should after ≈øo plain a Di≈øcovery of the bottome of ill men's intrieges, to involve the Nation in that deplorable mi≈øery under which it doth at pre≈øent groane, should, I ≈øay, not only totter, but at la≈øt fall into ≈øo abhorr'd a Crime as Perjury, doth pierce my very ≈øoule to think on't; ≈øince by ≈øuch ill example there is an irreparable injury done to my Flock, & to the young Clergy of my Jurisdiction, like to be influenc'd by the Example of the Archdeacon's Curate, who till this late Epidemick Apo≈øtacy had been very exemplary in keeping up good order & Di≈øcipline, according to the good old right principles of tho≈øe venerable Bp. Gunning Bp. Co≈øins.Prelates, under whom, by God's Providence, I had my education.

I cannot reflect on ≈øo unpardonable a Breach of Tru≈øt, tho never ≈øo much varnish'd over, with the fal≈øe paint now vented in the Kingdome, without ≈øore indignation; nor cea≈øe to charge the
guilt of ≈øo great a ≈øin upon you, my Repre≈øentative in my Parish of Sedgefield, (to whom I now ≈øingly ≈øpeak) who have committed the ≈øame with many high Aggravations, as the following particulars will make appeare.

Fir≈øt you being a Per≈øon, that was happyly train'd up not only in a [hitherto ever] Cornvval. loyall County, & more particularly in a Kilkhampton. Parish, where there had been much ≈øeed ≈øown, which ought to have brought forth other grain, but under a The-Granvilles. Family who≈øe Loyalty till the fatall month of Nov. 1688 was never blemish'd with the lea≈øt ≈øtaine.

In the next place after a loyall Education in the Univer≈øity, & the happyne≈øs to e≈øcape, by God's ble≈øsing, tho≈øe dangerous rocks, on which youth there mo≈øt commonly ≈øplit, (to witt: Corruption in principles or moralls,) were ≈øea≈øonably tran≈øplanted into the Curacy of a very con≈øiderable Parish in Wor≈øtershier, where the Rector kept up exactly the Order of the Church of England; the ≈øtrickt practice whereof (however things have fallen out) was the mo≈øt likely means to have kept Clergy-men ≈øteddy, in ≈øuch a day of tryall & temptation as our pre≈øent mi≈øerable generation have liv'd to ≈øee.

Thirdly were, with much affection & hone≈øt intention, ≈øingl'd out, & pitcht on, by me (I having a great opinion of your Loyalty) to be my Co-adjutour, in Sedgefield.one of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Country Parishes of England, the burthen of which tru≈øt, as well as my great concern for the ≈øpirituall wellfare of that my flock, you ought to have learn'd, from the extraordinary zealous applications, which I us'd at fir≈øt coming to ≈øet you, & all along after to keep you, right, in my hone≈øt Particular notions of obedience to the orders of the Church, & of ≈øubjection to all ≈øorts of lawfull Authority. Which notions I am not ashamed to ≈øtile now particular, ≈øince the i≈øsu√´ of things proclaimes them to be right, as well as the oppo≈øers of them notoriou≈øly in the wrong, & mu≈øt be ≈øo acknowledg'd by all per≈øons, who are not unhappyly be≈ømear'd with the pre≈øent [religious] Rebellion of England, or blinded by the mi≈øt, or fumes of an un≈øupportable U≈øurpation.

La≈øtly had more rea≈øon than others to have re≈øi≈øted tho≈øe temptations, which overthrew the generality of the Clergy of the Dioce≈øs, ≈øince you had in one per≈øon your Rector's
Dean's, & Archdeacon's continuall example, in your eye, to the very la≈øt minute‚ñ™ to uphold you. Nay, moreover, had a pathetick letter written joyntly to your ≈øelfe‚ñ™ & your) Brother (directed to the Curates of Ea≈øington & Sedgefield from the Deanery, the very night of my Departure‚ñ™ which carrying with it my la≈øt & be≈øt advice & ≈øentiments, immediately before‚ñ™ I lanch'd forth into a kind of ≈øea of trouble, likely to attend that per≈øecuted righteous Cau≈øe, whereto I was re≈øolv'd to adhere, ought to have had as much force at Sedgefield, as it had at Ea≈øington, in in≈øpiring one, as it did the other to with≈øtand the Shock, which hath furiou≈øly overturn'd ≈øo many of the elder & ≈øtronger Clergy, both in the Cathedrall & Dioce≈øs, & ≈øcar'd them out of their Allegiance unto their Lawfull Prince, into ≈øubmi≈øsion to a Forrain U≈øurper.

The la≈øt words of a Dying man are u≈øually very powerfull with all his Relations. And ≈øurely the la≈øt exhortations of a Departing Vi≈øitor, in ≈øuch a manner, & for ≈øuch a cau≈øe, should have had the like effect‚ñ™ If my late example, as well as zeal, expre≈øs'd in my addre≈øs to the Clergy in my conclu≈øive Vi≈øitation [in the Church of St. Mary-le-Bow Nov. the 15 1688]‚ñ™ proved un≈øucce≈øsfull, & ineffectuall to per≈øwade the Rectors of the Parishes of my Jurisdiction, to e≈øpou≈øe the Cau≈øe of an oppre≈øs'd Prince & imitate an hone≈øt Leader, & faithfull Servant to the Crown, who was re≈øolv'd to ≈øacrifice all rather than de≈øert his Soveraigne in mi≈øery, Yet it ought not to be ≈øo contemptible with either of you, my own Cutates, as to be rejected; but should have ≈øtopp'd you in your Carreer, had you been bent to run, with never ≈øo much eagerne≈øs, into ≈ølavery under a Belgick yoke; nay ought to have been e≈øteem'd ≈øo forcible to ≈øuch immediate Dependants, as you, to whom I now ≈øpeak, that it should have been hardly po≈øsible for either of you to re≈øi≈øt it. And that either of you should, & date thus to rebuke me by your practice, & abandon all hopes & expectations of kindne≈øs from me, by betraying me (it de≈øerves no milder expre≈øsion) I look on as a high act of contempt, & receive with all tho≈øe re≈øentmens of Di≈øplea≈øure that are allowable in a Chri≈øtian.

I did not expect that both, or either of you, should have
immitated me, ≈øo far then as to have de≈øerted your Stations (tho I am per≈øwaded that my doing ≈øo was the be≈øt & wi≈øe≈øt action of my whole life) but if both of you, (rather than renounce your ≈øworn fidelity to King Iames, & ≈øwear Allegiance to an ambitious Prince, his ≈øon in law & Nephew, who had by fraud & force depos'd his Uncle, nay Father) had been forced ≈øo to do, & de≈øert the Nation, (as I did,) as well a my Floks committed to your Care, it would have been a thing very edifying, & gratefull unto me, & oblig'd mee to have taken care of you, & allow'd you, a share of what≈øoever‚ñ™ I had to ≈øupport me; not ≈øuffering you to want bread as long as I had it, which yee had no rea≈øon to ≈øu≈øpect that God's Providence, & a gracious Ma≈øter's kindne≈øs would deny me in the deepe≈øt adver≈øity abroad.

I am ≈øure that yee two, who have not only been long re≈øident in my hou≈øe & family, but often admitted into my clo≈øet, & ≈øometimes into my very bo≈øome, ought to have conceiv'd ≈øuch an opinion; & should have taken it for granted, by great experience of me, without any farther Declaration. Tho you had not ≈øuch particular & po≈øitive a≈ø≈øurances thereof, as I ≈øea≈øonably gave a certaine Divine (I much valued) to deliver him out of tho≈øe temptations, whereinto hee (being unhappily Metamorpho≈øed in another Region‚ñ™) did however willfully run him≈øelfe, to the Injury of his Con≈øcience, and dishonour of him≈øelfe & freinds.

You therefore (my lap≈øed A≈øsi≈øtant) whom I had drawn away from my native ≈øoile (hoping, that, as you have breathed the ≈øame air, you would always profe≈øs the ≈øame principles) to be my comfort & ≈øupport, in a remote part of the Nation, for the remainder of my life, do ≈øtrangely di≈øappoint my hopes, & are ≈øo much the more blame-worthy, ≈øince God Almighty did a≈øsi≈øt me (poor weak & unworthy Labourer in his Vinyard) with ≈øuch a happy fore-≈øight of matters, relating to the late unfortunate change in government, that I was in≈øtrume ‚Ä¢ tall in the bringing to the view of all tho≈øe, who related to me, ≈øuch a Pro≈øpect of the things (that did at that time portend ill, as well as future „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ might render a per≈øon ≈øtupid, who should di≈øpi≈øe, or „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

Your „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ who has done his part faithfully to di≈øcharge
his Tru≈øt in a criticall juncture, (& thereby has help'd to ≈øave the honour of the young Clergy under my Conduct,) will be willing‚ñ™ I know, to hear te≈øtimony‚ñ™ that I did, to my utmo≈øt, diligently discharge the part of a faithfull vvatchman‚ñ™ penning down my thoughts almo≈øt dayly, (u≈øing him ≈øometimes for an Amanuen≈øis,) to fortify all Per≈øons under my care, again≈øt the dangerous inveiglements of ill men, & the plau≈øible, rather than reall, arguments of deluded goodmen; who have, by their Reputation‚ñ™ contributed more to the pre≈øent ≈øad ≈øtate of things, (I mu≈øt take the liberty to tell them) than the more malicious ≈øinners, that did originally de≈øigne to trample on the Crown & Mytre.

And that I was no bad Progno≈øticatour, in the month of Augu≈øt 1688, you your-≈øelfe, & every body el≈øe, may without all contradiction be convinced, by a coppy of a Paper which I penn'd at Durham, the 27 of the afore≈øaid month, according to my u≈øuall manner of dictating to one of my Clerks, in my chamber, at my upri≈øing. Which Paper only contains ≈øome floating thoughts of my brain, but relating to mattets of ≈øo great importance, as did, according to its title, portend very fatally to the Government & Church of England. And it being the only sheet of ≈øome hundreds, (penn'd in ≈øuch manner & much to the ≈øame purpo≈øe,) that I did by great accident bring away with me, I shall here, to this my letter, annex a printed Coppy thereof; which will, at lea≈øt, demon≈øtrate, to all who shall ≈øeriously con≈øider it, that I gave a better gue≈øs, how things would go, than any of my Cen≈øurers or Oppo≈øers, who thought them ≈øelves greater Politicians, but have ≈øo much faild in their Politicks, that they (as well as others) are by this time, I ≈øuppo≈øe, convinced how their zeale, which run ≈øo Counter to mine, was very prepo≈øterous: viz, That the irregular & unaccountable method they took, to be deliver'd from Popery and Arbitrary Power, hath brought the whole Kingdome, ab≈øolutely under the one, and in greater danger, than ever it was, of the other.

And that I may do all that in me lyes to clear my ≈øelfe, both in the ≈øight of God & man, from being the lea≈øt ways acce≈øsary to the horrid guilt, many, who have depended on me in my parishes, or el≈øe where, have contracted, by forsaking our
Churche's Doctrine, & the good Rules which I have ≈øet them, I shall embrace this occa≈øion to add another paper to the former, containing the Order & Directions which I required ≈øtrictly to be ob≈øerv'd in my parishes, re≈øpectively, which, will be ≈øufficient to evince, that I did hone≈øtly, tho imperfectly, endeavour to have prevented the Apo≈øtacy of any committed to my charge; Always looking on a ≈øtrict ob≈øervation of the Di≈øcipline & Rubricks of the Church, as the be≈øt means, by Gods ble≈øsing, to have ≈øtrengthen'd them again≈øt tho≈øe temptations that have, at la≈øt, overcome them, for which I now begin to value my ≈øelfe.

And a ≈øerious con≈øideration of this Method enjoyn'd in my Parishes, added to the manner of my parting with my Brethren of the Cathedrall, & Clergy of my Archdeaconry, ≈øet forth in tho≈øe Fare-vvell-Di≈øcour≈øes I made to them, in the months of Nov ‚Ä¢ & December 1688, will ≈øufficiently proclaime, to all unbia≈øs'd per≈øons, that I was, at lea≈øt, an Hone≈øt man, ≈øo far, in all my capacities, as to have no fingar at all in the Invitation of a Forreigne povver, & the unnaturall Inva≈øion which attended thereon, which I am de≈øirous should remaine to Po≈øterity upon Record.

If the publication of ≈øuch papers, as were never de≈øign'd for the pre≈øs, ≈øeem to ≈øavour any thing of vanity, & cau≈øe to beleive, that I glory in having been more regular‚ñ™ & con≈øtant, in my duty, than the generality of my Brethren, let them give a Loo≈øer leave to ≈øpeake, and de≈øire them to remember, & con≈øider, that the Apo≈øtle St. Paul him≈øelfe was compell'd to boa≈øt, in a le≈øs day of temptation than the fifth of November 1688, which did, in a manner, blow up the foundations of three Kingdoms.

I confe≈øs that I do glory with the B. Apo≈øtle, but it is, as he did, in my vveakne≈øs, & the grace that Almighty God has manife≈øted therein, carrying me through the manifold temptations which have prevailed over my Stronger Brethren. I do ble≈øs & prai≈øe God's holy name, & will do it, by his a≈øsi≈øtance, for ever & ever, that he did endow me with re≈øolution to ≈øtick clo≈øe to all the Churches Rules & Orders, (whereto I gave my a≈øsent & con≈øent at my fir≈øt entrance into the mini≈øterial function in the year 1661) without governing my ≈øelfe by example, of any Clergy, high or low, in the citty or in the country: Living
by the example of tho≈øe who contradicted their excellent Rule, being a ≈øort of Complai≈øance which, I ble≈øs God's holy name‚ñ™ I have never been guilty of, tho it has been, God know‚ñ™s, too frequent among my Brethren, and prov'd fatall to the poor church of England.

To take no comfort & ≈øatisfaction in my owne innocency, (which God has in a manner miraculou≈øly pre≈øerv'd, when he has ≈øuffer'd ≈øuch a multitude of abler Divines to faile, who were furnish'd with greater qualifications to have borne vvittne≈øs to his truth,) I should look on as an act of meane≈øs of ≈øpirit, ≈øavouring more of ≈øpirituall ingratitude than true humility, who de≈øire rather to be really thankfull & humble than appear either.

Let my cen≈øurers be contented with my revenue, which I have left to their mercy, (choo≈øing to do ≈øo rather than betray my con≈øcience,) without depriving me of that precious ointment, & more valuable trea≈øure, a good name, which I shall, in ≈øpight of all my enemys, endeavour, by the aid of Gods holy ≈øpirit, to ≈øecure my title to, in approving my ≈øelfe, to the very end, as I have hitherto as much as in me lay, a Genuine ≈øon of the Church, & Loyall ≈øubject to the Crown of England.

If the pre≈øent Generation, who favour none with their good opinion but tho≈øe who concurr to the ≈øupport of the pre≈øent Fabrick in England, will not allow me the afore≈øaid ≈øatisfaction, but load me with obloquy or contempt, (& one of the≈øe Fates I expect from the North where ≈øo few have followed my example,) there remains, yet, one thing, that I am ≈øure they are not able to deprive me of; I mean the internall Peace and Quiet of my con≈øcience, which I have enjoy'd ≈øince I was driven from my Station (to Heavens eternall prai≈øe I ≈øpeak it) in a more plentifull mea≈øure than ever I did heretofore, when I was in the actuall po≈øse≈øsion of ≈øome of the be≈øt preferments, of their kind, in England. This ≈øupports me under my pre≈øent pre≈øsures, and will be continued unto me, I tru≈øt in God, while I continue, as I pray I may, faithfull to my mother the Church, & unalterably obedient to the father of my Country.

Of the≈øe things I require you, to a≈øsure the flocks I have committed to your charge (whom I do not faile to commend unto
God in my con≈øtant prayers, &) to whom, be≈øides my devotions, I have nothing to bequeathe but vvhol≈øome coun≈øell & a good example. And ≈øince I have no way left to convey unto them the fir≈øt, but by writing (& that with great difficulty too) not to deprive them of the latter is become a duty of higher obligation.

Example is often more prevalent than precept. Whether the wi≈øe God will render mine ≈øo unto my people, He alone knows, & it depends on his good plea≈øure. Sure I am, that when I departed from my Cures, with a ≈øorrowfull heart, I did conceive it the be≈øt way left me to preach unto them, by putting into actual practice that peculiar ≈øort of Religion & Loyalty (to u≈øe the very phra≈øe of ≈øome of my cen≈øurers) which I had ever taught to others, & wherein I did ince≈øsantly labour to e≈øtablish you, (as before rehears'd,) again≈øt the then fashionable [up≈øtart] Divinity, & Allegiance of the Age; & Whereto I should not give this, nor the former epithet in the beginning of this letter, (my religion & loyalty, let men call them what they plea≈øe, being no other, I ble≈øs God, than the naturall Re≈øult of the pure uncorrupted Doctrine of the right Genuine Church of England) had they not been, you know, to my reproach often ≈øo ≈øtiled, by that Generation of Semi-conformi≈øts & Loyali≈øts, who could then but halfe comply with the rea≈øonnable demands of a Lawfull Prince, but can now wholy conforme to the will of an U≈øurper.

I recommend you both, with all my sheep, to Almighty God's mercy & direction, praying with all fervency to our Heavenly Father in the Churche's Littany [part of my dayly devotions as I ≈øuppo≈øe it likewi≈øe is of the ≈ømall number of Othodox Clergy men in the nation] That it may plea≈øe God to ≈øtrengthen ≈øuch as do ≈øtand, to comfort & helpe the vveak-hearted, to rai≈øe up them that fall, & finally to beat dovvn Satan under our feet. Applying it more e≈øpecially to the ca≈øe of you my Sub≈øtitutes, who are unhappyly divided, to my un≈øpeakable trouble, in your principles & practices, which renders this my pre≈øent way of application, very difficult to me, ≈øince it is not ea≈øy in one joyntaddre≈øs, at the ≈øame time, to prai≈øe & di≈øprai≈øe (according to the de≈øigne of this paper) you to whom I write.

You then (to conclude) who have continued faithfull in your Tru≈øts, & di≈øcharg'd your Con≈øcience, I do (as the be≈øt reward you can for a ‚Ä¢ hile expect) Prai≈øe & pray for; earne≈øtly be≈øeeching God to ≈øtrengthen you dayly, & to carry you through the remaining difficulties, you shall meet witthall. And mu≈øt Blame (tho I pitty) you that are fallen, conjuring you to reflect on what you have done, and de≈øiring you to be a≈øsur'd, that I can never have any complacency in your ≈øervices, till you bring forth undeniable fruits of Repentance. Hoping that my cen≈øures of one, as well as prai≈øes of the other, will have that kindly operation on your ≈øoules which I de≈øigne, I do, with much chri≈øtian charity & compa≈øsion, ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelfe‚ñ™

closer.signed: Your very lov: Brother in CHRIST JESUS, DENIS GRANVILLE.

argument.p: COPY of a Paper mention'd in the foregoing pag. 38. and penn'd at Durham, by the Authour, Aug. 27‚ñ™ 1688, by vvay of reflection on the, then, Di≈ømal Progno≈øtiks of the Times.

div.head: Things vvhich portend very fatally to the Government and Church of England.
div.p: 1. AN Vniver≈øall Aptitude in men to receive, multiply, and magnify Fears and Iealou≈øies of the King.
2. The generality of the ≈øubjects of England (contrary to the Rule of Charity) putting the vvor≈øt Con≈øtruction on the De≈øigns and Actings of their SOVERAIGNE.

3. Mens di≈øcovering by their prepo≈øterous cour≈øes (tho hey dare not speak it vvith their mouthes) that they think their Allegiance to the King (becau≈øe of a different Religion) not the ≈øame that it vvould be to a Prote≈øtant Prince
4. An indu≈øtrious endeavour, for a long time, throughout the land, to alienate the ≈øubjects Affection from their Soveraigne.

5. The Spirit of Popularity, at pre≈øent, ≈øo univer≈øally reigning, as to overthrovv many Hone≈øt & Good men, vvho ≈øeem afraid, any longer to do their Duty to the King, and act according to their Principles, for fear of the Mobile.

6. An extraordinary forvvardne≈øs, both in Clergy as vvell as Gentry, to di≈øpute, and rudely to contend vvith their Prince; nay in≈øoleutly to in≈øult over him upon the lea≈øt ≈øucce≈øs, made too apparent by the I≈øsue of the late Triall of the Bishops, in VVe≈øtmun≈øter Hall.
7. The itch of di≈øputation infinitely prevailing, in this age, above the ≈øpirit of Divine Charity & true Devotion, men relying too much on their Arguments & too little on their Prayers.

8. Men being novv agitated more than ever by an intemperate zeale again≈øt Popery, as heretofore again≈øt Fanatici≈øme, shevving much
more Aver≈øion to their Adver≈øary's, than love to their ovvn Religion.

9. Mo≈øt men, even Divines, manefe≈øting an exce≈øsive fear that Popery vvill come in, and yet all the vvhile neglect to betake them≈øelves to the mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured means to keep it out; to vvit, Amendment of life, and exact conformity to the CHURCHES RULES, and training up the young Generation by the due exerci≈øe of Catechi≈øme.
10. Too many flying to unju≈øtifiable means to pre≈øerve their Keligion, and proclaiming by their actions, that they are re≈øolved to Rebell rather than let it go.

11. Peaple‚ñ™ u≈øing their ≈øtrength and number to bring their Soveraigne to Terms, and endeavouring by all means po≈øsible ta Hough band him, (if I may be permitted to ≈øpeak in the Northern phra≈øe,) I meane not to leave it in his Rovver to hurt them, either in their Religion, Lawes, Lives, or E≈øtates, vvhich is, in plain English, to Unking him.

argument.p:
COPY of another Paper, mention'd p. 39. that the Authour publishes to shew how the Singularity, for which he was, cen≈øured by ≈øome, as before related, and de≈øpi≈øed by Others, (for hee knows him≈øelfe guilty of no other) was for practi≈øing this very following Method, him≈øelfe, when pre≈øent, and impo≈øing it on his Curates, when he was ab≈øent, to be by them al≈øo u≈øed in his Parishes: Or for other ≈øuch-like unfashionable ob≈øervation of the Churche's Rules, & performance of his Duty. Which upon ≈øtrict Enquiry into the Authour's Di≈øcharge of his Offices, (≈øince his fir≈øt ≈øettlement in the North of England,) will be found to be true; and may ≈øerve to evince, that as hee hath had the hard Fate to be Depo≈øed, for following his Soveraign into France, & ≈øticking to the Crovvne; ≈øo hath hee had as hard a Fate, heretofore, for cleaving to his Mother, [& regarding, more than Others, the Precepts of the Church] even to be oftentimes unju≈øtly Oppo≈øed, and ≈øometimes reproached, by his Brethren [Citty & Country-Clergy] merely for his Over doing,
as they have u≈øually term'd it. That is, in plaine English, becau≈øe his Con≈øcience would not give him leave to omit tho≈øe Duties, which they, and the generality of the Clergy in the nation, (I will, & may, now take more liberty than ever to ≈øpeak out) have, to their everla≈øting shame, ≈øcandalously neglected. And by the neglect whereof (in a word) have betrayed their Mother the Church of England, the Head of Reformed Chri≈øtendom; A very Odd kind of way to accomplish, what people pretend, the Support of the Prote≈øtant Religion.

That the houres for dayly Prayer, on VVorking-dayes, shall be ≈øix in the morning, & ≈øix in the evening, as the mo≈øt convenient for labourers, & men of bu≈øine≈øs.

That there shall be ≈øermons on all Fe≈øtivalls or Holy dayes. [Except there be an As people grevv more fond to hear Sermons than to amend their lives Homilies vvere mor ‚Ä¢ frequent.Homily vvhich shall not be oftenner than to countenance
the book, or a≈øsert the King‚ñ™s ≈øupremacy, according to the Canon, vvhich may very commodiously be done, in ≈øome of the Homilies Concerning Obedience, or again≈øt Di≈øobedience, being the very vvords of the Church] vvhich ≈øermons shall never exceed an halfe hour.

That the Curate, vvhen he bids Chri≈øtma≈øs, Ea≈øter‚ñ™ or Penteco≈øt‚ñ™ vvith their Fe≈øtivalls; as al≈øo vvhen he gives notice of Ember-vveek, Pa≈øsion-vveek, or Perambulation on Rogation-dayes, or other times extraordinary, he shall come dovvn to the desk [after the Niceene Creed] & do it in a more ≈øolemne manner, than vvhen he bids the ordinary Holy-dayes at the table, making a short ≈øpeech de tempore to quicken the People's Devotion.

That be≈øides the ≈øeverall Sacraments at Chri≈øtma≈øs, Ea≈øter-day, Holy-Thur≈øday & Penteco≈øt, there shal be, at lea≈øt, This practice changed into a monthly Sacrament, at the Combu≈øtions, in the yeare 1679.
5‚ñ™ other Sacraments, vvhich Sacraments shall be admini≈øter'd on the ≈øeverall d√†yes here nominated viz: on Nevv year's-day, on the fir≈øt ≈øunday in Lent, on the fir≈øt Sundays in July, October, & November.

That Ea≈øter shall be the time alvvayes for admi≈ø≈øion of Youth, fir≈øt at the Communion, vvho are never to be admitted till they have repair'd, upon ≈øummons, to the mini≈øter to receive private in≈øtruction, on vvens≈øday & Fryday-mornings, after ≈øervice during Lent.

That the young people be confirm'd after due in≈øtruction, before they receive, if po≈ø≈øible, but vvhen that cannot be contriv'd by rea≈øon of the Bishop's ab≈øence, or othervvi≈øe, that they, & their friends, be enjoyn'd faithfully to ≈øend them to the fir≈øt confirmation, vvhereof they shall have notice.

That vvhen Citations, Excommunications, or Ab≈øolutions are read, the Curate shall con≈øider vvhether he may, by any occa≈øionnall reflection out of the Desk, or from the pulpit, improve the ≈øame to the People to the deterring of them from the like offe ‚Ä¢ ces‚ñ™ for vvhich the per≈øons mention'd in the ≈øaid Acts of Court are proceeded again≈øt.

That the Curate do ≈øummon the Church-vvardens, tvvice at lea≈øt bevveen vi≈øitation & vi≈øitation, to read & con≈øider the vi≈øitation-articles, & to quicken & a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in the due di≈øcharges of their offices.

That the Curate shall on ≈øundayes & Holy-dayes (at lea≈øt) ob≈øerve a cour≈øe of per≈øonnal application (according to his promi≈øe at ordination) to the vvhole as vvell as ≈øick, vi≈øiting after evening-prayer, one family (if not more) on that account, ob≈øerving, as far as hee shall be able, the venerable Mr‚ñ™ George Herbert's method & rule to that purpo≈øe pre≈øcribed in his Country-Par≈øon, or Character of an holy Prei≈øt. VVhich book, as I recommend to all the Clergy in my Juri≈ødictions, so do I more e≈øpecialy to my Curates, for their rule & direction, in order to the exemplary di≈øcharge of their Function, having allvvayes made it mine.

That the Curate shall con≈øider frequently, at lea≈øt‚ñ™ once a quarter, vvhat Rubricks or Canons be mo≈øt neglected, & contemn'd by the parishoners; and that he doth‚ñ™ (be≈øides the ordinary explanation of the ≈øervice once a year, in obedience to his Maje≈øtie's Directions to Prearchers, read at convenient times the ≈øaid Rubricks to the people, that is to ≈øay betvveen the fri≈øt
≈øervice & Litany, or betvven Litany & ≈øecond Service, or before, or after ≈øermon, (omitting if occa≈øion require the p≈øalm then u≈øually ≈øung) & that he shall Zealously (but mildly) ≈øtirr up the people to the better ob≈øervation of the ≈øame; & that vvhen he di≈øcovers the≈øe publick admonitions ineffectuall, that he make it part of his labour, in private, vvith per≈øonnall applications to reforme ≈øuch irregularitys. And that he shall as frequently as he can (vvhen pre≈øentments are to be made) make ≈øuch applications, publick & private, (as shall appear mo≈øt convenient) to the offenders, in order to the prevention of their shame & expence, vvhich I de≈øire alvvayes may be done, vvithout further pro≈øecution, unle≈øs the thing cannot othervvi≈øe be reform'd.

That ≈øuch di≈øcour≈øes as he makes, about the Rubricks & Con≈øtitutions, may be u≈øually out of the Desk, or if occa≈øion require in the pulpit, after the ≈øermon, vvhich I vvould not have burthen'd often vvith the≈øe smaller matters relating only to good order; but re≈øerv'd for more ≈øub≈øtantial & e≈ø≈øential truths, as the Doctrins of Faith, Repentance, Love, Obedience, Temperance, &c.

That he doth not take notice of the People's breach of Rubricks, or ≈øuch di≈øorders, in publick, vvhen he can reforme the ≈øame ea≈øily in private, unle≈øs they are notorious & ≈øcandalous, in vvhich ca≈øe he is ≈øometimes to give particular per≈øons even publick reproofs, in the very Congregation.

That vvhen there is ground of ≈øu≈øpition that the Church-VVardens vvill not faithfully do their dutys in ≈øearching the Alehou≈øes, &c, that he go out of the Church ≈øometimes vvith them, for the more effectual prevention of di≈øorder.

That hee cau≈øe the Clarck to inquire (vvhen notice is given of Bapti≈øme) vvhether the vvitne≈øses have all receiv'd the Sacrament, & al≈øo to informe the Par≈øon (if the Church-vvardens do not) vvhen any excommunicat'd per≈øons enter the Church or Church-yard, to vvhich end & purpo≈øe there shall be a li≈øt kept in the Ve≈øtry of all per≈øons excommunicated.

div.head: IN REFERENCE TO THE FORE-GOING DIRECTIONS, Letters, & Di≈øcour≈øes, the Reader is de≈øired to note tho≈øe matters follovving.
div.p: FIRST, that here were intermingled, with the above≈øaid Directions for the Curates, ≈øundry advices for the Church-wardens & Parish-Clarks, not judged ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to be printed. The≈øe being ≈øufficient to accomplish the fore-mentioned end of their printing, (p. 39.) and convince tho≈øe Clergy (and others) who would not allow the authour to bee worthy of his ≈øtation (when he was admitted into his Deanery) that he did notwiths≈øtanding the great power of their evill example (who≈øe ≈øemiconformity fir≈øt poi≈øon'd the nation) at lea≈øt endeavour to be what hee all along cheifly aimed at, that is to ≈øay a Diligent COUNTRY-PARSON, if not good Archdeacon: He taking effectuall Care (and with no ill ≈øucce≈øs) that the≈øe his Rules should be, as they were, better ob≈øer'd by his Curates, then the Church-Cannons or Rubricks were by them, & the generality of the Clergy of the nation; and con≈øequently in due time might have become a tollerable Deane, by Gods ble≈øsing, if the CITTY-REBELS, Joyning with the Invaders, had not driven him with his ma≈øter out of England.

SECONDLY, the Reader is de≈øird to take further notice, that this‚ñ™ la≈øt‚ñ™
‚Ä¢ etter, (to wit to his Curates) was not printed when the others were, (as fir≈øt intended and mentioned in the Title-Page,) in the yeare 1689, but was, for certain rea≈øons underwritten, deferr'd to be put into the Pre≈øs, till the month & yeare mark'd in the conclu≈øion of the ≈øaid letter, to wit Oct: 1691, ≈øome months after the Dean's Deprivation; Which delay, among other things, hinder'd the more speedy Publication of all the other papers, and was occa≈øiond upon the three en≈øuing accounts; „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Fir≈øt, the Deane imagined, on ≈øecond thoughts, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ that ≈øo plaine a Rebuke as the faithfull di≈øcharge of his „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Con≈øcience, in the delivery of the Di≈øcour≈øes hee hath
printed‚ñ™ & the penning of the fore-going letters hee hath publish'd, in his own name, did, by reflection, ca≈øt on many con≈øiderable [Spirituall & Temporall] Supporters of the U≈øurped Authority in Churc ‚Ä¢ & State, was an Underaking too mighty for him, who never delighted to expo≈øe or reproach his Superiours in any manner; nor should have dared thus to have done it, at this time, had not too many of them, manefe≈øtly departed from and contradicted the very Doctrine of the Church of England, which they, as well as hee, had ≈øworne to maintaine.

Secondly, He long expected that ≈øome eminent per≈øon in England, better qualified, would have ≈øaved him the labour of ≈øuch an application, as he hath here in print made to the people under his authority, by publishing, ere this, ≈øome ≈øub≈øtantiall work that should have ≈øtrenuously a≈ø≈øerted the Cau≈øe of King James the 2, & that Church of England whereof he is ≈øupreme Governour, by unmasking the wickedne≈øs, inju≈øtice, and ingratitude, nay unnaturallne≈øs of Dethroning their lawfull Soveraign, and under a religious pretence u≈øurp his Crowne; The afore-≈øaid Per≈øon not ≈øticking, to ≈øet his name thereto, tho it might have co≈øt him his life, to proclaime undeniably to the World, that what hee writ hee beleived to be ≈øuch truth of God, as hee did dare ≈øeale with his Bloud. Which desireable peice of Charity to the ≈øoules of the poor people, who were unhappily drawn into Perjury, by the powerfull Example of their leaders, the authour hath not yet di≈øcover'd to be done by any, tho he thinks ought to have been performed long ago (what ever had been the i≈ø≈øue) to have given right mea≈øures to the People of the Land, while they were ≈øtaggerring, & not quite fallen into the abominable ≈øins of Perjury, and Renouncing their Allegiance. Which Chri≈øtian work, if it had been acted, in due ≈øea≈øon, would, among other good effects, have edified al≈øo the Dean's Flocks, and render'd unnece≈ø≈øary what hee‚ñ™ hath ≈øaid
to keep tho≈øe ≈øteddy who ≈øtand, & to re≈øtore tho≈øe who are fallen, for want of timely under-propping. The authour's earne≈øt longing, and waiting with great impa ‚Ä¢ ience‚ñ™ to have ≈øeen ≈øuch de≈øireable fruit of Primitive zeale, did detaine him a while from plunging him≈øelfe over head & ears, (tho hee made many offers ≈øo to do) into that Deluge which did over-spred the land; thinking him≈øelfe a bad swinmer in ≈øuch Troubled waters; & moreover (like Elihu Job. 32. 4.) being very unwilling to ≈øpeake out thus boldly, & shame the ≈øilence of his Elders, till hee had given them all ≈øufficient opportunity to ≈øpeak and write; Tho his boldne≈øs & zeale (as may be ob≈øerv'd, by the way, & is before noted,) was not levell'd, directly, to any but tho≈øe under his own Charge & Care (or nearly related to him) to whom ≈øuch a hearty application, and ≈øuch plain Reproofs, even in the very language of the letters, became ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, that hee could not, in good Con≈øcience, have wav'd them. And therefore he conceiv's that people have the le≈ø≈øe rea≈øon to be di≈øturbed thereby.

Thirdly, after the authour had made a con≈øiderable progre≈øs in printing the letters and other di≈øcour≈øes he was forced to undertake a hazardous Journey into England Feb. 1689 (whereby hee got a ≈ømall ≈øuply of money to ≈øub≈øi≈øt a while abroad without defiling him≈øelfe with any Oath of fidelity to the Prince of Orange,) tho with much trouble and Danger, occa≈øion'd him by an impertinent and malitious Po≈øtma≈øter, who di≈øcover'd him in Canterbury. Which voyage made it ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to lay a≈øide, till his returne, his de≈øigne of publishing the papers he had penn'd at his fir≈øt Coming over, unle≈øs he would willfully, and unavoidably, have run his neck into a halter. Which, all know, was the Fate lately of a Mr. Ashton.right hone≈øt and loyall man.

THIRDLY, all ≈øorts of Readers may hereby be informed, that the≈øe papers are, at this time, the more hastily published without polishing, becau≈øe the authour, hath had this ≈øummer after a
long intervall, ≈øome returne of tho≈øe infirmities that he brought out of England‚ñ™ which being ≈øea≈øonable memento's of the mortality of his condition, and uncertainty of his life, have cau≈øed him, without any more ado, or longer delay, thus plainly and hone≈øtly to deliver his ≈øoule: the comfort of which doth to him abundantly ballance the unea≈øine≈øs of any obloquy, which may accrew from the provoked friends of the new government in England, where he de≈øires to appeare no more, (unle≈øs it plea≈øe God to re≈øtore his Soveraign,) as all may be per≈øwaded ea≈øily to beleive, by his pre≈øent manner of proceeding.

Fourthly. All tho≈øe who shall blame the Dean's undertaking, may, in a word, ≈øatisfy them≈øelves, that hee had never thus expo≈øed him≈øelfe to their cen≈øure, if hee had beleived that a a Dignified Divine in his circum≈øtances (being the onely one here abroad out of the Reach of England, and who≈øe Con≈øcience would not permit him to ≈øwallow any new di≈øpen≈øatory oathes, or di≈øtinctions) could without the ju≈øt cen≈øure of all right Church‚ñ™of England-men, and loyall ≈øubjects to King James 2., have remained ≈øilent. Since hee hath not now tho≈øe prudentiall con≈øiderations, that others have, to ≈øtop his mouth, or ≈øtay his pen: His own per≈øon being ≈øecure & his Revenue lo≈øt. Whereas hone≈øt Divines & men in England (where hee hopes there be many that never bovved the knee to Baal, tho hee be ignorant who they are) cannot attempt what hee does, without the hazard of their lives, or ruine of their familyes. And therefore concludes that a weak and bad performance, as this, of ≈øo good & ≈øpirituall a de≈øigne (the more incumbent on him) would be better than none at all, and be gratiously accepted, through JESUS-CHRIST, by that ALMIGHTY GOD who can make the poore≈øt enterpri≈øes in his name, ≈øucce≈øsefull to accomplish his will.

Fiftly, & la≈øtly, the Dean's innate indignation to many former, & late prepo≈øterous unaccountable procedures in the Subjects of England: to wit, Fir≈øt the Non-conformity, or rather Semiconformity, of the Clergy (who did with zeale more than enough, & ≈øometimes too bitterly, inveigh again≈øt nonconformi≈øts) which ingendred that Brood which are the authours of our Mi≈øery: Secondly their Forvvardne≈øs to di≈øpen≈øe throughout the Nation, with the Church-Di≈øcipline, as they pleas'd, where & when, there appear'd no
nece≈ø≈øity; nay with the very Rubricks of the Liturgy, whereto they had all, ≈øince the late review, given a ≈øolemne A≈øsent & Con≈øent‚ñ™ ≈øadly pre≈øaging that in time of di≈øtre≈øs they would, as they have done, di≈øpen≈øe with the very Doctrine, tho they would not allow his Maje≈øty in extraordinary ca≈øes, √† le≈øs di≈øpen≈øing Power: Thirdly the Pragmaticallne≈øs of mo≈øt Common-Lavvye ‚Ä¢ s (who≈øe duty and intre≈øt it was, as well as of the Eccle≈øia≈øticks, to joyne in the ≈øupport of the crown of their Soveraign, the Fountaine whence all their Law did proceed) in endeavouring indu≈øtriou≈øly by all manner of quirks, to diminish the King's Prerogative & Authority, even coining wicked di≈øtinctions, & taking up ob≈øolete lawes to dethrone him (when there were enough of ≈øuch which they would not willingly have reviv'd again≈øt the People or them≈øelves) nay flying to the Reign of an U≈øurper for Acts of Pa ‚Ä¢ iament to ju≈øtify and colour over their full≈øome proceedings; as if a Di≈øpen≈øing power in the People was like to be found more tollerable than in the King, or that ≈øuch a kind of ≈øupremacy as the multitude contended for, (and which mu≈øt be either in Prince, or ≈øubject) is le≈øs liable to Tyranny, and other abu≈øes, when it is in the ≈øubject, than in the Soveraign.

The≈øe, and the like, perver≈øions of Law and Religion, did cau≈øe, (the authour profe≈øseth & is de≈øirous to proclaime) ≈øo much di≈øgu≈øt in his Soule, as hurried him over all the difficulties and dangers that he met with, in his way to this publication, in ≈øuch a degree, that the con≈øideration of his book's reflecting on the new Government (which was de≈øigned to edify the people within his own province) hath push'd him on, in≈øtead of deterring him‚ñ™ to ≈øend it forth into the light (committing it and his reputation to the mercy of a Gratious God) amid≈øt a crooked and perver≈øe Generation, which hee is willing may learne thus much by his boldne≈øs, (or fool-hardine≈øs as it will be po≈ø≈øibly termed,) to wit, that God hath given him (among a multitude of infirmities,) the Grace not to be afraid or ashamed to do his duty or di≈øcharge his offices faithfully, who ever may be rebuked by the doing thereof; and that hee is ≈øure, hee had done neither, if hee had not, as hee hath done, deliver'd his ≈øoule, without mincing, in ≈øuch plaine and intelligible language, at ≈øuch a juncture, as to allot, every thing its right epithet & appellation; giving the very names of REBELLION
& USURPATION to what, hee was per≈øwaded in his con≈øcience, de≈øerv'd ≈øuch denominations; and that are ≈øo, [even REBELLION & USURPATION,] if ever there were ≈øuch things in the World. Yea ≈øuch a REBELLION & USURPATION that no good Chri≈øtian can, hee is al≈øo ≈øatisfied in his Con≈øcience, joyne in the fir≈øt, or uphold the later, and con≈øequently, that no body can receive the communion, without injury to his ≈øoule, in the u≈øe of tho≈øe prayers, which pray for the maintaining of both; ≈øince hee that receives the ble≈ø≈øed Supper of the Lord, in the office of any Church, ≈øets his ≈øeale to all the corruptions that are crept into that Church, and doth, in a higher manner‚ñ™, profane Gods ≈øacred name, by u≈øing that holy ordinance to ≈øo impious an end (as to beg of God, by vertue of his ≈øaviours body and blood, the di≈øtruction of his lawfull Prince) than hee that barely ≈øwears allegiance to an U≈øurper, Which, yet by the way, who ever does, (let him under≈øtand) doth in a manner, Abjure his lawfull Soveraign.

Which is a Ca≈øe of Con≈øcience that the Authour will, in Gods name, now venture here publickly to decide (as hee hath long ≈øince don to ≈øome in private) and put his name to the deci≈øion, what ever comes of it, ≈øince no body el≈øe hath done ≈øo, for the ≈øake of tho≈øe many thousands of ≈øoules, under his authority, in the Jurisdictons belonging to the Archdeacon & Deane of Durham; whereof none can deny but that hee hath a Call from God to take care. And con≈øequently to undertake this difficult province, ≈øince no body el≈øe do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Who, if they are not ≈øatisfied with his Judgement in this particular (which, as poor as they may e≈øteeme it, will yet hee tru≈øts, in reference hereto, be found Orthodox) ought to con≈øult, as it concernes them, ≈øome abler Ca≈øui≈øt: without being ≈øcared, (as heretofore in ≈øome other ca≈øes,) with frightfull con≈øequences, admini≈øtred by the Univer≈øality of the DEFECTION & ≈øuch like con≈øiderations; to wit, Empty Churches & thin Altars.

For if it be a whole≈øom truth which is recomended, by the Authour, to their thoughts, it cannot, he is ≈øure, in the conclu≈øion, produce ill effects to be repented of. And he begs pardon, if he cannot prevaile with him≈øelfe to judge, the la≈øt recited effects to be ill, as matters go, & things ≈øtand. For hee makes no doubt, but that the Churches in England mu≈øt become Empty, & the Altars thin &c. before his Soveraign is like to return to Whitehall,
